PROCTEXT.PARA: Madam SPEAKER (Hon. Joan Child) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: `Authority Required' Prescriptions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens showeth:

that your petitioners deplore the Federal Government's decision to remove 53 Pharmaceutical drugs from the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme including the best available treatment of high blood pressure, cancer, epilepsy, high cholesterol and uneven heartbeat-and place them for cost saving reasons only on a special list requiring Authority from a Canberra bureaucrat, and;

that we believe a patient's doctor is clearly the best judge for medication needed for their particular illness and that it is therefore wrong and unfair to force that doctor to seek permission from a bureaucrat in Canberra who has no personal knowledge of that case.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will call on the Government to immediately abandon the proposal and keep its election promise of high quality and universal health care for all Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beazley (from 28 citizens), Dr Blewett (from 10 citizens), Mr John Brown (from 27 citizens), Mr Cadman (from 18 citizens), Mr Charles (from 54 citizens), Mr Downer (from 27 citizens), Mr Fife (from 200 citizens), Mr Tim Fischer (from 169 citizens), Mrs Harvey (from 162 citizens), Mr McArthur (from 289 citizens), Mr Mountford (from 243 citizens), Mr Porter (from 47 citizens), Mr Pratt (from 182 citizens), Mr Ruddock (from 376 citizens), Mr Shack (from 27 citizens), Mr Sharp (from 226 citizens), Mr Simmons (from 42 citizens), Mr Tickner (from 95 citizens), Mr Tuckey (from 58 citizens) and Mr Webster (from 28 citizens).

PETITION.PRESENTERS: BEALE; CAMERON; CHYNOWETH; DOWNER; HAWKE; JAKOBSEN; KERR; LANGMORE; MILES; PRATT; SHACK; WILSON; WOODS
PETITION.TITLE: X- and R-Rated Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of citizens of Australia points out that the community deplores the persistent refusal to ban pornography in X and NVE Videos, Films and Publications, and deplores the resulting escalation of crime and sexual crime in the Australian community.
Because parliament has a direct and heavy obligation to ensure the safety of women and child-victims, your petitioners therefore request the House:

to ban the importation and availability of pornography in Videos, Films and Publications, to prevent black-market trading by banning the possession of X and NVE material, vote against any recommendation to extend Video and Theatre Film Classifications and Guidelines into television standards, ensure that Pay Television does not exceed the programme limits of Television standards, control all censorship criteria and guidelines by substantive legislation, give earnest consideration to these matters, in order that no Attorney-General shall ever again have the power to change our social and home environment for generations to come, without thorough and full debate in both Houses of Parliament.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beale (from four citizens), Mr Donald Cameron (from 83 citizens), Mr Chynoweth (from 36 citizens), Mr Downer (from 41 citizens), Mr Hawke (from 43 citizens), Mrs Jakobsen (from 257 citizens), Mr Kerr (from 12 citizens), Mr Langmore (from 20 citizens), Mr Miles (from 49 citizens), Mr Pratt (from 50 citizens), Mr Shack (from 195 citizens), Mr Wilson (from 64 citizens), and Dr Woods (from 32 citizens).

PETITION.PRESENTERS: DARLING; HOLDING; HOLLIS; MCHUGH; MILTON; SAWFORD; THEOPHANOUS

PETITION.TITLE: Forests of South-Eastern Australia
PETITION.PARA: Petition to the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives Assembled in Parliament. The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of this House that we are concerned at the threats caused by logging to the integrity and continued existence of what remains of the forests of south eastern Australia.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to direct the Prime Minister and his government
(1) to phase out woodchipping for export;
(2) not to renew long-term export licence to Harris Daishowa;

(3) to ensure that sensitive environmental areas, and specifically the proposed national park and wilderness areas of Coolangubra, Cathcart, Egan Peaks and the Tantawangalo catchment, are protected and excluded from the proposed woodchip export licence; and
(4) to promote ecologically sound and sustainable forestry practices including:
re-afforestation and plantation of native hardwoods and already cleared land to reduce pressure on native forests; and
minimisation of wasteful uses of forest products.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Darling (from 1,200 citizens), Mr Holding (from 233 citizens), Mr Hollis (from 438 citizens), Ms McHugh (from 2,573 citizens), Mr Milton (from 2,352 citizens), Mr Sawford (from 647 citizens) and Dr Theophanous (from 1,200 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:
1. They are completely satisfied with the design of the existing Australian National Flag.
2. They are aware it properly reflects the immutable characteristics of Australia, namely:
(a) The Union Jack, itself the creation of three Christian Crosses, represents the Nation's historical origin and the source of its language and law;
(b) The Southern Cross on an azure blue background signifying its geographical location on this planet Earth;
(c) The large star depicting the advent of Federation in 1901.
3. They know the Flag has been a source of inspiration to generations of Australians in peace and war.
4. They recall that millions of native-born Australians and newcomers to these shores from other parts of the world have become united under its proud symbolism.
5. they are certain that any change to the Flag will produce division in the Australian community.
Your petitioners therefore pray that your honourable House will.
Propose and pass a motion that ``the existing Australian National Flag be changed only with the approval of the Nation as expressed in a Referendum''.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Brumby (from 34 citizens), Mr Charles (from 50 citizens), Mr Chynoweth (from 10 citizens), Mr Hawke (from 51 citizens) and Mr Staples (from 32 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and the Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth:
That your petitioners request that major reforms be made to Australia's Retirement Income System. These reforms are earnestly sought by retired Australians and those facing retirement.
The reforms are:
That the pension be increased to 30% of average weekly earnings (i.e. increasing the basic pension to $146 p.w.).
That the pension become tax exempt.
That the pension be adjusted so that it keeps pace with price rises rather than falling up to 12 months behind.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray that your House/Parliament will see that our requested reforms are implemented.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Brumby (from 22 citizens) and Mrs Sullivan (from 1,159 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Health Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that,
Australia's population is ageing and most people require more health services as they grow older.
if open not-for-profit health Funds are to be able to meet the costs of providing benefits to their older members at affordable rates, they need to share these costs equitably.
some health insurance organisations are being allowed to avoid meeting the health costs of sick and elderly people.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to,
take the necessary action to reverse rising cost trends and provide positive incentives to encourage all health funds to share the cost of health care for sick and elderly Australians.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Donald Cameron (from 231 citizens) and Mr Cross (from 320 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Pension Entitlements
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned shows:

We are gravely concerned at the Government's proposal to reduce significantly the pension and access to Fringe Benefits of persons who, in good faith, bought market-linked insurance bonds, Friendly Society bonds, approved deposit funds, deferred annuities and unit trusts, to protect their savings.
Your Petitioners request that:
The House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, amend the proposed legislation to ensure that it will not apply retrospectively and that provision is made to protect savings against inflation.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr McArthur (from 75 citizens) and Mr Pratt (from 20 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: X-Rated Videos
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that both Federal and State Attorneys General support the banning of X-rated videos.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to pass legislation banning X-rated videos.

PETITION.TITLE: Volunteer Referral Agencies
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The petition of certain concerned citizens of Australia from the many electorates of New South Wales shows the grave injustice to the Community Volunteer Programme (C.V.P) in the new Skillshare package.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the implementation of the volunteer referral agencies (V.R.A) be established, and that Voluntary effort for all Australian Citizens be recognised. To ``keep our job centres going''. And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: International Earth Repair Action Decade
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of concerned Australian citizens respectfully points out that:
our total global environment is rapidly deteriorating;
important natural resources vital to human life and livelihood such as ozone, trees, soil and water are being depleted at an increasing and alarming rate;
there is an urgent need to educate all people in conservation skills and the responsible use and maintenance of natural resources;
the United Nations Association of Australia (UNAA) has proclaimed an Australian Earth Repair Action (ERA) Decade from 1988;
Earth Repair Action will unite people, communities, religions and nations in the productive purpose of greening and repairing our Earth for a safer and more peaceful future.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament will:

Propose that an International Earth Repair Action (ERA) Decade begin on World Environment Day, June 5, 1990 with FIERY, the First International Earth Repair Year, and that this be proclaimed by the United Nations General Assembly. This ten-year plan will ignite the spirit of local and global co-operation to hygienically compost all presently wasted bio-degradable material into humus to revitalise soils; grow billions of trees to replace forests lost and replenish the atmosphere; establish sustainable, economic and agricultural growth internationally and end world hunger.

PETITION.TITLE: Eligibility for Austudy or the Isolated Children's Allowance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that the introduction of an Assets Test for Austudy and Isolated Children's Allowance for students, particularly in country areas, is unfair and excludes many students from financial help where parents do not have a substantial income.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House abolish the Assets Test and use an Income Test to determine eligibility for the payment of Austudy or the Isolated Children's Allowance.

PETITION.TITLE: Crime and Violence on Television
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that there is too much crime and violence on television and this is breaking down the standards and codes of behaviour in our society.

Your petitioners therefore ask the House to call on the Federal Government to require Television Stations to improve the standards of shows, news and current affairs programmes by reducing the incidence of crime and violence broadcast every day into people's homes.

PETITION.TITLE: Sponsorship of Australian Broadcasting Corporation Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the House-
1. That the ABC should remain independent and free of commercial interests.
2. That the ABC should maintain a full range of quality radio and television programmes.
3. That the ABC continue all regional services to rural Australia.
4. To the extent possible the ABC should play an active role in the cultural life of Australia.
5. That the ABC ensure cost-effective procedures are maintained.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House-
1. Reject any proposal to allow corporate sponsorship of ABC programmes.
2. Allocate sufficient funds from consolidated revenue to ensure the ABC remains a free and independent national broadcaster of quality programmes.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House-
(a) The introduction of time charge for local telephone calls would discriminate against ordinary telephone users.
(b) Time charge would be unfair to pensioners, handicapped people and low income earners.
(c) Telecom should introduce a charge for business usage in order to recover the cost of transferring business data.
(d) Telephone subscribers should not be required to subsidise the cost of transferring business data.
Your petitioners therefore request the House-
(a) That time charging not be introduced by Telecom.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens in Australia, draws to the attention of the House that the irradiation of food by any means degrades the nutritional value of food and is potentially harmful to the health of all consumers and to the environment.
Your petitioners therefore request that your honourable House:
1. Withdraw from the Asian Regional Co-operative Project on Food Irradiation and from the International Consultative Group on Food Irradiation.
2. Take all possible steps to prevent and disallow the irradiation of food in Australia.
3. Ban the export and importation of irradiated foods and animal feeds.
4. Take steps to obtain a testing device to make possible the identification of irradiated foods, as soon as one becomes available.

PETITION.TITLE: AGPS Style Manual
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of The House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that:
The Sex Discrimination chapter of the Style Manual interferes with the Australian language;
The Sex Discrimination chapter would bring an enormous cost to bear on ordinary Australians if its suggestions were applied;
The Sex Discrimination chapter would make the Australian language unwieldy and artificially destroy commonly used and understood expressions;
The Sex Discrimination chapter seeks to invalidate accepted characteristics of the Australian language and destroy part of our national heritage and identity;
The Sex Discrimination chapter trivialises our literary past and the great literature of the world by its promulgation of mediocre substitutionary language.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House move for a complete review of the Sex Discrimination chapter of the Style Manual.

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Force Vehicles: Drivers Licences and Registration
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of The House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that
Service Personnel postings generally occur within every two years
Postings are generally interstate
Changing vehicle drivers licences and registration causes considerable inconveniences
There is a heavy cost involved in frequently changing current licences and vehicle registration.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House grant a Defence Force vehicle drivers licence and a Defence Force motor vehicle registration for use Australia wide that is not subject to State changes and which is acceptable to all States.

PETITION.TITLE: PAYE Taxes and Sales Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that
The Federal Government has reaped an unprecedented amount of revenue in taxation recently, over and above expectations:
PAYE tax payers are losing one quarter and more of earnings through direct tax deductions:
Sales taxes which are charged on a vast range of everyday goods and necessities add to the taxes already imposed on wage earners:
The range of compulsory licences, fees, and charges imposed by governments and Statutory Authorities further erode family disposable incomes.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House immediately reduce PAYE taxes and all Sales Taxes by one third and hold all Government and Statutory Authority charges at the current level for a minimum four-year period.

PETITION.TITLE: The Last Temptation of Christ
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that
Jesus Christ personifies the perfect standard of behaviour and ideals for humanity out in Holy Scripture:
Any attack on the perfection of Jesus Christ is a vilification of Christ, and of Jehovah as portrayed in the Scriptures, and Who is worshipped on the basis of Scriptural portrayal:
The film, ``The Last Temptation of Christ'', is just such an attack on the basics of the values held by many Australian citizens.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House immediately act to have the film banned from Australia and so cease to condone the public vilification of Christian ethics.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Charges
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament Assembled
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
The introduction of time-charging for local telephone calls by Telecom Australia would isolate many elderly and disabled people who depend on telephone services for communication and social contact
That the greatest effect will be on isolated people and communities and will add to their disadvantages in that it will restrict social contact
The lifestyle of many people will be downgraded to facilitate business abuse of a technological device.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Totally reject plans by Telecom for time-charge local calls as a serious impost on housebound and isolated members of the community.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: The Philippines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that
The Philippines remains wracked by inequalities of wealth and power, senseless destruction and unjust violence, the wasteful degredation of human life, oppression and deprivation:
The growth of vigilante death squads plus arbitrary arrests and other atrocities by armed forces has increased in the Philippines over the last two years:
There is an apparent inability of the Aquino Government to stem the wave of corruption and human rights violations:
There is a growing atmosphere of violence, hatred, intolerance and injustice in the Philippines.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House give consideration to
(a) Our concern for the Defence Co-operations Program's involvement with the Armed Forces of the Philippines,
(b) A cessation of all military aid to the Philippine Military by Government or Private Companies and
(c) A ban on the training of Filipino military in Australia
Until human rights are observed in the Philippines.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Rural Programs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that
Listeners to ABC in country regions are dependent on advice and information provided in farming segments of ABC programs, particularly ``Farming Today'' and ``National Farm Report''
Information in programs as presently presented is relevant to the region in which it is broadcast and this is vital to country regions.
Country listeners have a long established, traditional link with ABC rural programs and a reliance on those services.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House ask the ABC to review its decision to alter its rural programs in any way.

PETITION.TITLE: Crime and Violence on Television
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House
There is too much crime and violence on TV and this is breaking down the standards and codes of behaviour in our society.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House compel TV stations to improve the standards of shows, news and current affairs programs by reducing the incidence of crime and violence broadcast every day into people's homes, by fifty per cent.

PETITION.TITLE: Broken Hill South Post Office
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain electors of Riverina Darling, Sub-division of Broken Hill South, in the State of New South Wales, points out to the House that it is the intention of The Director of Posts and Telegraphs to downgrade the South Broken Hill Post Office and to possibly convert it to an agency in the not so distant future, the reason being given that business has decreased over recent years.

Your petitioners pray that the House direct The Minister to keep the South Broken Hill Post Office open for as long as foreseeable, as it serves a population of 6000 or more people, many of whom are pensioners and do not have transport. It is significant that the fall-off in business parallels the decision of the local postmaster to close for lunch. The business area has suffered very badly in the middle of the day as a result and in the early afternoon. Many residents who used the Postal Services in this general period mentioned, now bypass the shopping area as they know they cannot avail themselves of mail services when they wish between 9 a.m. and 5 p.m.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Reform
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the leader and members of the House of Representatives of Australia:
the petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully shows that there has been clear demonstration of public dissatisfaction with mismanagement of the Otway forests in Victoria, and we pray that:
The Constitution of Australia be reformed to recognise significant public expressions of concern, e.g. petitions, by some action, e.g. referendums or committees of inquiry.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Allowance Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned shows:
We, the undersigned, are greatly disturbed at the recent changes that have taken place in relation to the Family Allowance Scheme.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled will re-examine the changes that have been initiated and re-examine their consequence on the people concerned.

PETITION.TITLE: Sale of Violent Videos and Books and Toys of Violence
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The sale of violent videos, books glorifying violence, and toys of violence encourages violence in the community, and has a deleterious effect on the more vulnerable members of the community who are easily influenced.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled, urge the Government to:
Ban the sale of violent videos, books and toys of violence, in an effort to put an end to the increasing number of violent crimes committed in this country.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: X- and R-Rated Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned,

note that a majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material has strongly opposed the proposition that a new NVE category will contain that material as defined in the current `X' classification.

call upon the House of Representatives to request the Government immediately to implement the recommendation of the majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material by introducing substantive legislation to ensure that X rated video material (and its R rated equivalent) is refused classification for the purpose of Commonwealth laws.
And Your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: X- and R-Rated Video Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:
X-rated video material contravenes Christian moral beliefs in that,
1. the status of both women and men are degraded by the material,
2. children could gain access to the material, much to the detriment of their moral development,
3. the material often promotes and encourages criminal acts.

Your petitioners therefore ask the House to put pressure on the Government immediately to implement the recommendation of the majority of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material by introducing substantive legislation to ensure that X-rated video material (and its R-rated equivalent) is refused classification for the purposes of Commonwealth laws.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Electoral Commission Office, Burnie, Tasmania
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled, the Petition of certain electors of the Division of Braddon draws the attention of the House to the proposal to close the Burnie Office of the Australian Electoral Commission.
We believe:
1. That the proposed closure is not in the best interests of democracy.
2. That closure will further erode jobs in regional areas of Australia.
3. That we oppose the further centralisation of government services at the expense of rural and isolated communities.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will oppose the closure.

PETITION.TITLE: Soviet Fishing Agreement
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and all members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the activities of the Soviet Union in our region and in particular the South Pacific are detrimental to and threaten the security of our country.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House urge the Government not to enter into a fishing agreement with the Soviet Union.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Advertising of Alcohol
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House that:
Alcohol is recognised as Australia's number one drug problem which is responsible for at least 50% of all road fatalities; a high percentage of serious crime and vandalism.
Hospital beds are filled with sufferers of the many alcohol related diseases including; cirrhosis of the liver; heart disease; stomach ulcers; various forms of cancer and mental illness.
Alcohol causes much family unhappiness and marriage breakdown, as well as being involved in some cases of child abuse and molestation.
Television and radio have a persuasive effect on children and young people.
Your petitioners therefore request the House to ban all advertising of alcohol on television and radio.

PETITION.TITLE: Voluntary Vote for People Aged 80 and Over
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the House the plight of many frail aged people and the unnecessary stress they suffer through the compulsory voting system in local, state and federal elections. Due to their difficulties in concentrating on life outside their own home, many require assistance in voting and also the conveyancing back and forth in order for them to register their vote.

Your petitioners therefore request the house to amend the legislation to allow people aged 80 and over to exercise a voluntary vote at their discretion without fear of fine or recrimination if they do not vote, and many agencies will then be freed from the burden and cost of herding the frail aged to the polling booth, it will also prevent the need of other persons exercising a second de facto vote in order to ease the distress of the puzzled voter.
May love and compassion be your guide.

PETITION.TITLE: Road Funding
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens respectfully showeth that:

Australians living in rural and non-urban areas rely extensively on the local road network for all facets of their lives. Funding for roads is an essential part of the Commonwealth's responsibilities for the maintenance of the transport infra-structure. Road funding under the Hawke Government has decreased significantly in real terms and local government is particularly disadvantaged by this decline.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled,

Oppose any proposal to absorb road funds into General Revenue Assistance to either Local or State Governments; and immediately address the serious problem of a rapidly deteriorating road network which is confronting local government by allocating more resources to local road funding.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of certain citizens of Australia points out to the House that:
1. Parliament should allow insurance for the gap between the Medicare rebate and the scheduled fee.
2. That the unfair discrimination against private patients in hospital should be withdrawn.

Your petitioners therefore request the House take action to ensure that all patients receive an equal Medicare rebate for services regardless of where they are provided, on the understanding that all patients pay the same compulsory Medicare insurance levy.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding for the Committee for Assistance to Italians
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia, draws to the attention of the House, that we are disappointed and angered by the decision by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs to cut funding for some important and effective services offered by CO.AS.IT. (Sydney) to us and the whole Italian community.

Your petitioners therefore request that the House call on the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, to reverse his decision and reinstate funding for these essential services as soon as possible.
I Dr Bob Woods, Federal Member for Lowe hereby certify that this following paragraph in Italian is in essence the same as the above.

Noi sottoscritti, accogliamo con rabbia e disappunto la decisione dal Vostro Dipartimento di eliminare sussidi per alcuni importanti ed efficienti servizi offerti dal CO.AS.IT. (Sydney a noi ed all `intera comunita' italiana.
Chiediamo al Ministro di tornare sulla sua decisione e di ristabilire al piu' presto possibile, fondi per questi essenziali servizi.

PETITION.TITLE: Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in Parliament:
The petition of residents of Drummoyne, Sydney, in the state of N.S.W. draws to the attention of the House that:

1. Residents of Drummoyne, who are in the direct flight path of aircraft landing on or departing from the northern runway of Sydney's Kingsford-Smith Airport, are concerned about new curfew arrangements due to come into force as from the 31st October 1988.
2. They believe that these will lead to increased air traffic over Drummoyne especially between 11 p.m. to 12 midnight and 5 a.m. to 6 a.m. in the morning.

3. They are concerned that a Curfew Monitoring Committee proposed by the Federal Government to comprise 10 representatives of local councils effected by flight paths, including Drummoyne Council, due to come into force from November 1988, will be ineffectual.
4. The Committee will have no powers to penalise pilots and airlines that ignore the runway and curfew restrictions.
Your petitioners therefore request that the House immediately
1. Call for an pledge that these new flight arrangements will be permanently restricted to the Botany Bay runways and
2. Legislate to provide effective penalties for breach of these flight restrictions.

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with standing order 28a (f), on behalf of the Committee of Members' Interests, I present the report on the operations of the Committee for 1988.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EMPLOYMENT, EDUCATION AND TRAINING

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brumby Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, I present the Committee's report entitled An Apple for the Teacher-Choice and Technology in Learning, together with the minutes of the proceedings and the evidence received by the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —In essence, the report looks at the ways in which new technology can open up educational opportunities to more people and the ways in which the quality of education can be improved. In the terms of the trade, the report looks at the ways in which technology can improve educational access and outcomes and what this requires. Improving educational access and outcomes using new technology should not be dismissed as an abstract or symbolic endeavour-yet another gentle stroll through the garden of education, pushing the perambulator of better learning; nor should the topic of increasing educational access and outcomes be pigeonholed as a purely technical matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Use of technology to improve the availability and quality of education is not a technical issue which concerns only people of mellifluous manner in dark three-piece suits trying to sell the latest model of machine. Educational technology does not concern only uncommunicative technicians in white coats busy pulling cables through the roof; nor is educational technology only the province of wide-eyed teachers enthralled with the use of facsimile, videos, computer graphics or desktop publishing. The issue of how to use technology to improve educational access and outcomes transcends both social and technical areas of interest. In fact, it is a matter which typifies the close interrelationships in, and complex goals of, Government policies to advance social equity and economic development.

There is both an economic and a social imperative to expand educational opportunities to as wide a range of Australians as possible. Education can assist people to become socially capable citizens who understand, and are able to contribute to, their society. Not only does education critically and crucially influence personal development and economic advancement, but also it fundamentally affects the wellbeing, productivity and adaptability of our economy at large. There is an economic necessity to ensure that within an expanded range of educational opportunities-in other words, with this improved access-we provide the best learning experience possible, that is, the best outcomes of these opportunities.

In examining access, the Committee was concerned to see how more people, and especially the more disadvantaged groups, could be given further opportunities for education with new forms of technology. This applies particularly to people cut off from access to conventional education by geographic isolation or by other circumstances of their employment or personal lives. In examining outcomes, the Committee focused on how the quality of education can be broadened, enriched and stimulated by the application of new forms of technology to the educational process. The Committee concluded that new forms of technology can improve educational access and outcomes but that new technology is not necessarily the required or the limiting factor. Older forms of technology such as printing, radio and television have their place. I shall return to this point later.

If technology is to be used successfully to improve educational access and outcomes we must choose the appropriate form of technology for the particular task at hand and manage it well. Success depends on the way technology and learning is organised and supported. New technology is not in itself enough to open new doors more widely. Access to learning must be translated into choice for the learner. In other words access should also involve the application of the principles of what is known as `open learning'. Open learning attempts to give students as much choice as possible-for example, in choice of subject, structure and location of study and method and timing of assessment. Open learning is much more than external study. As I am sure the Minister knows only too well, courses of external study can be remarkably unopen, except in so far as they are offered off campus. An open learning approach can be made possible by the use of new communications and information technology, but there are important organisational factors which also influence the openness of learning.

At the most basic and fundamental level, learners in any location-metropolitan or rural-must be able to find out what courses are available. Post school learners in Australia cannot do this at present. It is, in my view, a matter of national shame that, in an era of high technology, user computer networks and communications systems criss-crossing Australia, there is no national information base which lets people know what educational courses are available. To redress this, the Committee recommends that the Department of Employment, Education and Training should urgently establish a national database of all Australian tertiary education courses. We believe that the information on the database should be widely available through the TAFE computer network and, in rural and remote areas, through Australia Post offices and agencies.

One thing was strikingly evident during the conduct of this inquiry, from many of the 109 submissions received, many of the 101 witnesses at public hearings and the numerous people to whom the Committee spoke during its inspections and visits. That is, there is a high level of interest in the development and application of new technology in education. It was also obvious that there is an immense variety in the way this interest has been manifest, and the degree to which the particular initiatives undertaken have been successful.

To the Committee, success seems to depend on setting goals and having good practical support. This is perhaps nowhere more obvious than in the case of television in education. Television is an exciting educational medium but it could hardly be termed new. It was introduced into Australia in 1956. Nonetheless, there are important initiatives which could and should be taken to improve and extend educational horizons using television.

The threshold issue to be addressed is that of the availability of educational material of good quality. Many members in this place would be familiar, and certainly their children would, for example, with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation's Playschool programs on television. What we need is more material like this-good Australian material which takes the education task seriously. We have confidence in our technicians to make such material. All they need is the incentive to do so. Broadcasters, in turn, need an incentive to buy Australian produced material. In this regard, the Committee believes that metropolitan and regional commercial television broadcasts should be required to broadcast educational programs as a condition of their licences.

As to the future, the Committee believes that if pay television were widely introduced in Australia, a specified amount of that broadcast capacity should be required to be made available free for educational purposes. Service operators should provide assistance in producing the educational programs that are broadcast. Coordination and communication are vital if we are to have both goals for the future and adequate levels of practical support to give effect to these ideas.

One of the recurrent themes in this report is the perceived need at all levels in the education sector for coordination of effort. The Committee was repeatedly told that coordination and communication were needed in order to avoid duplication of effort, recurrence of mistakes and uneconomic segmentation of services. Organisations and individuals as diverse as the Brisbane College of Advanced Education and the Victorian Department of Education made precisely this point and suggested that the Commonwealth encourage this cooperative effort. The Committee agrees that such coordination is essential from an economic as well as a functional point of view.

There are coordinating mechanisms in education, but it is clear that many practitioners in education do not think they are working. The Committee looked closely at the coordinating mechanisms and suggests improvements in their structure and operations. The Committee recommends, for instance, that the Australian Education Council (AEC) be instrumental in development, promoting, and implementing national strategies in the use of technology. The Australian Educational Council, known as the AEC, is the joint Commonwealth-State and Territory Council of Ministers of Education. The Australian Education Council should also encourage the adoption of guidelines and standards for communications and information technology. We hope that such standards and guidelines will enhance compatibility within and between educational sectors. (Extension of time granted)

Just a couple of minutes more will enable me to complete my remarks. Coordination is a particular priority in the higher education sector. The Higher Education Council of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training should use the national strategies and policies developed by the AEC and the Board should be responsible for ensuring cooperative effort between institutions. A national database of courseware and software information which would be accessible to all tertiary institutions should also be established.

I believe that it is in the school sector that the challenges of new educational technology are the most pressing and the potential gains most significant. The Committee was told, though, that the rate at which technology is taking off in schools probably exceeds schools' capacity to support it. Teachers are discovering the potential of technology and they are basically hungry for more access. The Committee saw ample evidence of such enthusiasm and this was pleasing. But there is an ongoing and very pressing need to ensure that teachers are adequately trained in new technology. The Commonwealth should allocate more funds to in-service training which deals with new technology, provided that State and non-government systems match these funds. It is also vital that schools themselves have increased opportunities for `hands on' use of computers. A large number of schools have acquired computers, often with the assistance of parent associations and the encouragement of computer companies. However, the Committee believes that the present availability of computers in schools is quite inadequate and that there is a crying need Australia-wide to remedy this situation. The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) target is for a ratio of 10 pupils per computer. Our best performance appears to be in Tasmania, with 22 students per computer. Sufficient government funds should be provided to enable schools to meet the OECD target by the beginning of the 1992 school year.

Before I conclude, I would like to thank the other members of the Committee who worked very hard on this report, and the tireless and very able Committee secretariat and the specialist adviser for the time and effort they put into the inquiry. I commend the report to honourable members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price Mr L.R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make a few brief remarks. I certainly do not anticipate requiring an extension of time. I am pleased to support this very important report of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. When we first got the reference I imagined that it would deal mostly with the problems of rural Australia. Indeed, there certainly were problems when the Committee went round rural Australia. It was a real pleasure to see organisations such as the Broken Hill School of the Air and the Darwin School of the Air. They provide an excellent service. But one has even more concern for those students that have to rely totally on correspondence education.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the important themes of this report is that technology has a capacity to assist in improving access not only in rural Australia but also in disadvantaged areas of metropolitan and provincial Australia. The other point I would like to make-the report makes it too-is that there is no point in providing technology if we do not provide training for teachers to use the technology. There is really no good substitute for the excellence of face to face teaching, but technology can go a long way in supplementing and complementing that. In some instances, of course, there is just no alternative. I certainly hope that the Government will carefully consider the report. I am sure it will be welcomed by teachers, students and caring parents. I too would like to commend the Committee and also all those members, such as the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns), the honourable member for Cowan (Mrs Jakobsen), the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby) and the honourable member for Lindsay (Mr Free), who contributed so much to the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jakobsen Ms C.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The inquiry which led to this report generated considerable discussion around Australia with interested people and organisations, as the Chairman, the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Brumby), has already said. Submissions were received from State governments, tertiary institutions, technical and further education colleges, community colleges, correspondence schools, isolated children parents associations, television and satellite service providers, as well as independent individuals, expert and otherwise. The submissions outlined the relative merits of various new and less new technologies in achieving greater access to a broader range of educational options and outcomes. They concentrated on opening more doors to education, not simply widening the existing doors.

SPEECH.PARA: Our report particularly emphasises the need for a national direction in the use of technology in learning and teaching. Furthermore, it is evident that production of Australian-designed courseware and software for schools and tertiary institutions will be encouraged by a more co-ordinated approach to curricula and result in a more consistent relevant delivery of course information to students across Australia. Accreditation transfer and recognition between States will also be greatly improved if this type of cooperation can be obtained. This report is also about the need for informed choice in technology on the basis of fulfilling specific goals. Too often, it seems, the process is reversed and technology is purchased and employed with no clear objective of output in mind. The Committee was firmly of the view that more resources are required to lift the incidence of hands-on experience with computers by children in our schools. An understanding of computer logic and the use of computers in a variety of ways for a number of tasks seems essential, given the prevailing computer culture and the likelihood of exposure to this technology in later personal and occupational life.

While not believing that computers are the answer to all education problems, the Committee considered that computer literacy among students was an essential national goal. Accordingly, the acquisition of suitable hardware and software and the enhancement of relevant skills among teachers has been recommended. The Committee consciously avoided going down the path of `gee whizzery' and recommending the use of new technology for new technology's sake. That does not mean that we were unimpressed by the displays of video-disk and satellite technology provided nor blind to the possibilities of such technologies in the longer term, and I would like to record my thanks to those witnesses for their informative presentations. It must be remembered, however, that in the Australian context there are still a number of isolated areas where relatively old technologies have not yet penetrated and where the provision of newer technologies would be completely unrealistic. It was, therefore, generally considered that the more intelligent application of a combination of computer, broadcasting, telecommunication and video-audio tape-type technology would be the most efficient and cost-effective way of improving both access and outcomes in the Australian education system in the foreseeable future. I would like to join with the Chairman and the honourable member for Chifley (Mr Price) in thanking the Committee and the Committee Secretariat for their assistance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johns Mr G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —My lasting impression of this report, An apple for the Teacher, will be this: there are many, many good ideas in new technology that apply to education and there are many Australians who are working on those ideas. All that remains is for us to pool our best ideas and then to rebroadcast those ideas so that pupils in schools, in senior colleges and in the community can use those ideas to best effect. There are a couple of areas in which I am most interested, these being in the area called narrowcast rather than broadcast.

SPEECH.PARA: I am thinking in particular of a group called TSN11 at the South Brisbane Technical and Further Education College, which has the ability to put a small group-whether it be a classroom or a bowls club or someone else from a community group-into a studio, produce a program at low cost, beam it out to a satellite and then back down to discrete points on the map throughout Queensland. In other words, it is like a classroom from one point to 20, 30 or 40 other points around Queensland. The beauty of this is the ability to use this technology to talk to a very small group of individuals who require specific information. It is unlike television and it is unlike a broadcast medium where one has to talk to a broad and general audience and therefore one's message is often general. I was impressed by the ability of that technology to put people across an enormous area of Queensland in touch with each other about specific issues or topics at relatively low cost. That is one aspect of new technology that I have learnt and experienced.

Another aspect-this was pointed out in the report-is that a great deal of software is available, that is, the programs one puts into a computer that enable kids to learn. I was recently at the Bald Hills Primary School in my electorate and some primary school children were playing with a computer. I was interested to know what game they were playing and what lessons they were learning. It was a marvellous little game about the Eureka Stockade. The questions were: `If you were Peter Lalor and were locked up here for five days, how would you cope? How would you get enough water, gunshot, food and all the rest in order to keep the coppers out?'. Alternatively, `If you were a copper, how would you get inside and knock off Peter Lalor and what sorts of resources would you require?'. The thing that thrilled me about this game is that it is very Australian. Some Australians have had the knowledge to write the program about a very important event in our history and to give it to Australian kids.

We are competing with mainly American television influences, which the kids see all the time. They pick up the language of other countries, particularly America, through watching videos and television programs. I guess we have to fight back, and one way of fighting back would be to give sufficient resources to Australians of great talent to write software about Australian events so Australian kids can learn about our history and become involved in it. The beauty of these software programs is that children can work through the problems of, for instance, what Peter Lalor faced in the Eureka Stockade, get a feel for what it was like and work out how he could possibly have kept the troops together over that time. It gives them a sense of our history. If we can do that sort of thing with new technology in education each of us will be richer and our culture will be enriched through the use of new technology.
I have learnt a great deal in working on this report. I would like to congratulate all the members, and especially the Chairman and staff, who have assisted us in writing an excellent report.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade I present the Committee's report entitled A Review of the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau and Australia's Overseas Aid Program, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade which I have just presented is the result of 15 months work by a subcommittee of the Joint Committee. The report follows a request in November 1987 by the then Foreign Minister, Bill Hayden, to review the operations of the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) and the overseas aid program generally.

SPEECH.PARA: More than 90 submissions were received in response to the public advertising of the inquiry and over 1,200 pages of written evidence. This was supplemented by nearly 600 pages of oral evidence taken during a series of public hearings held during the inquiry. Witnesses appearing before the subcommittee included representatives of a number of Government departments and agencies, non-government organisations and industry organisations as well as academics and private individuals. In addition to the formal hearings of the Committee, members undertook a number of visits, both official and unofficial, to countries which receive Australian aid. Information gathered during these visits, such as during the tour of South Pacific nations by members of the Committee's South Pacific subcommittee and by me to the Philippines and Thailand, provided useful background to this aid review. Members of the subcommittee also met with a number of representatives of international aid and development organisations. These discussions did not constitute formal evidence but assisted in the process whereby the subcommittee formulated its views as the inquiry progressed.

Reviews of our aid agency and the overseas aid program are not an uncommon phenomenon. As the report notes, between 1973 and 1983 there were at least 18 separate reviews of various aspects of the aid program. The most significant of recent reviews was the major review of both aid policy and management conducted under the chairmanship of Sir Gordon Jackson. The so-called Jackson Committee report-the report of the Committee to Review Australia's Overseas Aid Program-presented in 1984, was a watershed in the history of the aid program. It combined a comprehensive review of both aid policy and management. This Committee's predecessor in the last Parliament strongly supported the broad thrusts of Jackson's recommendations, as indeed did both the Government and the Opposition. It is with the background of the Jackson report and the changes in the effectiveness of the aid program, and the efficiency of its administration by AIDAB, that this inquiry has focused its attention.

The report is divided into four broad sections. Section one examines the background to the inquiry and the objectives of the Australian aid program. Section two looks at AIDAB's effectiveness as the national overseas aid agency in terms of the mechanics by which it manages the aid program and its accountability as required by the terms of reference. The report examines in section three the appropriateness of the present amount and distribution of the funds Australia spends on aid. In this section there are chapters on the amount of aid, the distribution of aid, equity and effectiveness issues and on benefits to Australia arising from commercial and foreign affairs aspects of the aid program. The report concludes at section four with a chapter that brings together and summarises 64 separate conclusions and recommendations arising from the Committee's inquiry. At this stage I pay tribute to the people from AIDAB for their very good cooperation in preparing the report. The Committee strongly supports the objective of the aid program as set out in paragraph 3.3 of the report:

. . . to promote the social and economic advancement of the peoples of developing countries in response to Australia's humanitarian concerns, as well as to Australia's foreign policy and commercial interests. . .

Before summarising the Committee's recommendations, or some of the important ones, may I say that, not unusually for me, I do not agree with a few of them; but I do not disagree with them sufficiently strongly to present a dissenting report. The report's recommendations proceed from the fundamental conclusion that the humanitarian motive must continue to be paramount in driving the aid program. Aid should be given to promote development. But the Committee also concludes that a concern for development effectiveness can be compatible with the pursuit of national self-interest. With careful management, foreign policy and commercial goals can be pursued without corrupting the quality of aid. In the management of the aid program the Committee makes a number of quite specific recommendations:
There must be no diminution of the autonomy of AIDAB or of the integrity of the aid program;

There should be a junior ministry of development cooperation within the Foreign Affairs and Trade portfolio but ultimate responsibility for the aid program should remain with the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade;

AIDAB must continue to exercise tight control over its staffing levels although a greater proportion of its staff may be needed in such areas as country programs, evaluations and other quality control tasks;

In terms of aid volume, the Committee has concluded that there must be rapid growth in aid as a proportion of gross national product (GNP). In real terms, between 1985-86 and 1988-89 the allocation of aid has been reduced by 19 per cent. The ratio of Australian aid to GNP in this financial year is 0.36 per cent. The Committee recommends that by 1992 Australian aid should once again stand at 0.5 per cent of GNP, but I realise that this is unlikely to happen.

Some have argued that the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank are primarily development agencies. Accordingly, the Committee recommends that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade should replace the Treasurer as Australia's Governor of both the World and Asian Development Banks. I agree that Australia's executive director and alternate director positions for both banks should be filled on the basis of expertise in development and development finance issues, but I am personally not convinced that the Treasury is not the appropriate department to represent us at these institutions, continuing, of course, its present cooperation with the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, and especially AIDAB.

It remains for me only to thank the members of the Subcommittee for their hard work throughout the inquiry, and the range of witnesses who gave evidence and the persons and organisations who tendered submissions to this important inquiry. I specifically pay tribute to Mr Peter Gibson, Secretary to the Committee; Ms Ali Gillies, Adviser to the Committee; Mr Andrew Moran, Secretary to the Subcommittee until April 1988; and Miss Therese Douch of the secretariat. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unlike the Chairman of the subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman), I intend to enthusiastically endorse all the recommendations of the Committee. I have no doubts about the correctness of the views that we adopted on the range of recommendations that are contained in the report. In the few minutes available to me, I will endeavour to give some guidance as to where interested readers might find some of the more interesting titbits of information contained in this report and, I hope, encourage them to read all of it by exciting their interest on some specific aspects.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very comprehensive review and follows a large number of reports on the aid question generally and the performance of the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) in particular. Unlike some of the earlier reports which have been fairly critical of the way in which our aid program has been administered, this Committee's report followed a major shake-up of the AIDAB organisation following the report of the Jackson Committee to Review the Australian Overseas Aid Program. We were specifically charged with looking at the way in which the organisation had responded. I think it would be fair to say that our comments are generally not adverse to the organisation. In other words, the review has brought about a number of very significant reforms which have achieved a great deal and AIDAB comes out of the matter well.

In commenting on that, I draw attention only to one matter that the Chairman addressed in particular in his comments and that is our concern that there were areas in which AIDAB evidenced certain staff shortages. Those areas are particularly important. The one about which I was concerned, which had a very limited number of staff involved, was the evaluation of the organisation's programs over the longer term. In other words, we were not effectively undertaking with a large enough number of people the task of reviewing the way in which programs had achieved their objectives in the countries where they were based. It was our view that the organisation ought to look at the way in which its staff is allocated to ensure that sufficient staff are available for that task. We even had the audacity to suggest that there may be areas for rationalisation within AIDAB as to the way in which these extra personnel may be found. One area that we identified, following an AIDAB review, related to the workings of its regional offices in the capital cities of Australia. Significant staff savings had been made there, and it seemed to us, without undertaking a full review, that there may be further savings if other alternatives, which I will address later, were undertaken by the organisation.

The second matter I want to address relates to other bodies that have not come out of this report so well. The first is the Government. The Committee comments on the level of aid. In commenting on budget matters, the report says in paragraph 6.3:
As a result, allocation to aid was slashed by 19% in real terms between 1985-86 and 1988-89 as outlined in Table 6.1 . . .

However, as table 6.1 shows, Australia's aid program bore a disproportionate amount of the burden imposed by the Government's budgetary strategy. This is a bipartisan report, and this was a level of concern felt by all members who participated in this review. I simply draw attention to the following recommendation in relation to Australia's overseas development aid:

The Committee recommends that the Government implement a policy of rapid growth in Australia's ODA as a proportion of GNP: by 1992 Australian aid should once again stand at 0.5% of GNP. However this growth must be linked to AIDAB's capacity to successfully undertake specific program initiatives of high quality.

The next matter I want to address relates to the banks, so-called-in effect, major multilateral development agencies-one being the World Bank, as we know it, and the other being the Asian Development Bank. The Chairman indicated that, for his own part, he was not necessarily convinced of the correctness of our recommendation that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade should be the Governor on both the World Bank and the Asian Development Bank. I would encourage readers to look at pages 70 and 71 of the report to see the comprehensive argument as to why our representative on these bodies, as development agencies, ought to be a person who has a commitment to the development function of those organisations. It is regrettable that the psyche of Treasury, which has a major input to these organisations, is such that the people we recruit to work in these areas are not necessarily asked whether or not they have any knowledge or understanding of how multilateral financial institutions should operate. In fact, on page 72 of the report we find some specific comments made in a submission by a Mr Abbott, a former employee of the Asian Development Bank. He said:

I should have thought that a detailed knowledge of development issues would have been essential for anyone preparing or helping prepare briefings for Australia's representatives on the ADB's board of directors and that a sound knowledge and understanding of how multilateral financial institutions operate would have been at least highly desirable.

The Committee shared Mr Abbott's surprise that these criteria were not considered essential qualifications, particularly when the Committee noted that advertisements seeking to fill positions to advise in this area said that development knowledge was not essential. That says something about Treasury's attitude to the banks.

I want to draw attention particularly to our comments in relation to the Asian Development Bank. The Committee sought Treasury cooperation in relation to that organisation and, quite frankly, I think the report understates the concern I had about the way Treasury responded to our inquiries. But the comments of the Committee in paragraph 7.53 are damning enough of Treasury's involvement in this area. Any argument that Treasury ought to have policy formulation responsibilities in this area can be seen, by the way in which the Asian Development Bank issue has been handled, as being quite inappropriate. I put that view as strongly and as passionately as I can.

Finally, I want to address two other matters that arise in the report. I am particularly interested in the way in which AIDAB works with non-government organisations. The Committee commends the way in which the organisation has done that over time. It makes this comment, which I fully support:
The demonstration of public support for NGOs should continue to be an important factor in determining the level of funding for which they are eligible.

The degree of Australian commitment to organisations ought to be the guiding influence on whether international organisations are going to be effective in the field. In other words, their ability to garner public support ought to be an important guide to government, and I am pleased that the report says that. In relation to the work in regional offices of AIDAB, I observed earlier that we were of the view that some rationalisation could occur and the corollary of that was that some of the undertakings of these regional offices could be taken up by councils for overseas students in the capitals and regional cities around Australia. I draw attention particularly to the Committee's comments on page 95, which draw attention to the way in which AIDAB should act to support and enhance the role of these organisations. The Committee makes the comment that much can be learned from the way in which in other countries, particularly the United States of America, voluntary groups are used to support students in those countries and other individuals visiting those countries. There are valuable suggestions in the report and I am sure the organisation will willingly take them up.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bilney Mr G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to rise in support of the honourable member for Prospect (Dr Klugman) and the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) to speak on the report from the subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade which has just been tabled. Perhaps I should begin by congratulating my good friend and colleague the honourable member for Prospect on his chairmanship of this inquiry which, as he pointed out in his opening remarks, took 15 months and covered a most comprehensive range of issues. As he said, there have been numerous reports on our aid programs and policies in the past, including one done by the Joint Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade Committee, which I have the pleasure of chairing. This perhaps is a narrower report than the last couple have been. It is a very workmanlike report and one which has a good deal of value in it.

SPEECH.PARA: The terms of reference have been referred to. They cover the effectiveness of the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau as Australia's overseas aid unit, changes in aid policy and management implemented as a result of the report some years ago of the Jackson Committee to Review the Australian Overseas Aid Program; and the appropriateness of the present amount and distribution of the funds Australia spends on aid. I am not planning to go through the recommendations in detail but I want to comment on several points which seem to be important. Like the honourable member for Dundas I not only urge honourable members to read the report but also hope that it will be read considerably more widely.

A very different picture emerges from this report from that which we brought down last time, in particular in respect of AIDAB. It is pretty clear that AIDAB is now a much tighter, much better organised, better staffed and better directed agency than when we last reported. This is perhaps the recommendation which Jackson made in his original report which has been most effectively implemented and which gives most promise for the future for AIDAB as an organisation.

A problem arises, however, when one contrasts that rather encouraging situation with the conclusions the Committee arrived at in its third term of reference, namely, aid volume. There has been what can only be called a catastrophic and tragic decline in the volume of aid over past years, which the report documents and refers to. Aid volume has gone down 19 per cent in real terms over the last three or four years. That has had extraordinarily bad effects on the kind of program we are able to operate. It is perfectly true that Australia has a current account problem. This is perhaps one of the major problems we face but when we compare the depth and scale of our problems with those of the recipients of our aid I am pretty sure that the conclusion we must come to is that we can do more. In that respect the last Budget was a step in the right direction-the first step of that kind for some time. The report points the way to how we can gradually but substantially expand our aid volume in future years so that we can once again have an aid program of which this country can be proud.

There are two other points I want to mention. The report is a bipartisan one. There are no dissents from it in spite of the remarks made by the Chairman of the subcommittee. I believe it will be supported on all sides. That is a good thing. In an area such as this I believe we should have bipartisan policies. The second thing which is not widely realised is that our aid program is not a matter of charity beginning at home and ending there. It helps Australians too. I have recently heard some criticism, for example, of the announcement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) during his visit to South East Asia of his gift of $30m to build a bridge over the River Kwai. I point to the section in the report which outlines the contracts which have been won with support from a very small part of our aid program, called Development Import Finance Facility (DIFF). There one sees, for example, that the firm Transfield Pty Ltd won a contract for a bridge worth $55m in Indonesia with a very small amount of support from the aid program. Later in 1986 it won a contract in Indonesia for more bridges with a value of $143m. Essentially, these contracts mean Australian jobs and Australian companies are kept in business in an area in the world where we need to be competitive.

The last thing I mention relates to the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD). There has been a public debate about the decision by the Government not to support the third replenishment of IFAD. I must admit that I was one of those who believed that if IFAD did not exist it would not have needed to be invented. The evidence brought before the Committee from the public was enough to convince it that a different course ought to be followed. That recommendation is contained in the report. I realise that time has run out for me but I wish to extend the debate so that other honourable members can participate. I move:
That so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent the consideration of Committee reports continuing until 11.10 a.m.
