SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade for this report on this very important area. Development aid is an area in which it is only too easy for cuts to be made. It needs all the support that we can possibly give it. It is important to mobilise that support out in the community, where development aid is often seen to be in competition with urgent social needs within the community. It is very important not only on humanitarian grounds but also to our long term economic and political self-interest that effective programs of development aid be undertaken by the developed, the rich countries. I think President Kennedy once said that we cannot have a peaceful world one-third rich and two-thirds hungry. In the interests of world peace and our long term economic and political benefit as well as on humanitarian grounds it is important that we support this program.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to make a few further brief comments. The Committee drew attention to the importance of raising the proportion of Australia's gross domestic product (GDP) that is spent on overseas aid. That is crucial. It is a measure of the priority that we as a country attach to this matter. The Committee mentioned that as a long term objective it could be raised to 0.5 per cent. I think there is a more immediate target to try to raise it to 0.4 per cent. I draw attention to the fact that in 1982-83, the first year that the Hawke Government came to office, that ratio was in excess of 0.5 per cent of GDP. If that ratio had been maintained-in short, if the Government had maintained the priority it attached to this area which it held at that time and if the proportion were 0.5 per cent today-the total aid would be $1.5 billion. It is actually in the order of $1 billion, that ratio having slid to about 0.36 per cent, as was mentioned in the Committee report. If the priority accorded to this area in 1982-83 had been maintained we would now be spending another $500m in this area. I am not suggesting for a moment that we can immediately go out now and spend that sort of additional money in this area, but the priority nevertheless is there. We need to attend to that.

The point I make is that it is very important in addressing this problem that we use the money we do make available in the most effective way. I believe the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau by and large is an efficient agency, but we do need to carry out closer surveillance and assessment of the results of our aid. It was encouraging earlier this week when the House, in dealing with the Bill authorising our replenishment of the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD), accepted an amendment to the effect that the Treasurer report annually in detail on the effectiveness and work of the bank with a view to this Parliament more effectively considering its allocations of funds in that direction.

I have long been an advocate of the importance in our program of encouraging more participation of non-government organisations (NGOs). It has to be recognised that, in the developing countries, there is a very large so-called `informal' or `illegal' sector. It could be, indeed, as much as 50 per cent of the population. Because it is informal, one does not know precisely what the figure is. It is very difficult for official government aid to get through. In this area non-government organisations have a very effective role. I myself am associated with an organisation involved in getting through to these people, in mobilising the energy and dignity of the millions of ordinary men and women in the nooks and crannies of the developing world, assisting in the process of giving them jobs, a chance to earn a living, and dignity and a place in the sun.

This organisation-Maranatha Trust-makes advances to the poorest of the poor who do not possess the collateral to get an advance from a bank or other such organisation. I believe it is a measure of the success of the program that as these moneys are repaid the repayment rate is in excess of 90 per cent-better than many banks achieve. The program I refer to in the Philippines, when given full effect, will be of assistance to in the order of 500,000 people in this sector. I urge that increasing attention be paid to the role of NGOs in the overseas aid program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the 1980s developing countries have gone through a depression more severe than the industrialised countries went through in the 1930s. Living standards in Africa have fallen by 25 per cent, in Latin America by 12 to 15 per cent, and in parts of southern Asia by between 10 and 20 per cent. In our region there are more people living in absolute poverty than in any other part of the world. Nearly 400 million people live in absolute poverty in South and East Asia.

SPEECH.PARA: The report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade is an attempt to outline an Australian contribution to addressing problems in those countries. There can be no doubt at all that overseas development assistance plays a very important role in reducing poverty and creating the conditions under which those countries are able to develop themselves. Australia has a fine record of aid to overseas developing countries. All our aid is in grant form; it always has been in grant form. None of our aid has been in the form of loans, as is that of most other countries to some extent. We have allowed the quantity of our grant aid to fall from about 0.5 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP) about four years ago to 0.36 per cent now, as a number of previous speakers have pointed out. That puts Australia well below the average contributions of Western countries. The unweighted average of overseas development assistance of Western countries is 0.49 per cent of their national incomes. We are well below that level.

The central recommendation of this report is that aid be increased to 0.5 per cent of GDP by 1992. That is an extremely ambitious target but it is one that is commensurate with the seriousness of the problems of poverty and malnutrition, of absolute deprivation, in much of the developing world. Such an increase is consistent with the concerns of any moderately compassionate country. Many Western countries give much more than that, as I have pointed out. If we move back to 0.5 per cent of national income by 1992, we will only then be back at the level of average aid contributions by Western countries.

The next stage of the recommendation is that it go through the Budget process. I hope that this recommendation will receive much more informed and compassionate attention than it has received in the past from the Department of Finance. In giving evidence to the Committee the Department of Finance showed complete ignorance of the extent of the depression in developing countries. The Finance official simply did not know the degree of the decline of living standards in developing countries. The Department even had the gall to say in the submission to the Committee:

A question which needs to be addressed is the extent to which the United Nations target for ODA of 0.7 per cent of the donor country's GNP remains an appropriate target for Australia. Countries such as the USA and the UK have been well below this target for some years.

In other words, the Department is quoting the two meanest countries in the West, the two countries which under the Reagan and Thatcher governments have most reduced their aid. The Department of Finance went on:
The rationale for Australia to be ahead of such countries in terms of aid effort is not evident.

When asked on what basis they made that recommendation, they had no basis at all except a simple minded comparison between those two English-speaking countries. Their ignorance was inexcusable. I hope they will read the material now available in this report, take it seriously, and be much better informed in making recommendations to their Minister about the appropriate levels of Australian aid.

The report also makes a number of other important recommendations about the way aid is delivered. One of the most important conclusions is that the Australian International Development Assistance Bureau (AIDAB) has improved the quality of its aid delivery very substantially in the last three or four years. In other words, we can have confidence that if Australia increased the quantity of its aid, such aid would be delivered in a good quality way as well. Another important recommendation is that the level of development education should be built up. It is absolutely essential that the Australian community have a sound basis for understanding what our aid is used for, the extent of the deprivation it is aimed at meeting, and how effective it is in achieving those goals. Already AIDAB's development education effort has been increased and the Bureau has improved the sophistication of that program in a number of very important ways. But development education needs more funds, and that program needs to be greatly extended.

The Committee also recommends that a Minister for development and cooperation be appointed. That would ensure that more attention was given to this very important area of government policy. A number of other important recommendations made by the Committee have already been referred to. I will not go over those except to support strongly our rejoining the International Fund for Agricultural Development and the United Nations Industrial and Development Organisation.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON ENVIRONMENT, RECREATION AND THE ARTS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 1 December, on the following report presented by Mr Milton:
Report on the use of ionising radiation.
and on the motion by Ms McHugh:
That the House take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Milton Mr P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The inquiry by the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts examined the use of ionising radiation for a wide range of industrial processes but was primarily concerned with the safety of the use of this technology for food irradiation. In addition, it examined in detailed the operations of existing radiation facilities which are used to sterilise medical equipment. The report which is now before the House is the culmination of two years of extensive investigation which resulted in 4,000 pages of oral evidence and many thousands of pages of written submissions and technical documents. Hundreds of petitions from all over Australia containing thousands of signatures were also presented to the House by individual members, indicating strong consumer resistance to irradiated food. In essence, the report concluded that the processing of food irradiation should not be permitted in Australia until such time as adequate research studies have been undertaken which can conclusively show that irradiated food is safe for human consumption and that a routine commercial method of detection of irradiated food has been developed.

SPEECH.PARA: Food irradiation is a process whereby food is bombarded by highly radioactive gamma rays in order to kill off the insects, bacteria and other micro-organisms which cause food spoilage. The process can be used as a substitution for other methods of food preservation which are considered harmful and is strongly supported by tropical fruit and vegetable exporters in the northern areas of Australia. In contrast, as previously indicated, there has been overwhelming opposition from consumers all over Australia and little interest from food retail organisations. Importantly, whilst not causing food to become radioactive at the levels which would be used, food irradiation does involve the creation of radiolytic substances which could be harmful to humans and which could also cause a loss in nutritional quality of food. It is interesting to note that while some 30 countries have approved the irradiation of at least some foods, only a minute quantity is being irradiated. This fact reflects not only consumer resistance to the process but also the difficulty in translating the results of laboratory studies to a real world commercial situation. In summary, we found the possible application of food irradiation in Australia to be extremely limited and for most, if not all, applications there are effective and more economic alternatives.

One of the concerns of the Standing Committee was that the World Health Organisation is strongly promoting the acceptance of food irradiation in collaboration with the International Atomic Energy Agency and the Food and Agriculture Organisation, despite the fact that some research studies had cast doubts on the safety of irradiated food. There was also concern that whilst the majority of scientists appeared to accept that the process was safe, some leading scientists continued to submit that the safety of the process had not yet been proven. Accordingly the Standing Committee recommended that the World Health Organisation review existing data relating to the safety of irradiated food, particularly in relation to the impact of food irradiation on nutrients and that the World Health Organisation produce a fully referenced report on the safety of food irradiation and identify those areas where further research is required.

Another of the main reasons for the conducting of food irradiation inquiries in Australia by both the Australian Consumers Association and the House of Representatives Standing Committee was the fact that, unbeknown to the Australian public, the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) had published draft regulations for the introduction of food irradiation in Australia. One of the recommendations of the Standing Committee is that the NHMRC be required in the future to introduce administrative procedures enabling fuller public consultation and participation in the development of food standards regulations.

The report, after describing the manufacturing process of ionising radiation, which has been mainly used for nearly 30 years in Australia for sterilising medical products, detailed the application of the process as applied to the prevention of food spoilage and for food preservation. Individual chapters deal with food safety, nutrition, radiological and environmental safety and food irradiation regulations. Some people may be surprised that, despite the view of the Committee that food irradiation in Australia should not be introduced at the present time, a large number of the recommendations of the Committee deal with food irradiation regulations. The terms of reference of the inquiry required that the environmental impacts and the adequacy of assessment and regulatory procedures also be part of the report. The Committee has accordingly recommended that regulations require minimum and maximum doses to be stated, that it be applied only to specific foods, and that packaging materials be stated and the products clearly labelled. The proposed regulations involve a strict monitoring of each individual food both before and after irradiation is approved, with strict penalties if regulations are broken. The Committee also recommended that radioactive isotopes not be used in mobile irradiators and that caesium 137 be prohibited for use as a general irradiation source.

Evidence received by the Committee indicated that there is no routine test to tell whether food has been irradiated or irradiated in accordance with regulations. Various public health authorities advised that because there were no routine tests, health inspectors would find it extremely difficult to enforce any regulations relating to doses, packaging and labelling. This was of great concern to the Committee. Accordingly, the Committee recommended that approval for food irradiation in Australia should not be granted until such time as a routine commercial method of detection has been developed. This is in line with other governments, including the United Kingdom Government.

During the inquiry four major areas of concern with regard to the safety of irradiated food emerged. These were: a general concern relating to the manner in which data has been assessed by scientific panels; that products may be formed in the food which may be harmful; that essential nutrients may be reduced; and the effects on micro-organisms, including the enhancements of aflatoxin growth, radiation resistant bacteria and mutations. The Committee accepted that the majority of studies undertaken suggested that the ingestion of irradiated food would cause no harmful effects. However, there are studies which indicate that irradiated food may be harmful in some instances. The Committee also noted the comments, not only by witnesses opposed to food irradiation but also by some regulatory authorities such as the United States Food and Drug Administration, which indicated that many of the earlier studies are inadequate as bases on which to make a judgment either way concerning the safety of irradiated food. In addition, the Committee notes that the International Joint Expert Committee on Food Irradiation, in its various reports, recommended that further studies be conducted. The Committee also noted the arguments of its own expert advisers that animal feed trials would be unlikely to show adverse effects because cells of all living animals have evolved mechanisms designed to protect against the radiolytic products formed in irradiated food. Indeed, one witness stated-and it is a view with which I have some sympathy-that one gets the feeling that all findings which are in favour of the safety of irradiated food are readily accepted without question, while those findings which question this stand are either rejected or viewed with suspicion, either covertly or overtly.

For the reasons indicated, it is clear that further research into the safety of food irradiation is required. The Committee had particular concern over the nutritional risks of food irradiation. In terms of the wholesomeness of irradiated food, the Committee found that some nutrients were reduced and others were changed in irradiated food but concluded that the significance of these effects could only be determined by an examination of the sources of those nutrients in the diet, and the significance of these nutrients in foods which could be irradiated. Some witnesses stated that the impact of irradiation on the nutritional value of foods for the average Australian would probably be insignificant. This view, however, was based on the assumption that only a few tropical fruits and a limited range of other products would be irradiated. This view did not take account of the fact that various international assessment bodies, including Australia's own National Health and Medical Research Council, had approved the irradiation of an extensive range of foods.

We also had difficulty with the concept of the average Australian as this concept does not take sufficient account of individual diets and `at risk' groups. The Committee was of the view that there is insufficient firm data on the practical effects of consuming irradiated food to conclude that the nutritional status of the Australian population would not be reduced. This is particularly the case of those at risk groups of Australians whose diets might be nutritionally inadequate, as stated by some expert witnesses.

In concluding my own comments on the report of the Committee, I have to say that I found the argument that there is a need to introduce food irradiation into Australia entirely unconvincing. We are fortunate in Australia in having a wide variety of fresh foods available throughout the year. Australia has a strong reputation as a provider of fresh food products for overseas markets, which could be seriously undermined if the process were introduced both internally and for export purposes. There is not a great demand for food irradiation from potential exporters and there is strong opposition to food irradiation from Australian consumers. For all the reasons indicated in the report, and because of the lack of demand for the process in Australia, I am firmly of the opinion that food irradiation should not be introduced into Australia.

I end by thanking the members of the Committee for their tolerance and understanding, which enabled the tabling of what I consider to be a most comprehensive and worthwhile report containing recommendations adopted unanimously. Thanks are also due to the Hansard reporters who produced accurate reports of what was often highly technical evidence. I would also like to place on record my appreciation of the assistance given by the Committee secretariat involved in the inquiry-namely, John Cummins, Ron Kropp and Judy Ferris. Finally, I would like to thank those of my colleagues who were not members of the Committee, namely, the honourable member for Cowan (Mrs Jakobsen), the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr John Scott) and the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright), for their initiative in bringing the issue to the attention of the Government and assisting in the inquiry. Unfortunately, I have not been given time to deal with all the matters investigated, but I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Deputy Chairman of the Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts, it gives me a great deal of pleasure and pride to commend this report entitled The use of Ionising Radiation which has been compiled by the Committee. I want, first, to recognise the contributions which made this report so valuable a document. I thank the Chairman, the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton), for his hard work, his fairness and professionalism as a chairman, and his enthusiasm for the important policy work this Parliament undertakes concerning the environment. I thank the Committee Secretary, John Cummins, his staff and our Committee's scientific advisers for their crucial contribution by way of advice and the man-hours which have gone into the hearings, analysis and drafting connected with this report.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank the hundreds of submission writers and witnesses for both the quality of the evidence and the genuine spirit and sincerity which pervaded our consultation work. Honourable members will note that we received hundreds of submissions and witnesses and took over 4,000 pages of transcript. As the Chairman said, this was a mammoth task for the Hansard reporters. This was a thorough and fair exercise in consultation and analysis. There can be no doubt that this Committee and the staff and processes which undergird it are a fine example of how important the Committee system is, and can be, to the decision-making process of this Parliament.

I now turn to the report. I do not hesitate to identify with this report and its recommendations. It embodies the prudence of political conservatism and the desire of liberalism to maximise informed choice and freedom, which are the foundational political and social philosophies of my Party, the Liberal Party of Australia. It reflects, again referring to these traditions, the commitment of the Liberal Party to government based on the concurrence of the people. Conservatives believe that technological, social and political change should proceed in tandem with and not against the concern and thinking of the community. Liberalism is based on the central principle of the right of each citizen to participate in the decision making of the community. These fundamental philosophies and principles-prudence, informed freedom of choice, and concurrence between government and community-are evident in the report's recommendations.

In brief, the Committee wants to see further collection of data and further research, nationally and internationally, concerning the irradiation process. It wants the further development of safety and standards regulation, and further development of practical commercial methods of irradiated food identification and detection. Most importantly, it wants further consultation within and across the community.

The Committee has recommended, in fact, that the use of irradiation for foodstuffs not be approved until these prudent criteria, and these processes designed to ensure adequate information and choice for consumers, are thoroughly met. The report indicates that the vast majority of evidence and scientific opinion supports the claim by proponents of irradiation that it is a safe and efficient form of sterilisation and preservation. The Committee also notes, however, that doubts still remain for some eminent scientists.

The report notes that much of the information available to the public is inadequate and that, therefore, much public concern about food irradiation is unjustified. It also noted that concerns about irradiation plants and facilities have thus far been totally unjustified. I recall in passing the experience of Committee members at one plant in particular. We witnessed the sterilisation by ionising radiation of medical supplies at levels far above what would be approved for foodstuffs, within 30 seconds or so we handled the supplies and tested them for radiation levels. There was no registration of radiation at all. We then tested the luminous face of one Committee member's watch and the geigercounter made an immediate registration of radiation.

I make the point that, on the whole, the community is not aware of the ever-present, normal levels of radiation and is not aware of how exaggerated claims about radiation can be. The Committee, nevertheless, believes that, politically, policy development must proceed no faster than public awareness and public opinion in this area. The Committee notes that there are other forms of food sterilisation and preservation. I refer to chemical substances and the use of systemic poisons, which would not meet the standards in place and suggested by the Committee for food irradiation. That there is an inadequate framework for assessing and controlling those forms of sterilisation does not justify approval for an expansion of that inadequate framework. The Committee, therefore, argues that the burden of proof rests with those who would wish to introduce the process to allay doubts and to provide an adequate system of safety, regulation and information to the community.

Unlike the vexed questions of mining, logging and urban development, there is no economic or balance of payments pressure to take into consideration on this environmental question. The Committee notes that there is little demand or need either by producers or by consumers for irradiated foodstuffs. Indeed, there may be a strategic, market oriented case for ensuring that Australian foodstuffs are seen by the international markets to be radiation free.

That last point is the good news. There are inadequacies to be met concerning the regulation and consumer information framework. The Committee has been advised that there are still serious doubts amongst the majority of Australian citizens concerning food irradiation. Given that there is no compelling or urgent national economic interest in approving the process, I would suggest that the Committee's recommendations are more than reasonable and appropriate. I would go further: I would be deeply concerned if they were to be ignored or rejected. In that situation I would have to consider whether there was some imbalance in the influence which had been brought to bear on the decision making process.

I commend the report to the House. I finish by noting that there was considerable interest in this report in my own electorate. In particular, strong and well reasoned views were put to me by the Campaign to Ban Food Irradiation through that group's coordinator, Mrs Mountwinter. I thank her and her group for that interest and involvement and commend the report to them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chynoweth Mr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I start by thanking all the other members of the Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts. We spent many hours together. We went to many rooms and places all over Australia and we heard many strange tales. However, we sat through them all. I thank them all. It was a pleasure to be part of the preparation of this most important report. I take this opportunity to thank the Committee Secretary, John Cummins, and the staff. John is sitting in the chamber at the moment. His hair has gone grey in the last few months. I do not think the reason was exposure to gamma radiation; I think it was the pressure of producing this report. It was really hard and he did a good job. I thank Hansard and all the witnesses. I would like to thank one witness in particular-George West, the General Manager of Steritech Pty Ltd, which is an organisation that has a radiation plant in Australia. Even though I did not agree with everything he said, he answered all the questions. Throughout the whole of the hearings and our deliberations, he took quite a battering. I give special thanks to him.

SPEECH.PARA: I am a bit surprised that my office has not had one request for the report since it was released. Hundreds of people wrote to us, but I am still waiting for a request for a copy. However, we have probably not had a request because of the findings of the report. This also underlines my impression that there was no real need to introduce food irradiation: there was no general call and no real necessity for it. This issue was raised because of the fear that it might be brought in. That is good. We should look at these problems before they happen. The Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) kicked it off, but I thank whoever raised the concern initially.

During the deliberations I tried to be fair and not allow my prejudices and biases to colour my views on the subject. However, they did. In some of my questioning during the inquiry I did ask what would happen to the famous apple if it was irradiated; what would happen to the atoms, et cetera. I felt that this was important. I really cannot feel comfortable with a process that changes the atomic structure of our food by irradiation. I have spoken to many people about the subject and if I have had an irradiated apple and a fresh apple and asked them, `Which one would you eat?', everyone has gone for the fresh apple. There possibly could be in future some need for it-I do not know what the need would be-but somewhere down the track maybe it could be looked at again. The decisions that the Committee has made, which have come out in this report, will be a guideline for many other people looking at food irradiation in the future.

We must keep an eye on food that comes in from overseas. If we have in a way banned irradiated food in Australia, whatever food we import we must check, to see that it has not been irradiated. As honourable members know from this report, there is no way of knowing whether food has been irradiated or not. I think it is up to people throughout the community, if they see on the back of a package, in small print, a notice that `this food has been irradiated', they should let us know and we can do something about it. At the moment we have enough chemicals and fertilisers and other things in our food that we do not know anything about. If we added irradiation to our food processes, who knows what it would cause. We do not really know enough about it.

We had scientists come to the Committee with many submissions and I just could not understand them. I am no scientist. I am a turner and fitter. I am the same as anyone else in the community. I am just an average person. We had advisers advising us on these things and they were trying to get it down to a simple language, but it was very hard for them to do that. We saw quite a bit of political in-fighting within the scientific community, which was interesting. I thought it only went on up here in Canberra, but it is alive and well within scientific communities. I suppose that is good. Food irradiation is a process that I personally think we do not need yet. It is a process that we should keep an eye on to make sure that in the future any food coming in from overseas is watched closely. I again thank the Committee. I thank the Chairman and I especially thank the members of the secretariat.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the subject of food irradiation has produced more nonsense and more alarmism than just about anything that I can think of. Some of the submissions to the Committee would have us believe that if a food were irradiated it would glow in the dark and persons who ate it would glow in the dark. Unfortunately, some of the impressions being given today are that irradiated food in some way has been demonstrated to be a very dangerous thing. All the evidence that was provable that came before the Committee was very strongly of the view that food irradiation as presently carried out was safe. I do not think anybody should lose sight of that.

SPEECH.PARA: I think some of the alarmism that has been generated in the community is quite irresponsible. In saying that I do not say for a moment that food irradiation is in any way the answer to all the problems of preservation of food. It is certainly not, but I do believe that it has some applications at present and may have more applications in the future. There is no great impetus at the moment for it to be introduced into Australia. I understand that and I support it. But to suggest that somehow this mysterious process is inimical in a greater degree than other food preservation processes is really irresponsible and should not be allowed to continue without challenge.

In fact, food irradiation is one of the most widely researched areas, if not the most widely researched area, of food preservation that there has been. It was discovered in 1908. The concept of irradiating food was patented in 1930. In 1963 the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) of the United States of America gave approval for the treatment of bacon and the decontamination of vegetable seasoning. Over 30 countries have now approved the use of food irradiation, although on a highly selective basis, and so it goes on. In Australia there have been a number of investigations, going back to 1962. So it is a very widely investigated procedure and to suggest somehow that there is still a major area of concern really is not in accord with the facts.

Some of the scientific evidence that came before the Committee was demonstrably nonsense and some of the so-called scientific evidence upon which the opposition to food irradiation was based was blown out of the water by expert advice to the Committee. The facts of the matter are that the standing committee found that there were very widely held misconceptions about food irradiation, about the irradiation process, about the foods it would apply to, about the levels of irradiation to be applied to those foods, about its effect on human health and about environmental impact considerations. Food irradiation of course does have a major consumer acceptance problem. It has also become a politically sensitive issue because somehow people try to tie it in with the debate about nuclear energy, as though there was any real association between food irradiation and the use of nuclear energy in a broader sense.

For these reasons the introduction of food irradiation has met considerable resistance and will continue to do so because there will be some elements within the community which, in whipping up the anti-nuclear debate, will use the subject of food irradiation to bolster their case. This is despite support for the process as a safe process by the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC), by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) and by the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO); despite the fact that comprehensive scrutiny for over 30 years by respected international scientific bodies has suggested that the process as carried out is safe; despite the fact, as I have said, that there is approval for use with specific foods under controlled conditions by over 30 countries; and despite the fact that there is total rejection by expert scientific bodies of all the totally alarmist claims.

The Committee found that the majority of scientific evidence presented to the inquiry indicated that food irradiation was safe. Certainly, no scientist is going to say to anybody that he can guarantee 100 per cent that such and such a thing is going to happen. No scientist of proper repute would do so, and because he will not, because he should not, some people suggest that because there is this infinitesimal amount of concern or of lack of certainty, the whole process must be scrutinised again and again and again. The Committee also accepted that most studies showed that irradiated food would cause no harmful effects, but of course, as we have heard, the Committee expressed concern that some studies did indicate possible harmful effects in some circumstances and that some of the earlier scientific studies had been inadequate. We have heard all the submissions to the Committee about free radicals and these sorts of materials in food. People just do not understand that a lot of these substances are produced by the normal cooking processes.

I really do think it is time-and I am glad that the Committee did it-that we looked at all this material. Hopefully, people will read the Committee's recommendations and the report very carefully indeed, because there is a lot of rejection of some of the most alarmist statements that are continually being made. It is quite proper that consumers should know whether or not food or a component of food has been irradiated. I totally support that. Until there is a sound commercial way in which foods can be tested to show whether they have been irradiated, in my view there is no case for the introduction of irradiated food in Australia. But I would hope that the commercial discovery of a way in which food can be quickly delineated as to whether it has been irradiated will be found, because the process may be a very useful one in the future.

I believe that some of the other means of food preservation and the destruction of insects in grains, spices, fruits and vegetables, which are currently in use, could be far more harmful to human health than would be properly controlled irradiation. I am not suggesting for a moment that all food can be preserved by irradiation. It obviously cannot. But there are some foods which lend themselves particularly to irradiation treatment, and I believe it could be very useful for them so to be treated. But I make the proviso that until there is a readily available, commercially useful way of checking whether food or a component of food has been irradiated, then it should not be introduced in Australia. But for goodness sake, let none of us go around promulgating this alarmist nonsense about the supposed ill-effects of irradiated food as though we are going to glow in the dark if we eat some of this stuff. That is nonsense and it should be put completely behind us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want first to thank the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts for the work it has carried out on this inquiry. Reference has been made to the fact that the inquiry held a large number of public hearings, taking evidence running to over 4,000 pages. During those hearings the Committee was shadowed by some dark operatives from the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO), the former Australian Atomic Energy Commission. Their interest in the question of food irradiation I found somewhat fascinating. I was glad I, likewise, had the opportunity to travel with the Committee to hear what evidence was being given. I still remain fascinated by the involvement of ANSTO. Over the 2 1/2 years of my interest in this subject I have found that ANSTO has been more interested in food irradiation than anyone else in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue was first revealed in a public sense on 14 April 1986, when the Australian revealed the existence of a draft model of the regulations that had been prepared by the National Health and Medical Research Council subcommittee, which was called the Food Standards Committee. Prior to that public release I became involved in a rather strange way. I am glad to say that in public life there are public servants with a conscience about things that are going on. I was lucky in that in the old Parliament House a document was given to me and it was suggested that I have a close look at it because it was thought to be rather sinister. I was fortunate in having heard some preliminary information on food irradiation when I was in Washington the previous year, so I was not totally in the dark on the subject. Nevertheless, I followed the matter up as well as the work of the Food Standards Committee.

Through various questions to Ministers-I think some 200-through demands for documents, letters, records and so on we found out a great deal about what was going on. What is really at the heart of the concern of the Australian community is that this was carried out in secret. It was something that was to be imposed on the consuming public. I have no doubts that this was the case. I think it was exemplified by the work of a subcommittee of the Food Standards Committee, a working party the composition of which was rather loaded, shall we say. I was lucky enough to get hold of some of the minutes, which revealed that that working party had determined to prepare one million leaflets for distribution throughout Australia along with 30,000 booklets, and that it was going to do this `as a matter of urgency'. They are not my words, but the words of the working party. It said that it would conduct the work `as a matter of urgency'. That is quite sinister. There is nothing urgent about the matter. The way it went about its work suggests that it was trying to cover up something or impose it on the public before the public could wake up to it. The minutes of the working party also said that it could not address the question of cost because this was a complex subject that could not be answered simply. Later on I will mention something about the costs of food irradiation, which would have to be borne by the consuming public.

I am glad I was actively involved in alerting the public conscience to what was going on. I would like to take this opportunity to quote a statement that I think is very relevant. It would do all members of Parliament and legislators a lot of good to keep this in mind, because we might all learn from it. It reads:
We live in a community becoming more and more nutrition conscious, diet conscious and consumer conscious.

People today are interested not just in whether something tastes good-or whether the children will eat it: they are interested in whether it is good for them; they are interested in what it has in it.
That statement comes from a Commonwealth Department of Health publication and I think it says a great deal about today's consumers.

Mention has been made of the many petitions on this matter which come to most members on both sides of this House. I have reason to believe that the issue has attracted the second highest number of signatures on petitions in recent years. I want to raise a grievance about petitions which I have raised in this House before. I believe very strongly in the system of petitions, which allows the public to express its views in this House. I am very disappointed and, in fact, very angry at the bureaucratic imposition which limits the number of petitions that can be submitted to this House. We receive thousands and thousands of signatures from petitioners but because some petitions are not worded in the correct manner they are not allowed to be presented in this House. I give warning that I will continue to fight-I am sure members on both sides agree with me-to change this stupid bureaucratic decision. I hope the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Procedure will take on board the complaints that I am making and that many others have made. I think it is nothing but bumptious nonsense that the voice of the people cannot be recorded properly in this House because one or two words happen to be out of place.

During the campaign to try to impose food irradiation on the consuming public I came across a publication, which would probably never have seen the light of day here if the Committee had not undertaken its inquiry, from the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) in Vienna called the Food Irradiation Newsletter. We now make sure that we get each issue of this publication as it comes out. I refer particularly to two items in that publication. The first is called the `Marketing Plan'. This document, as I said, was prepared by the IAEA under a group called the International Consultative Group on Food Irradiation. We managed to get hold of a copy of this 28-page document, which is quite sinister and which shows the international implications of food irradiation and the push that is on to impose it on the public. An article in this document, entitled `Marketing and Communication Guidelines for Acceptance and Usage of Food Irradiation', is very revealing. Its objects are quite clear, and they are to:
Achieve the approval, acceptance and usage of food irradiation on a worldwide basis.

The document goes on to talk about how to set up seeding groups, how to influence governments, how to influence decision makers and how to influence trade unions in the food industry. I am quite sure that it caused the IAEA a great deal of embarrassment when we got hold of this document. Its authenticity has been verified. We have raised the matter in the House and finally received documents from the Australian Atomic Energy Commission, now known as ANSTO, which revealed that Australia had been involved in this consultative group. I am glad to say that the Government is taking a new line on that issue. Its enthusiasm for the work of the IAEA on food irradiation is on the wane, and so it should be.

I want to refer to the April 1988 edition of the Food Irradiation Newsletter. On page 54 there is a fairly long article dealing with the International Finance Corporation, which is a branch of the World Bank. The article explains that the International Finance Corporation is interested in setting up food irradiation plants in developing countries. It gives in fairly great detail the costs of such a venture, and what kind of capital is being sought by way of a sponsorship arrangement. It also gives figures for costs of and profits from food irradiation. It is interesting that, once the plant has been set up and is fully operational commercially, and assuming an effective utilisation of 7,500 operating hours per year, the average processing cost of food can range from $1 to $3 per pound. That is interesting and revealing. It is the first time that any assertion about the cost of food irradiation has been put publicly.

The most important reason for raising this point is that the International Finance Corporation has been under pressure from organisations in Washington which are opposed to food irradiation and which knew of the Corporation's sponsorship of and support for the process. This matter was taken up with the International Finance Corporation. On 4 August 1988, that organisation, in response to the complaints it had received, sent a letter to the joint Food and Agriculture Organisation-IAEA division of the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna. The letter is very revealing. It reads:
The purpose of this letter is to correct and clarify the position of IFC that appeared in your April 1988 Newsletter with regard to IFC's possible involvement with food irradiation projects.
The statement that IFC is ``in principle ready to finance installations of food irradiation facilities in developing countries'' reflects IFC's position as of late 1986.

Since then, IFC has been carefully examining several proposals. As a result of this examination, we have concluded that the issues related to environment, consumer acceptance, and operating safety of food irradiation projects are so complex that it is unlikely that such projects in developing countries will meet our stringent standards. For these reasons as well as business considerations, we are not actively promoting this type of project.
We would appreciate your publishing in your next available issue of the newsletter this clarification so as to provide to your readers IFC's current position.

The letter is signed by the Manager of the Technology and Development Unit of the International Finance Corporation. It is one of the most startling and revealing documents that has surfaced during this debate on food irradiation. Clearly, part of the World Bank has realised that the community does not want food irradiation and does not see the need for it, and it now wishes to get out from under.

Many issues could be raised on this question. Honourable members who have spoken have touched on a range of them, one of them being the question of the loss of nutritional value of food in the irradiation process. That is quite alarming. The Committee has done a marvellous job in this regard. Its public relations exercise in allowing the community to express its views has been excellent. However, the Committee has been operating somewhat in the dark in that it had no evidence as to the loss of nutritional value. I am glad to say that a move has been made to allow the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories (AGAL) to conduct such tests. A small allocation of money for that purpose has been made available. I understand that ANSTO, through its greed and its rapacious attempts to grab that money, is ripping off the total amount that was allocated to AGAL. It is likely that the report on nutritional value will be less than satisfactory. It is a matter that must be pursued.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that this report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts entitled Use of Ionising Radiation is significant. I believe that it reinforces the role and importance of parliamentary committees. I also congratulate all other members of the Committee. I believe that this report will have a great impact, as have numerous other reports of the Standing Committee. The Committee's terms of reference were, basically, to look at the human health and safety aspects of ionising radiation, particularly its impact on food, the environmental impact and, of course, the adequacy of assessment and regulatory processes. I believe this report is one of integrity. I believe it dispels all the emotion surrounding this subject and refers rationally to technical and scientific evidence. I thank the staff of the Committee, some of whom are present in the gallery today-Mr Cummins, Mr Kropp and Mrs Ferris. I congratulate our advisers-Dr Hall, Dr MacPhee and Mr Robotham. They have given us expert and balanced advice and put in considerable effort to make sure that this report was as technically viable and feasible as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: There was tremendous interest in this subject. On the one hand, individuals and organisations were naturally concerned about any process that interfered in any way with food. I believe that many of their concerns were not legitimate, and this report signifies that point. On the other hand, a number of regulatory authorities, scientific organisations including the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, and other commercial associations, gave evidence-particularly with regard to the horticultural industry, about which I am concerned-that food irradiation was a safe process and could have significant advantages for the industry and the consumer.

While food irradiation is not used extensively worldwide, 30 countries have given approval for the irradiation of some food products. I had the opportunity during this inquiry to visit China and to speak with a number of people who were involved at both a scientific level and a practical level in the process of food irradiation. It does have potential for both domestic and export use in preservation and quarantine purposes in many countries. For instance, in China, one-third of all food produced is spoiled. There is limited transport potential to distribute food throughout that country, and only 2 to 3 per cent of the population have refrigeration available. It is natural that this process, which has enormous potential for preservation of food, has gained widespread experimentation and usage in that country.

We express a number of concerns in this report. I will not mention those to any great extent because my colleagues have done so. For the information of those people who are listening to the broadcast of this debate, or those who read reports of this debate, I would like to refer to some of the widespread applications that already exist in this country for ionising radiation. There is a wide range of applications. Of course, the medical application is the most significant. This includes the use of X-ray and injected radioisotopes to produce images of bones and organs, and the therapy machines used to control cancer. There are a number of industrial applications, particularly in thickness gauges used for radiographing welds and pipes. This has been used with enormous success and, in many instances, is unique to Australia. Other major uses of ionising radiation are for sterilisation, preservation and disinfestation. The sterilisation of medical and surgical products by the application of ionising radiation is the largest use of this process currently. It has a number of advantages over the other forms of treatment. It permits the sterilisation of heat sensitive drugs. It is used with low melting point plastic articles. It is used extensively in biological preparations.

Food can be preserved under this process at a much lower dose level than is required for the sterilisation of other products. Irradiation is used mainly to prevent food spoilage by micro-organisms and insects between harvest and eating. Irradiation is important in the disinfestation and conservation of produce and in increasing market value, and helps in compliance with quarantine restrictions.

I briefly refer to the positive effects of treating food with ionising radiation. There would be an inactivisation of micro-organisms which may contaminate food and cause spoilage. Food-borne pathogenic micro-organisms would be inactivated. Ionisation can delay ripening and inhibit sprouting. This technique is used in many countries, particularly China and Japan, to ensure that the supply of potatoes and onions through the winter is maintained. It can be used for the decontamination of disinfestation of food to combat bacterial yeasts, moulds and insects. I understand that almost all wheat that is imported into the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics has been irradiated. So the method is widely used. In compiling this report the Committee has ensured that a balance has been brought to all these arguments. The Committee has determined that, while there is no great demand in Australia for the use of ionising radiation in its application to food, it has a potential for preservation and quarantine purposes.

We do, of course, express a number of concerns, which relate primarily to the safety of the process and to the transportation of any nuclear material that is used in that process. We have discovered a major deficiency in data collection and availability. This particularly relates to the impact on the nutritional value of food. We have a number of doubts about the levels of experimentation and integrity of experiments that have taken place in Australia and throughout the world. We have specifically recommended against the use of caesium 137 in the process. My major concern-and this concern was expressed by the honourable member for Warringah (Mr MacKellar)-is that this process should not commence until a cheap and routine method of detection and measurement of radiation has been developed. This report strongly recommends that if irradiation is to be introduced in this country, we should have very stringent and effective labelling and packaging techniques.

This report does not recommend against the irradiation process. It may have widespread significance in the future, particularly as a quarantine measure, and it could provide this nation with the capacity to overcome the tyranny of distance to world markets. This process would allow the extension of the shelf life of a number of products and would be a significant boost to our export potential. I remind the House that this method is already used by a number of our overseas competitors, particularly to tap into the European market.

I refer to one comment made by the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr John Scott) about the cost that may be incurred as a result of the irradiation process. Of course there is a cost involved. The Chinese people recognise that in the use of irradiation in their country. But it has the potential to carry products through periods of shortage when supplies would otherwise not be available. Therefore, it can be a hedge in some countries against food shortage. The process would not be used if a commercial decision determined that a product would not improve its attractiveness or that there would be consumer resistance to it.

This has been a very long and time consuming inquiry. The report has enormous integrity and it is a great base for the future discussion of this process, which is important for medicine and has potential in agriculture, particularly in relation to exports. I recommend the report to the community for reading. I believe that it has dispelled for all time the fear that the use of products from the nuclear industry in the process has the potential to damage or cause harm to people. As with other processes involved in the preservation of food, whether it be cooking, refrigeration or deep freezing, we need to know a lot more about the impact on the nutrients and the quality of the product that is treated.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I want to make one brief comment which relates to the comments made by my friend and colleague the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mr John Scott). He referred to the problems which the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories might have with regard to costs in its work on the possible loss of nutritional values of irradiated food. I refer to paragraph 6.15 of our report, which states that the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts had been informally advised that the Government had provided funds to enable such an examination to be undertaken by the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories. One would hope in those circumstances that the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation (ANSTO) would not charge heavily-if at all. I hope that the item that was mentioned by my colleague was inaccurate and that we will find that the money that is made available, by the Government or through very small charges by ANSTO, will enable this very important study to be undertaken by the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories into the possible loss of nutritional values of irradiated food.
—Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting Thursday.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Sudan-Alzheimer's Disease-Petrol Prices-Pollution of Sydney's Beaches-Bush Nursing Hospitals-Hawke Government-Economy-Queensland: Voluntary Employment Agreements-Quangos-Prime Minister-Woodridge High School-New South Wales Land

PROCTEXT.PARA: Question proposed:
That grievances be noted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I might liven the place up a bit. I do not know whether I will talk about apples; I do not know whether I will talk about petrol. I do not know what I will talk about, but I will talk about something.
—Talk about Dr Bob Brown.

—I will give him a bit of a serve later on in the session. I have been trying to ask the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) a question in the House for some time now. The question I want to ask does not pertain to Tasmania. That will probably surprise everybody. Maybe I need a packet of Aspros to distribute to wake everybody up again. Recently I went on a trip to the front line states. The trip has become very famous because of certain reports that have been made on it. The Prime Minister would be aware that aid should be directed to the most needy and that we must always make certain that the aid goes to the most needy. During that trip to Ethiopia my colleagues and I came across a refugee camp. We were astounded to find that the number of people in that refugee camp equalled about half the population of Tasmania-about 200,000-and that they were Sudanese. It has left a very indelible mark on my brain. What I saw there horrified me. We read articles and see pictures of things occurring throughout the world and we take it with a grain of salt for a while because it does not really affect us or our family. When we see it at first hand we start to realise that this world is a very miserable one. There were 200,000 people in that refugee camp. It was horrific.

SPEECH.PARA: We saw very tall, gaunt and proud people brought down to the lowest common denominator. They were so thin and frail and most of them had been just living there for about three years. I will not go into the reasons why but it is mainly because of civil war. It is because of the inability of the people in Sudan to get on. In fact, they had to flee across the border into Ethiopia from the army that was attacking them. But because of Ethiopia's problems of drought and civil war there were problems there also. The problem was exacerbated by these 200,000 people arriving. I thought to myself, `God, what is going to happen to them?'. Sometimes we begrudge giving aid. We think to ourselves, `Is it going to the right people?'. But if one proportion goes there and saves or helps somebody then it is reaching the right person. I have been trying for a couple of months to ask a question but it is difficult being a mere backbencher.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are a compassionate man.
—I am a compassionate man but it is still difficult to ask a question. On 8 March I read an article headed `Warning on Sudan Famine'. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Starvation in Sudan was so severe it might dwarf the misery of Ethiopia's 1984 famine. The Executive Director of Oxfam, America, a very ethical and well organised organisation said yesterday, `A million people had died since 1983 in a famine created by a civil war in which both sides had prevented food from reaching starving people'.

In fact, we have had a civil war and in between we had these starving people. Of course, it has reached the astronomical number of a million people. It has been mentioned that genocide is occurring in Sudan. It has been mentioned that some of the scenes there are absolutely horrific. I suppose it is difficult for us to send a delegation to Sudan or Ethiopia once again. A fact finding mission is fine but we do not have very much time. I think it would be extremely beneficial for us if we were able to send an organised group there just to determine what the problems are and what can be done to help them and to make absolutely certain that the aid that we give is appreciated. People in Australia are very compassionate; they like to give to a very good cause. If they knew the circumstances first hand-if they knew that people from Australia had been there to determine the extent of the situation-I am sure that they would give and give freely. We need to know. There are a lot of mixed up situations in Ethiopia. It has a terrible civil war. Sometimes we wonder and put a question mark in our minds about the army in Ethiopia, which is larger than the army in Australia. There have been very contentious debates about where the aid is going. I for one would like to be absolutely certain that the aid goes to the right people, in particular to those who really need it.

I will move to another compassionate matter for a few minutes. It is something that worries me particularly. We are opening a tennis court at Parliament House today. That is fine. A lot of people might not realise it but I was a sportsman once upon a time until I got old and decrepit. Now I am just a great politician. I love sports and love to see openings of tennis courts and sporting facilities in Australia but sometimes I think that far too much emphasis is being placed on sporting facilities and not enough emphasis on some of the homes that are urgently required for the elderly of Australia. I talk in particular about Alzheimer's disease. I will refer to Tasmania because I know what goes on in that State better than anywhere else. In Hobart at the moment we have people selling buttons on street corners. They are elderly people. Some of them are wives of men who have Alzheimer's disease and they are trying to put a bit back into the community by helping. They are trying to get facilities to help their husbands or wives who might have the disease. I think there is not enough emphasis or assistance given by governments. I am not being critical of this Federal Government. It is also the State governments and local authorities which are to blame. Not enough help and assistance is going into helping these particular people.

Regrettably, we could all be confronted with the disease. It does not just affect people aged 75 or 80. It is touching people of 50, 55 and 60 years of age. It is an unknown disease that some have said is even larger and bigger than the acquired immune deficiency syndrome epidemic in this country at the moment but it is not as contentious or controversial an issue in the press. It is taken for granted that a person can be struck down with it and all of a sudden placed in an institution and forgotten about. I firmly believe that we need to do more about it. I know my good friends here, and those sitting opposite too, would agree with me. It is great going to the opening of a sporting facility and having a plaque put up with the words `Opened by Bruce Goodluck in 1989' but I would like to go far better and open a home for people with Alzheimer's disease with my name on it where people are going to be looked after. I would feel far prouder and it would be far better for me than going to the opening of a sporting facility.

I am not going to the opening of the tennis court here today. That is not being critical. Somebody said to me that this is an expensive place. I think I made a quip off the top of my head and said that it is only worth one and a half submarines or something like that. We will always be the centre of controversy up here. People will say that we are wasting money. I do not want to exacerbate that by using the tennis courts as an example. I heard over the air that it is being opened and I thought to myself, great, it is good for us and it is good for the people who come here. It would be far better if that money was being directed elsewhere. That is just an example; I am not being critical.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Whip won't agree with you.

—No, probably not, but very few people do. I turn now to the people of Canberra and the petrol situation. Last week I came to work and got the shock of my life. The poor people of Canberra, I thought. They have been paying 52.8c a litre for petrol and it could have been higher. I think it was 58c a litre. I can tell by the eyes of the Canberra people at the table. They sort of glared at me and I knew I was wrong. It was about 58c a litre. In the Canberra Times-I have no reason to refute the Canberra Times-an article appeared headed, `The benefits of shopping around: about $7.50 a week'. On the day I saw that article, last Thursday, the price of petrol was reported to have dropped from 58c a litre to a low of 42.9c a litre. The article said:

SPEECH.PARA: The evidence of the advantage to Canberra motorists has been made clear over the past two months with prices fluctuating wildly between a high of about 59c a litre and a low of 42.9c a litre . . .
Oil-industry executives confirmed the phenomenon yesterday and attributed it to the changes introduced by companies such as Shell Australia Ltd, Mobil Oil Australia Ltd and Ampol Petroleum Ltd.
Those changes mean that discounting is no longer being confined to the Sydney metropolitan area but is being spread to country areas of New South Wales, albeit to a lesser degree.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Tasmania?
—It does not refer to Tasmania but I will come to that. What occurred on this particular day and a Shell executive confirmed it- -
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McHugh Ms J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am going to take advantage of the grievance debate to raise in the national Parliament the plight of some of our greatest national assets-Sydney's beaches. It is about time, in my view, that we in the Federal sphere of government became involved in what is a national disgrace-the pollution of our national pride, Sydney's beaches. Everywhere I go as the member for Phillip I identify myself and my electorate with Bondi. Over the years I have got angry and defensive when the name Bondi has triggered the response `sewage' and people have put their fingers to their nose. I have jumped to the defence of the beach I love and the beaches in my electorate that I love. I have been right to defend Bondi. For a start it is almost always cleaner than many of the other beaches. During this season's carnivals in January and February it looked absolutely marvellous and was covered with people swimming and having a great time. But now I am angry and I am ashamed. It is obvious that there is a serious problem of pollution and all our beaches are under threat, even Bondi.

SPEECH.PARA: For years we have been conned. We have been conned by the Metropolitan Water, Sewerage and Drainage Board, conned by the State Pollution Control Commission, conned by the experts. Even the politicians have been conned. Jack Ferguson, a former Minister and Deputy Premier in the Wran Government, said that he was given the same rosy picture as the public. The public, of course, was not told the facts. Even the current Minister, Mr Tim Moore, appears to have had a great deal of trouble squeezing results from the Water Board.
As the Sydney Morning Herald revealed in articles this week:

A cosy relationship between the Sydney Water Board and the State Pollution Control Commission has been instrumental in making the city's beaches unfit for swimming and contaminating the marine food chain.
Herald investigations into the environmental scandal of the beaches leave the two bureaucracies, either singly or in concert, accused of having:
fixed pollution standards at levels which the SPCC knew to be unjustifiable but which suited the Board;
consistently understated the health risks of swimming at our beaches and used measurement criteria which both knew to be hopelessly inadequate;
secretly dumped thousands of tonnes of highly-toxic sewage sludge into Sydney's waters despite warnings of abnormalities in marine life;
tried to shift the blame for what has happened on to the public.

Throughout the shambles, the two organisations have condemned all opposition. They have kept from the public not only internal reports which seriously questioned their policies but also alarming scientific research.
Throughout that time they have been spending a fortune on glossy advertisements in magazines and newspapers, assuring us that everything is all right.

I have been involved with many experts in the great environmental issues over the years. I always quote the record of the asbestos companies when experts are mentioned. As part of the fight on environmental issues throughout Australia, we have had to get the facts. We have fought to save the Franklin in South-West Tasmania; to save the rainforests in New South Wales and Queensland; to save Kakadu in the Northern Territory; to try to save the Great Barrier Reef from overdevelopment, although I do not think we are really succeeding. And we have fought to save Bondi and Coogee from high rise development.

As a member of Save Our Bondi when we were fighting against the proposed developments, I always claimed that Bondi belonged to everyone, that we local citizens had to save and protect Bondi because we had a duty of care to all Australians. We won that fight. We saved Bondi from the developers, and the new council is getting along with some excellent programs. Now I am asking all Australians to help us save our national asset. When I talk about Bondi, of course, I think of all our beaches. As I have said so proudly for so long, Bondi just happens to be the most famous and still the most breathtakingly beautiful.

It is a national disgrace to foul our beaches and it is a national responsibility for us to be involved in protecting them. First we have got to have some honesty. There have been all sorts of deceptions, deceptions by the authorities, deceptions by those politicians who want to protect tourism and local businesses, which naturally suffer. The impact on tourism of this potential disaster is incalculable. We cannot protect all businesses any more. Today we hear that fish sales have gone down by 30 to 40 per cent. That is half a million dollars a week.

But there is another sort of deception. It is a deception I get involved in. It is hard for us who live in Bondi to believe pollution is occurring. Some of us steadfastly refuse to believe it. We just do not want to believe it is as bad as it might be. I do it myself all the time. Every time I want a swim, I will use any excuse to pretend it is all right. I ask my own experts, the lifesavers. If the members of the surf clubs say it is okay, I will go in the water. The surf club members are the most handsome, fittest people I know, especially those who have been swimming at Bondi for years and years. I will keep going in for a swim if they do. They are the experts I trust. Like those who swim 365 days a year and remain fit and healthy, I will keep going. I am lucky: I am fit and I love the sea. I go there to feel good. But some people go there and get sick. If I pretend there is absolutely nothing wrong or that the water is perfect, I am as irresponsible as the authorities who have deceived us for years.

If I look at Bondi on a good day when it is crystal clear-and there are plenty of those good days-and if I turn my gaze from the brown stain heading for Bronte and Coogee, I would be as one-eyed as the company executives at Ranger Uranium Mines Pty Ltd, surrounded by Kakadu National Park, who stand with their backs to the harsh ugliness of the mine, look across the tailings dam to the beautiful Mount Brockman escarpment in the background and claim that the dam is like a lake enhancing the landscape. Of course, Ranger's biggest problem-unsolved as yet-is waste. And that is what the problem at the beaches is all about-a different sort of waste.

If I claimed there was nothing wrong, I would be like the Queensland Government putting roads through the rainforest, in its words, `so more people can see it', and thereby destroying the forest itself. I would be like Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd at Coronation Hill, saying that the Alligator Rivers catchment area will not be harmed by anything it might do. I will not be like that. There is a problem and we have to face up to it.

The reason there should be hope for Bondi-and for Mackenzies, Tamarama, Bronte, Clovelly, Coogee and Maroubra and for Manly and the northern beaches-is that in this struggle for the environment there is no conflict with a profit making body which claims it is necessary to inflict damage for an alleged benefit. There is no profit for anyone in any of this destruction. The only enemies in this battle are dishonesty and lack of will. It is too late for us to pretend ignorance. That was only the result of the authorities' dishonesty and our loyalty anyway. Now even the Water Board is saying it will give Sydney the whole unpleasant truth. It is a bit late, but honesty will be a great help in solving this problem, and lack of will can be overcome if all levels of government-Federal, State and local-make an effort to cooperate.

Until now the Federal Government has been left out. Some years ago I wanted to propose an inquiry by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts. But when we looked into it, all responsibility in that area lay with the State and local governments. A sewage summit was held in Waverley a couple of weeks ago. I was not invited because, apparently, nobody thought it had anything to do with the Federal Government. Senator Richardson said recently that he had received no requests for Federal assistance from the States-certainly not from New South Wales. Perhaps in New South Wales people are still too confused trying to work out the facts and options after years of misinformation. I certainly hope political motives are not involved, even though Tim Moore said that if the Federal Government became involved it would only be for votes.

What can the Federal Government do? It is true that it has no legal responsibility at the moment. Some say it has no power to act. Perhaps it has the power somewhere, but there is no legislation it can use to intervene. Stop the Ocean Pollution says we should enforce the 1975 London Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships. That convention does not cover land-based outfalls and our legislation simply enacts its protocol. I am advised that we cannot extend it to cover land-based outfalls such as pipelines without involving the Federal Government in every land based water management process, every outlet, every stormwater drain, but it should not be beyond the ingenuity of our legal and constitutional brains to work out the powers to allow us to intervene through legislation.

The other way the Federal Government can be asked to help is financially. At this stage nobody can be certain that any money handed to the States will be used in a way that will solve the problem. The record is not too good. Too much money has been spent wrongly already. Bob Carr said he thinks there can be cooperation. Waverley Council thinks there can be cooperation. The Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation has some good answers. Perhaps the Commonwealth Government's most important role right now is to acknowledge that the problem is everyone's problem. It is a national disgrace, so it is a national responsibility to be involved. Perhaps we can initiate the cooperation that is needed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilson The Hon I.B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to focus attention during the minutes at my disposal on the plight of Australian families. The present Government has told us that it is contemplating providing tax cuts. I want to say again what I have said earlier this year, that tax cuts for the needy should take priority over tax cuts for all.
