The needy, on my definition, are Australia's families, families supporting dependent children, families supporting dependent spouses and dependent children, and families supporting only dependent spouses. It is those families, whatever their level of income, who are in great need. Some are in real need; some are in comparative need. The components which provide tax relief for families have declined in real value during the period of office of the present Government. The incomes of taxpayers with dependants-those with dependent children, those with dependent children and spouses, and those with dependent spouses alone-have fallen. The tax brackets have not been adjusted during the term of office of the present Government. The effect of this bracket creep is that the standard rate of tax of the Fraser Government of 30c in the dollar on every dollar earned by the great majority of the full time work force has been increased by a massive 33 per cent to 40c in the dollar. More and more of Australia's full time work force in the lower paid categories are now finding that their nominal income is taking them into that 40c tax bracket. The spouse rebate has not been adjusted, so those who are supporting spouses, particularly those caring for children, have been given no real relief. In fact, the real tax burden on those families has been increasing.

SPEECH.PARA: The family allowance has also not been adjusted for six years. Indeed, the family allowance for many families has been taken away. The social security system is totally inadequate in its recognition of the role of families in the support of dependants. Even when the components which provide tax relief for families were at their maximum levels, they were inadequate. They were a token gesture. The amounts set were unrelated to a proper assessment of the impact on a taxpayer's reduced capacity to pay tax due to the costs of supporting children and dependants.

Last week the Australian Institute of Family Studies (AIFS) produced a very interesting bulletin called Families and Tax in 1989. It raises some issues which we in the Opposition have raised over recent years. But it is inadequate; it does not go far enough. It is unduly influenced by the policies and stated objectives of the present anti-family Labor Government. In this regard it fails to identify the full extent of the need of taxpaying families for tax relief in respect of the children they support. It fails to acknowledge the cost of supporting a dependent spouse. Though it talks of the importance of equity, it makes no attempt to develop proposals which reduce the tax burden to a level which takes account of the costs borne by taxpayers in supporting dependants as compared with the burden imposed on taxpayers with no dependants. Some of the assumptions upon which its argument is premised are based on prejudice. Some of the assumptions are not even stated. Those which are expressed are often not adequately justified.

In dealing with family allowance, the AIFS points out that it is the major policy measure that recognises the reduced capacity of people with children to pay tax because of the expenses involved in raising children. The Institute of Family Studies says it is appropriate to regard this as part of the tax system and that it should be reviewed as a negative tax payment. It should not be regarded as a welfare payment. However, it points out that the rationale of making payments to all families has not been fully understood by some and sometimes is not agreed to at all. I draw to the attention of the House that Dr Cass in the Social Security Review paper, which was brought out last year, expressed the view that family allowances should be universally available to all families. The AIFS supports that view and says that such allowances should be paid to all families in order to achieve horizontal equity, so that families with the same level of income should get tax relief, if they have children, greater than the tax relief that is provided to families or individuals with a similar income but not supporting dependants.

The AIFS points out that family allowances for those receiving them have fallen 43 per cent in real terms, but it fails to evaluate the appropriateness of the level at which they were originally set. The rationale for family allowances and the family income supplement is that low income families should not be worse off than those families on unemployment benefit. Surely, the amount of family allowance and family income supplement is the extent of the impact on the capacity to pay tax due to the cost of children in not only low income families but all families. My view is that the universal family allowance that is being advocated by the AIFS should not be limited to a mean $10 a week but should, in the case of children under 13 years of age, be of the order of $31 a week and, in the case of children over that age, $41 a week, so that all families can achieve a proper level of horizontal equity between taxpayers who are supporting dependent children and those who are not.

In 1984 the AIFS published a paper entitled Cost of Children in Australia. It offered for the first time a systematic estimate of what it costs for Australian children to be fed and clothed at a basic level. In this report, Kerry Lovering points out:

It is important to note that these figures do not include costs of housing (mortgages, rents, rates), transport, school fees or uniforms, child care, holidays (in the case of low-income families), medical or dental expenses. In the case of low-income families the figures are a basic survival costing only.
Attempts have been made to quantify the direct costs of children while recognising that the indirect costs of children may have an even greater impact on one or both parents.

The Institute is inclined to agree with the argument that family allowances should reflect the direct cost of children and that family rebates should reflect the indirect costs of children. This is essentially because it sees that the direct costs of children can be justified by achieving horizontal equity. To ensure horizontal equity, it acknowledges the direct impact of the costs of the support of children on a family's real income and that this impact should be recognised by a universal provision in the tax transfer system. I urge the Government to reintroduce a universal family allowance, but I urge it to do so at the real cost, not accepting the somewhat irrational justification of the Institute of Family Studies for the low figure of $10 per week.

Let us look at what the options are. There are experts who say that there are such things as equivalence scales; that it costs approximately 20 per cent of the cost of maintaining a couple at a basic level to look after children. What the Institute of Family Studies suggests is that the tax threshold for a couple should be $12,373. It then takes 20 per cent of that and, instead of saying that 20 per cent of that figure should be paid by way of universal family allowance, it discounts it to 22 per cent of that figure. It is crazy to suggest that families could support children on 22 per cent of 20 per cent of the cost of supporting a couple when expert evidence and the Lovering report indicate that the figure for supporting children should not be $10 a week but of the order of $30 to $40 a week.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lavarch Mr M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Saturday I had the pleasure of attending the official opening of a new service for the intellectually disabled within my electorate. It was the opening of an adult training centre in the suburb of Lawnton in the Pine Rivers shire. The building became available to the Endeavour Foundation, which is the service provider, due to the decision of the Queensland Government to assume total responsibility for the education of intellectually disabled children. The Carawartha site up to that time was a special school run by the Endeavour Foundation. It became vacant at the end of last year, and the Endeavour Foundation has decided to pilot a new adult training centre program in the building.

SPEECH.PARA: The grievance that I wish to draw to the attention of the House today is the decision of the Department of Community Services and Health not to fund the Carawartha Centre. I will also touch upon the difficulties that the Endeavour Foundation has experienced since the enactment of the new Disability Services Act. I doing so, I make it quite clear that I do not support the views expressed by my colleague the honourable member for Petrie (Mr Johns) almost one year ago when he spoke about the Endeavour Foundation in a grievance debate in this House. At that time, the honourable member for Petrie attacked Endeavour's attitude to the new disability services legislation. He also attacked Endeavour's financial priorities and some of its service models and outcomes. My experience has been quite to the contrary.
I believe that the Endeavour Foundation has a very real and true commitment to the disability services legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —A good organisation.

—As the honourable member points out, it is a good organisation. It has a real commitment to the legislation. I will quote one of the board members, Mr E. C. Baston, when discussing the impact of the legislation. He said that the legislation is:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a piece of enlightened legislation and provides the statutory vehicle for handicapped persons to achieve their full potential and an enhanced quality of life.

There is no dispute between this Government and the Endeavour Foundation about the Disability Services Act. Unfortunately, there is dispute between the Endeavour Foundation and the Department of Community Services and Health about the implementation and the objectives and principles of the particular legislation. The problem lies in the different interpretations which officers within the Department have given over a period of almost two years. For instance, in October 1986, when the new service types under the legislation were first described in document form, this document together with discussions with departmental officers led Endeavour to think that its existing services, with some minor modifications, would certainly be funded under the new legislation. However, by February 1987 this advice had been reversed. It was declared that its existing service types would not be funded.

In May 1987, the then Australian Director of the Department, Dr Madden, stated that the types of services currently provided by many sheltered workshops, such as those run by the Endeavour Foundation, could be funded under the category of `supported employment' under the new legislation. These contrary messages which have been coming out of the Department have caused a great deal of concern not only for Endeavour in terms of a corporate entity of board members and management but also for the families of the adults and children that have been cared for by the Foundation for decades. Unfortunately, the real problem is the concern being caused to those families. I am not interested in pushing Endeavour's barrow; I am interested in pushing the barrow of those families and those disabled Australians who need service providers such as Endeavour and that need to be adequately looked after under the new legislation.

In my opinion, this centre does fall within the spirit and, indeed, almost the letter of the disability services legislation. The philosophy behind that legislation was summarised by the Minister for Community Services and Health, Dr Blewett, when he addressed the Australian Council for Rehabilitation of Disabled convention in Melbourne on 10 November 1988. Looking at part of the Minister's speech, he said:

In formulating our policy, we all agreed that services for disabled people should be responsive to each person's ability rather than their disability; that they should develop people's strengths, rather than concentrate on their weakness.
He went on to say:

We want residential services and living skills services to operate in a environment which as closely as possible mirrors the mainstream of life in which people are constantly learning and adapting to new situations, making difficult personal decisions and exercising choice and independence with the assistance and advice of people they trust.

They are, of course, fine words and words on which I do not think there is any disagreement from members in this House, and certainly not from the Endeavour Foundation. The difficulty is in taking those words as embodied by the legislation and actually getting a service on the ground, a model that fulfils those aims. In the particular case of the Carawartha Centre, we have an existing facility. Admittedly it was designed as a school, but the infrastructure is there. It is lunacy, in my opinion, to say that this centre cannot be used in order to impart living skills because it is not a community based model; it is not a nice home in a leafy suburb where there are only four or five people in there and one can go in and in an environment as close as possible to that of a normal home learn the skills. What is being taught in this particular adult training centre is exactly the same as what would be taught in that community based model-that is, the independent living skills, the ability to deal with things such as public transport; simple things, such as being able to prepare one's own meal, being able to handle those everyday decisions and cope with those everyday situations which the rest of us who are fortunate enough to have our full faculties just take for granted.

If those skills are being imparted by the centre and if the people there are able to have a more fulfilled life, are able to enjoy their life more fully and move out into the broader community as a result of the skills which they have been taught by this centre, then why in heaven's name can it not be funded? At the moment the yearly operating cost of the centre is something in the order of $80,000. Under the general scheme of things the Commonwealth could be expected to pay a proportion of that by way of subsidies for salaries. Currently, because of the Department's decision, the Government is not picking up any of the tab and the cost is being borne entirely by the Endeavour Foundation. Endeavour is a large organisation and it can bear that cost. It can bear it in terms of the centre at Lawnton, but it is trying to pilot a similar centre now at Newstead and at other centres throughout Queensland. It simply cannot do it without some form of government assistance.

Who loses if no funding is made available? Does Endeavour lose? It does not really matter to Endeavour; it already has established service models and a well-developed program. Those who lose are the individuals involved-the individuals missing out on that particular service, the individuals missing out on the opportunity to have their lives enhanced. If there is stubbornness on the part of Endeavour I certainly do not support that in any form, but I think there is a responsibility on the part of the Department and a responsibility on the part of the Minister to make sure the difficulties that have been experienced over the last two years are overcome and that some position can be reached with Endeavour so that services of this type are indeed funded.

There is hope on the horizon, I am able to report. We are currently awaiting a report of two working committees about eligibility criteria and the sheltered workshops which are run by the Endeavour Foundation, to see how they can be funded and what modifications are needed. I believe that if Endeavour were given clear guidelines on exactly what changes it had to make, it would make those changes. It is not trying to be obstructionist; it is trying to accommodate. I believe it deserves the support of this House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch) on what was an excellent speech. There is not the slightest doubt that services to our aged and disabled have deteriorated rapidly, and I believe that reflects a general lack of commitment by this Government and its bureaucracy. I want to refer to similar types of problems. There is no doubt that during the past six years living standards in this nation have declined markedly and the average Australian family has been squeezed.

SPEECH.PARA: Nothing has contributed more to these falling living standards than the reduced effectiveness of our public services and the management and distribution of health services and policies. Medicare has been a financial disaster and has thrown public and private hospital administration into chaos. Waiting lists at public hospitals are still a national disgrace. It is not, of course, the well-off in our community who are hurting but the poor and the underprivileged. Medicare has placed additional strains on an already stressed public hospital system by discouraging the use of private hospitals. Not only does Medicare reintroduce the unfortunate concept of so-called free public hospital treatment without income or means test, but it also loads the dice heavily against private hospitals competing for privately insured patients. There are heavy disincentives against private hospitals in the proposed insurance and subsidy arrangements, which have encouraged State governments to pursue their own vendetta against private hospitals.

I wish to refer particularly to the bush nursing hospital system in Victoria, a system developed as a result of great strength and strong leadership in rural communities which through selfless service and the generosity of local communities built and maintained highly regarded hospitals with competent local staff. There are a large number of these hospitals in Victoria, with a bed capacity approaching 900. They are community owned, are non-profit organisations and yet are categorised as private hospitals and therefore must be self-supporting. Patients unable to afford both the taxation levy and private insurance are bypassing their local hospital and, with the penalty of time, expense and risk, are travelling to public hospitals long distances from their own district.

What therefore is loudly hailed as a universal health scheme cannot be used by those who need it most at their own community hospital. The prime purpose of community health service delivery is being destroyed. The availability of a local hospital has a large social and economic bearing on a rural community as a whole. It maintains services so necessary for doctors, for ambulances and for chemists and, with the excellent expansion of aged persons facilities during the past decade, facilities for the full range of health needs of our ever increasing aged population. The Government's answer is to rationalise and regionalise the system-in fact it has simply been a reduction in services-and penalise those most in need and those most isolated. Today we have a health system that is not designed as a health delivery system but as a financial system. We have reached a position where the very future of health services is under threat. We have a hospital system desperately struggling for survival and we have a system where the Government's cry for social justice in so many areas is becoming a farce.

Last month in my electorate, at a town called Warracknabeal, we heard of a tragic story for a number of hospitals of rising costs and falling revenues. Representatives from hospitals outside my electorate, in Avoca, Pyramid Hill, Korong and Merino, as well as all the hospitals in my electorate, attended this meeting. Later on that month there was a public meeting at Murrayville, in my electorate, on the South Australian border, and 240 people attended in an effort to stem the financial haemorrhage and maintain a satisfactory level of service.

I believe that this Government and the Victorian Government in particular are trying to eliminate bush nursing hospitals, depriving lifetime residents of their rightful chance to use their local facilities. I believe they are giving impetus to the loss from our district of young families and young people who need these essential services. I believe that in some communities in my constituency and in others in Victoria up to 70 per cent of residents are dependent on welfare but of course, with the way the system is administered, they are prevented from admission to their community hospital. Of course the Government is stopping the payment of private insurance payments for long term patients at these hospitals.

We must remember that in some of these more rural and isolated areas people are huge distances from facilities. If the people of Murrayville, for instance, lose their hospital-and there is a very real reason to believe that may occur if something is not done in the next week or two, as they have a $70,000 overdraft all of which is the responsibility of the local community-they will have to travel at least 110 kilometres, from Murrayville to Ouyen, to receive medical and health services. Yesterday, here in the Parliament, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) was concerned that people in the western suburbs of Melbourne had to travel to the eastern suburbs to universities. Of course this is a real problem, but at least those people are only about 20 miles from the university and have a satisfactory rail system to get there. These people in Murrayville are at least 110 kilometres from their local hospital and have no public transport whatsoever.

The most disappointing thing about the closure of bush nursing hospitals is that over the years these hospitals have survived almost entirely on community support, relieving government and taxpayers of their expense. I believe the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) must immediately introduce tax deductability for private insurance and he must immediately remove the Medicare levy from those people who do not have a public hospital facility. He must immediately allow a change to the system of categorisation that would allow bush nursing hospitals to take public patients. In the face of growing community and industry concern about the inability of insurance funds to cope with rising costs and declining membership, I think the Minister also has an unequivocal duty to state clearly whether all funds are complying with the statutory reserve requirements designed to guarantee settlement of contributors' claims.

This issue in one of crisis and I believe nothing better indicates that than an editorial written in the Horsham newspaper, the Wimmera Mail Times, on Monday, 20 February 1989, commenting on both the meeting in Warracknabeal the previous day and subsequent meetings in Murrayville. The editorial is headed `Bush nursing hospitals face crisis', and reads:

The time for straight talking by federal and state governments on the future of bush nursing hospitals is well past. Health ministers continue to hedge and cower from any kind of commitment to or against the bush nursing system, now in the throes of a desperate struggle for survival.

If the federal Health Minister Dr Blewett and his Victorian counterpart Mrs Hogg believe there is no place for bush nursing hospitals in the Australian Labor Party health strategy, so be it. But let them come out and say so. Bush nursing communities would then at least know where they stand.

The current process of attrition, of wearing down by ruthless, regulatory process, is brutal, immoral and a travesty of human rights. The government is saying it does not recognise the need of people who, because of circumstances or choice, live in isolation.

Simply, the Federal Government wants to knock the bush nursing system out of existence. It refuses to allow the hospitals to accept public patients, and forces people who wish to use their own community hospital to be doubly insured-by compulsory Medicare levy and private insurance. They are denied a tax deduction for their private cover.
If the bush nursing system collapses there will be chaos in health care. Public hospitals will have no hope of providing the extra beds.

The urgent need is a policy statement from Dr Blewett and Mrs Hogg. Do they really want to force bush nursing hospitals to the wall? And how do they plan to cope with the demand on centralised hospital facilities and medical staff?

I am seeing the Minister at 9 o'clock tonight and I hope that he will recognise this need and do something urgently with his Victorian counterpart to ensure this vital health service remains for rural Victoria.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Most honourable members will have heard reports of Australian travellers who kiss the soil of Australia on their return. It is not uncommon for Australians visiting foreign lands to be told that the present standard of living in Australia is the envy of the world; to be told that our way of life, our freedoms, our security, our unlimited opportunities have made Australia a sanctuary of civilisation. These are the attributes that spur more than one million foreign people each year to inquire about migrating to Australia. There are other observations to make about Australia in 1989. Despite Australia's wealth and its allure to the rest of the world, we still face great challenges. I do not only mean the challenge to ensure that Australia is secure militarily, but also the challenge of building a strong Australia, economically and socially. These challenges can only be met by a nation united, not a nation divided; by a nation that is led by a united government, not by a divided government. For six years Australia has been led by a united government-a government whose policies have given certainty, consistency and security; a government whose aim has been to achieve economic reconstruction, national cohesion and practical cooperation.

SPEECH.PARA: Later this year, or early next year, there will be a Federal election. The people of Australia will exercise their constitutional right to re-elect the Hawke Government. They will have compelling reasons to do so. Memories of the failures of the Fraser-Howard years will, with absolute certainty, direct them well away from the future Australia re-visited by a Howard Government. I will make some brief observations why the Hawke Government will continue to enjoy the overwhelming support of the Australian people at the next election. I turn first to industrial relations. A great deal of credit for Australia's vastly improved industrial relations during the almost six years of Labor Government is due to the successful operation of the prices and incomes accord. Honourable members will recall that an average of 249,200 working days a month were lost in the period January 1976 to February 1983-that is, the period under the Liberal-National Party Government. From March 1983 to October 1988, an average of 120,000 working days were lost each month. Under the Hawke Labor Government there was a 52 per cent drop in working days lost compared with the wasteful record of the Fraser-Howard Government.

Independent research by Beggs and Chapman from the Australian National University concluded that the Hawke Government's consensus based incomes policies have contributed to reducing the levels of industrial disputation in Australia. The study estimated that, after adjusting for changes in economic conditions, strike activity during the accord period 1983-1987 was 82 per cent lower than for the Liberal-National period 1964-1982. Is it any wonder, therefore, that effective productivity of the nation's capital stock has enjoyed good results? For example, between 1982-83 and 1987-88 output per unit of real capital stock in Australia increased by 6.6 per cent. Honourable members will compare that increase of 6.6 per cent in five years with the 6.7 per cent decline in capital productivity recorded over the preceding five years, 1977-78 to 1982-83-that is, when the present Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) was Commonwealth Treasurer.

The Leader of the Opposition condemns the accord. The Liberal-National Party's policy document Future Directions, or, as it is more widely known across the nation, `Futile Diversions', calls for a return to the values of 30 years ago-the era of division and disruption-with its constant strikes and loss of production in manufacturing industry. The Australian people do not want back to future policies. They want policies, they support policies, that are certain, consistent, predictable and successful. The Hawke Government's policies on industry development have brought about an attitudinal shift on the part of industry, unions and government-for industry, an emphasis on innovation, productivity and enterprise, for unions, a recognition of the need to increase employment by freeing up industry and modernising work practices, and for government, constant reappraisal of policy to enhance the overall productive capacity.

The results of these initiatives are there for all to see. For example, in the manufacturing industry between 1982-83 and 1987-88 production grew by 16 per cent, investment grew by 23 per cent and exports grew by 45 per cent. Between 1981-82 and 1986-87 research and development in manufacturing grew by 100 per cent in real terms. These achievements are unprecedented in Australia's history. We will not find the recipe for these achievements in the empty manifesto of the Leader of the Opposition.

Educating Australia and reskilling Australia are fundamental to our economy and our social cohesion, and for every Australian to provide the path to fulfilment as a productive citizen. Despite its best efforts, the Fraser-Howard Government failed to have more than just over one-third of young Australians stay on to year 12 at school in 1982. After just six years under the Hawke Labor Government between 57 and 58 per cent of young Australians stay on to year 12. By the early 1990s the Hawke Government policy should have two-thirds of Australian school children staying on to year 12. In the last year of the Fraser-Howard Government, student assistance for 16 and 17-year-old children in low and moderate income families was about $23 a week. Under Labor, it is $53.55 a week. The Hawke Government is opening the doors of tertiary education to every academically qualified young Australian. Within three years there will be another 49,000 new student places, and by 1991 the Hawke Government will have created 130,000 new higher education places in just six years compared with the just 26,000 new higher education places in the previous seven years of Liberal-National Party government. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) is owed the gratitude of the nation for his efforts to educate and reskill Australia.

Will Future Directions give young Australians the chance to gain a university education? It is not likely to, if we read the Opposition's policy on higher education. The Howard policy is to fund extra tertiary places by imposing tertiary fees negotiated by the institution and the student. Not only will the student have to haggle with the institution over the fee, but students from low and middle income families will miss out because the tertiary fees will be just too expensive-with a medical degree costing upwards of $90,000 and an engineering degree costing around $50,000. Future Directions will not help our sons or daughters get jobs.

Look at the record of the Fraser-Howard Government. Unemployment rose during the Fraser years, at first gradually then at levels not seen since the Depression. More than 200,000 jobs were abolished during the Leader of the Opposition's last 15 months as Commonwealth Treasurer. His back to the future policies put a Depression value on the security of a quarter of a million Australians. By 1983 Australians in every walk of life had had enough. The said `No way' to the future directions of Mr Fraser and the present Leader of the Opposition. Since April 1983 more than 1.2 million new jobs have been created, over 80 per cent of them in the private sector. Job growth in Australia has been almost double that of the rest of the industrialised world. It is one of the most cherished accomplishments of the Hawke Government. The Leader of the Opposition calls for a return to the attitudes of 30 years ago. By that we may assume he means the Liberal-National Party attitudes of 30 years ago. There is no need to go back 30 years to discover the true meaning of coalition values. One need only scrutinise the Leader of the Opposition's five years as Commonwealth Treasurer. This period is not mentioned in Future Directions, and for good reason. It was during this time that there was a collapse of public morality. Tax cheating, fuelled by unbridled greed and manipulated by the coalition's supporters, became, in the words of its own royal commissioner, `Australia's fastest growing industry', at a cost of billions of dollars to the ordinary families of Australia. It was a national disgrace.

There has never been any public apology by the Leader of the Opposition for his role in this shameful period in our history, yet during his time as Commonwealth Treasurer he perfected an interesting technique when other things went wrong and errors were uncovered. On these occasions the Leader of the Opposition was wheeled out to admit that something dreadful had occurred, but only occasionally was he prepared to take the blame. The newspaper headlines during his period as Commonwealth Treasurer spell it out: `Howard admits a major blunder', the Australian, 31 May 1979; `Treasurer ``reneges'' on promises', the Canberra Times, 25 May 1979; `Financial system a mess: Howard', the Australian Financial Review, 24 July 1980. Are these the headlines that qualify a man to become Prime Minister? Are these the headlines of a man who would keep Australia on a stable course? Are these the headlines that would describe a man at the top who is a force for prosperity, a force for improving the well-being of all Australians, or are they the headlines of a man who leaves behind a trail of tragic blunders? I am certain that it will be with a sense of pride and faith that the people of Australia at the next election once again re-elect the Hawke Government and secure for themselves stable, clean, competent government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition has been arguing for some time that Australia is facing major economic problems which the Government has refused to tackle seriously. Recent confirmation of our warnings has come from the continuing poor balance of payments figures and the blow-out in the measured rate of inflation. As the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) himself acknowledged, those two figures were a disaster for his Government-a disaster not so much because they measure poor economic performance but because they let the cat out of the bag, dispelling the myth of prosperity since the Prime Minister and his failing Treasurer (Mr Keating) came to power. Those figures only confirm what the Opposition has been saying for a long time. However, they do the very valuable service of convincing many other people that the Government's so-called economic policy is in tatters.

SPEECH.PARA: An issue that I want to raise in this debate today is the detrimental influence of political considerations on economic policy in general and monetary policy in particular. The political interests of the Australian Labor Party are divergent from economic commonsense. This was cogently illustrated by an editorial in the International Herald-Tribune a couple of weeks ago. That editorial seriously questions whether the social democratic governments of a number of Western countries, including Australia, can deal with the challenge of competition from a unified European market or from Japan and the so-called Asian dragons, as the case may be. On the rare occasions when the Treasurer has acknowledged that Australia has any economic problems at all, he says that he can deal with them when no other Treasurer in Australia, or for that matter in the world, can because of the unique benefits of the accord. Mr Des Moore, of the Institute of Public Affairs in Victoria, has-despite what the honourable member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) had to say just moments ago-effectively demolished the over enthusiastic and plain wrong claims of apologists for the accord, who argue that it has been a tool for reducing industrial disputes, for wage restraint and for employment growth.

The International Herald-Tribune effectively contradicts the claims that the accord is unique and will save Australia from its economic problems. It suggests that Australia might well be less likely to avoid the problems of social contract-style governments than some other countries with social democratic governments which have managed to distance themselves from the rapacious demands of their trade unions. For example, in Spain the socialist Prime Minister, Mr Gonzalez, has said that the unions had `asked him to do things incompatible with the efficient running of the Spanish economy'. We have had no such brave attempts at independence from either our Prime Minister or our failing Treasurer. They remain beholden to the trade union movement in Australia and to the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU). This has cost Australians dearly, contributing to the economic problems which we now face. The International Herald-Tribune is unequivocal on the costs of devices such as the accord:
It adds to inflation. It increases the cost, direct or indirect, of the goods the country wants to send abroad. It almost certainly puts more people out of jobs.

That sums up Australia's problems emanating from the accord very neatly indeed. We have persistently high unemployment, growing inflation and an apparent inability to export enough goods to pay for products Australians want from overseas. Indeed Australia's economic problems might be seen as the classic symbols of a crumbling social contract such as the accord between the Labor Party and the ACTU. It is clear that the continuing existence of the so-called accord is dictated by political rather than economic needs. The Labor Party is in a bind since it can no more continue in government with the accord that it can hope to control the demands of the trade unions without it. This bind will result in compromises for the sake of electoral success which will continue to harm Australia's economic future. An economic policy should not be judged by how it appears to work in good times such as the seven-year expansion which the world outside Australia has been going through. If the Government cannot address the long term micro-economic problems now, it will never manage the tough decisions we will be faced with in the future.

The Treasurer either seriously underestimates the looming economic problems, or is deliberately misleading this Parliament and the public as to the nature of those problems. It might almost be better if he were misleading us. We might then have some measure of confidence that he will attempt the much needed realignment of the economic path which he has set. As it is, the Treasurer is showing all the signs of understanding only the political problems he faces in ever becoming Prime Minister, without any comprehension of the economic problems which his political manoeuvrings have produced. When touting the virtues of his last Budget, the Treasurer's first thought was the political impact of his efforts on the dwindling electoral prospects of the Keating-Hawke Government. We have an economic crisis and the best that the Labor Party has to offer Australians is political hype and a cynical exercise in marketing with an eye simply to the next election.

What people may not fully realise is that these shallow exercises in politics by the Treasurer and his Party have had serious detrimental effects on our economy. Recently the Treasurer has made it quite clear that monetary policy is firmly under his control. The Reserve Bank of Australia does what he says. The once vaunted independence of the Reserve Bank has been revealed as a myth which obscures the political interference in the development of monetary policy decisions. A growing amount of economic research has examined the links between the business cycle and monetary policy and the political cycle of the decline and fall of governments. Most governments, of course, would prefer to go to an election at a time of expansion in the economy so that they can benefit from the growth in wages, employment and profitability which accompanies such growth. Nevertheless, anyone who is concerned about this country's economic future would be aware that the prospects for lower interest rates in time to save the Keating-Hawke Government are rather slim-unless there is shortsighted intervention in the market, further undermining our economic future and our economic security.

Members of the Labor Caucus have been reassured that there is no need to worry about interest rates; the Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland, will fix all that. He will bring home the bacon. What cost that bacon? If the Treasurer continues his cut and paste job, he will only bring further calamity to an economy which, particularly in recent times, for cynical political reasons he has ravaged. Inflation over the years of the Keating-Hawke Labor Government has continued at more than double the rate of our major trading partners. It is a major failing which contributes to the high interest rates which Australians now face. One does not have to be a monetarist to acknowledge that monetary policy has a major effect on inflation and interest rates. The Treasurer has burnt his monetary policy bridges behind him by his refusal to use fiscal policy as well as his overuse of loose monetary policy for political benefit. The sly phone calls to the Reserve Bank will not produce the results he desires or we all want. With the rediscount rate charged by the Reserve Bank already at 16.4 per cent the Government does not have much money policy flexibility. Until now the rhetoric of tight monetary policy has been a myth. Over the past 12 months broad money has grown at 18.9 per cent. Is it any wonder that Australia has an inflation problem?

The Government's economic policy has failed to address the long term problems of micro-economic reform. Its forays into macro-economic policy are ad hoc; at best, attempts to make the most of a deteriorating situation. Take the so-called wages policy of the Government. It does not have one. It does not extend beyond the imminent wage/tax trade-off sometime this year. I will concede at one time the accord was a wages policy of sorts-not a very good policy, but the Government had one and was smugly proud of it. As it now is, it would be a brave man indeed who tried to predict wages outcomes in 1989. The wages/tax trade-off is not a wages policy but an exercise in wishful thinking and `see how she goes' improvisation. The basis of the Government's wages policy these days is to have a chat with its masters at the ACTU.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Courtice Mr B.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Party Government in Queensland has decided to bypass the Industrial Commission to ram through voluntary employment agreements (VEAs). It is against the background of corruption and incompetence within his own Government that Mr Ahern has decided to stir up the issue. The matter came to a head last week when the State Industrial Commission sought clarification from the Industrial Court on aspects of the largely untested legislation. The Government's response was to remove the condition for VEA applications to go before the Industrial Commission. In future the Office of the Industrial Registrar and the Industrial Inspectorate will simply examine VEA applications and grant approval if minimum statutory requirements are met. Only afterwards will parties to the agreement be able to lodge complaints or seek redress before the Commission.

SPEECH.PARA: The Queensland Confederation of Industry described the changes as dramatic overreaction. For the Ahern Government it is yet another dramatic backdown.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are desperate.

—They certainly are desperate, as the honourable member for Fisher says. The Government originally promoted the idea of applications being heard by the Industrial Commission as the prime safeguard against unscrupulous employers exploiting employees. Experience of VEAs to date shows that the conditions are employer determined, with little opportunity for employees to have a real input. Employees, to have a proper input, would be required to negotiate on and understand complex industrial relations issues. Most people do not have this knowledge, expertise or experience. Individuals do not have access to specialist advice. They are open to unfair bargaining arrangements and, in certain situations, this leaves them open to exploitation and discrimination. Employers usually have access to industrial relations specialists, and advice from employer organisations and specialist industrial relations consultants. This is why union participation is so vital in the development of agreements. Union members involved in industrial agreements have access to assistance and advice from their union which can provide support to ensure the negotiation process is not one-sided.

SPEECH.PARA: The Ahern Government is seeking to smash the process in two ways: it seeks to take the unions out of the process and to take the Industrial Court out of the determinations. The Ahern Government claims this is in the name of deregulation, yet it has not shown the same commitment to deregulation in other sectors of industry. The Ahern Government simply shows double standards by singling out the union movement for deregulation. It is simply an attack on working families. The conditions that have been gained did not come out of charity, they came after decades of hard work and sacrifice by the trade union movement.

The State Government has made no attempt to free up agricultural boards and farmer organisation membership. Queensland dairy farmers, for instance, are forced to belong to the Queensland Dairymen's Organisation-in other words, compulsory unionism. Cane farmers are forced to belong to the Queensland Cane Growers Council through an Act of the State Parliament-once again, compulsory unionism. The Queensland Graingrowers Association is currently pressing the State Government for a compulsory levy to force grain growers to become members of their organisation-once again, compulsory unionism. Membership of the Queensland Commercial Fishermen's Organisation is necessary to obtain a professional fishing licence.

The Ahern Government should free up membership of these organisations if it is truly committed to deregulation. Farmers should be able to opt out of these compulsory unions if the Ahern Government is sincere in what it is saying. There is no reform or freedom of choice for many agricultural and resource boards. An Act of the Queensland Parliament determines how much sugar cane can be grown, where it is grown and to whom it can be sold. Acts of Parliament control egg production, dairy production and bean production. Even coal producers are regulated by the Queensland Government. Coal producers must use Queensland railways to transport their product, and they pay one of the highest freight rates in the world to do so. Because of Queensland Government taxes, it costs twice as much to rail a tonne of coal from the mine to the wharf as it costs to ship the same tonne of coal to the other side of the world. All this, allegedly in the name of efficiency, is presided over by the State Government of Queensland. The number of State Government boards shows the extent of over-regulation in Queensland. Despite a promise in 1985 to reduce the number of statutory boards, by July 1987 160 new boards had been created. In July 1987 there were 1,218 boards employing 50,000 people and containing 3,677 elected or appointed members.
Mr Sciacia-Good jobs for the boys treatment.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the honourable member says, if the experience in my electorate is reflected throughout Queensland most of the appointed members are not there through any expertise at all-they are there because they are National Party branch members. The last figures I took out for 1987 showed that members of most quangos are paid meeting attendance fees and chairmen of many of the larger boards are paid salaries of up to $45,000 a year. So there is gross inefficiency and over-regulation. Quango members are paid $59 for meetings up to two hours in length or $79 for meetings up to four hours. Chairmen not on salaries are paid $89 for short meetings and $119 for meetings over four hours.

SPEECH.PARA: The Queensland dairy industry is a good example of this. Queensland consumers pay the highest prices for milk in Australia, yet the returns to dairy farmers are no greater than in the rest of Australia. When I last checked, there were nine boards governing the dairy industry in Queensland. The Queensland Milk Board has 10 members who ensure there is an adequate supply of dairy products, fix prices and promote the use of dairy products. There are eight other quangos duplicating various parts of the Milk Board. For example: the Milk Transport Advisory Committee is a committee of three which deals with disputes relating to the transport of milk; the Milk Vending Advisory Committee has a membership of three and concerns itself with the registration of vendor vehicles; the Milk Sales Promotion Advisory Committee has a membership of nine and makes recommendations to the Milk Board about the promotion of liquid milk; the Milk Entitlements Committee has five members who determine the size of each processor and establish schemes to regulate access of processors to markets; and the Dairymen's State Council has a membership of eight and they are there to represent dairymen-which all the others are supposed to be doing anyway. The Filled Milk Advisory Committee has three members who make recommendations with respect to newly developed commercial products. Of course, if any of these quangos trying to help suddenly run off the rails, in Queensland there are a lot of quangos ready to put the situation right again. I guess one is looking after the other. There is the Milk Appeals Tribunal and the Milk Pasteurisation Tribunal.

TALK.START.PARA: —No wonder a bottle of milk costs so much.

—As the honourable member for Bowman says, it is so sad that although the price is high farmers are not gaining anything out of this. It is just total over-regulation by a State government that talks about efficiency and a vision of excellence, yet it is made up of nothing more than backwoods regulators looking down a time tunnel. Last week I outlined how over-regulation is costing cane producers millions of dollars in lost potential, and just for the record I will repeat it once again: the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics suggests that 50 per cent more sugar could be produced in Queensland under a more appropriate regulatory environment. At current world prices this amounts to $500m in extra income for Australia, and also more jobs. Again we are paying the price for the incompetence of the Queensland Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The quangos that are administering primary industries such as the dairy industry are costing taxpayers plenty of money as well. Instead of applying deregulation across the board what we have, especially in the wheat industry, is a coalition split. In Queensland the National Party is threatening to set up a State wheat board, yet another quango. The Ahern Government has no sophisticated strategy to revitalise the Queensland economy. It has singled out the trade union movement and working families, wage and salary earners, and has made a lop-sided deregulation attempt to take the emphasis and the spotlight off the incompetence of the last 20 years of maladministration and the scandals of the Fitzgerald Commission of Inquiry into Possible Illegal Activities and Associated Police Misconduct. I believe that if it is sincere it should apply a freeing up strategy to take the cost strictures off primary producers so that they can expand and employ more people. But as I said, what we have in Queensland is a one-sided attempt to create a scenario for the next State election by attacking average working families.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —After listening to the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) I must say that an old saying came to mind, something to the effect that people in glass houses should not throw stones, and if he is going to talk about deregulating in one area he ought to look at the area that is causing the greatest concern to Australia right now, and that is whether or not there should be deregulation in the labour market. I doubt that there would be a single member of the Parliament on the Government side who does not privately concede, certainly in his own mind if nowhere else, that this is probably the single most important thing that we have to do in so-called micro-economic reform if Australia is to get out of its present malaise. So I would suggest that he ought to be a bit more even-handed in his criticism of others.

SPEECH.PARA: I thought today I would like to talk a little bit about the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the great play he likes to make on his integrity. We are always hearing the Prime Minister telling us what a great man of integrity he is and how people should trust him, but there are a number of occasions when we have had reason to question this. Let us look at some of the promises he has made before elections. For example, before the 1983 election he was very quick to pledge that, under Labor, Parliament would run its full term and yet we have had three elections in the last six years and there is every chance of there being yet another one this year, which would make four in seven. That is even more curious when we consider that the Government was campaigning last year for four-year terms.

But we can also point to other promises. Before the 1984 election, the Prime Minister pledged to bring home ownership once again within the reach of ordinary Australian families. The Prime Minister has called a housing summit and has blamed everyone. He has blamed the States, he has blamed everything but his own interest rates, for the fact that Australians are finding it harder and harder to buy a house. Just before the Western Australian election he was very quick to give an indication to Australians that he believed that interest rates would not rise, and he was sure they were going to fall this year. Again, one has to question the man and what he is prepared to do when he claims that he is such a man of integrity.

I would like to talk specifically about some comments made in the biography of the Prime Minister by Miss Blanche d'Alpuget. I note in the foreword to the biography she makes this comment, which I think is important to draw to honourable members' attention:
It is a mark of his candour and integrity that he has permitted me, as an authorised biographer-
I emphasise `authorised'-
to write about him critically . . .

In this book Miss d'Alpuget draws attention, on pages 346 and 347, to the live sheep dispute of 1978. It is very interesting to see the way that dispute is portrayed. Much of the story is made up of direct quotes of the then Mr Hawke, now the Prime Minister. I would like first of all to draw to honourable members' attention some of the things that he said and then to go on to refer to a recent paper put together by Mr David Trebeck, who was then the executive officer of the Australian Wool Growers and Graziers Council and is now the principal of the consulting firm ACIL Australia Pty Ltd. His paper shows that on at least five points Mr Hawke quite clearly misleads readers of his biography. On page 347, in reference to the live sheep dispute in Adelaide in 1978, the book states:

The dispute had abruptly shifted towards flash-point. In South Australia a convoy of sheep trucks had already set out and was only hours away from arriving at the wharves; both the picketers and the farmers were carrying weapons. Hawke recalled:

`I got to Tony (Street's) office and he told me what the position was: we only had a couple of hours. The situation was appalling-the union blokes and the farmers were armed, and when the trucks arrived at the wharves that was going to be it'.
It sounds very dramatic. It continues:

`We got on the telephones and managed to get a message to Ian McLachlan, who was the leader of the farmers' group in South Australia. McLachlan is a very able bloke and one of the toughest I've ever had to deal with in negotiations. Finally, we were able to talk to him in a telephone box at Wallaroo. I had a very tough conversation with him-I pleaded then demanded that he had to call his people off because otherwise there would be bloodshed, maybe death, and if that had happened then there was no way the thing could be unravelled, and at any rate, it was just too horrible to contemplate that people might be killing each other. He was very tough-his side undeniably had a case: the farmers were really scratching financially and were fighting for their livelihood-but to his credit he responded. He called his men off. That was just the first step'.
That quote in the book is attributed to the now Prime Minister. The book goes on to say:

A senior government official who requested anonymity, said later that Hawke's handling of the dispute had averted not just a brawl on a wharf in South Australia but the development of a widespread violent confrontation. Both sides had access to weapons-the farmers were carrying iron clubs and batons gnarled with barbed wire, and are rifle owners-
note `are'-
while the meat workers could-
note `could'-
lay their hands upon a murderous variety of skinning and boning knives.

All very dramatic staff, but as Mr Trebeck points out in his paper the reality was very different. Certainly individual farmers may have welcomed the opportunity for a stoush and were not intending to retreat if challenged, but apart from several factual errors in these accounts the reality was that the farmer leaders were in total control, at all times. In fact, an editorial in the Adelaide Advertiser a couple of weeks beforehand had commented on the fact that the farmers were properly controlled. That editorial of 5 April 1978 says, in reference to widespread traffic jams in Adelaide a few weeks before in relation to the dispute:
. . . yesterday's demonstration was no less impressive for the restraint shown by its leaders.

So that was the control that they had. But if we go on we find that when the dispute was said to have been resolved, in fact the sheep were being trucked away from Adelaide, where it had been intended to load them, and up to Wallaroo, a small port some miles north of Adelaide and where there was no picket line. The whole reason for trucking them there was to avoid confrontation, not to try to provoke it. So the farmers were taking a very responsible attitude. As it pointed out, the meat workers would have had to drive 150 kilometres in order to get there to provoke a dispute, because the farmers were already on the wharf and had already set up their own picket line. While some drove up there, in the end they had the sense not to hang around. The suggestion by the Prime Minister that McLachlan had to call his men off was completely wrong, because they were already there. They were not moving in to set up a dispute. They were already on the wharf waiting to load the sheep.

In regard to the suggestion about the farmers' weapons, as has been pointed out virtually the most dangerous piece of equipment on hand were links of PVC pipe-which farmers use quite regularly in yards for moving stock. How some union official could have seen that these were filled with lead, or that the farmers had bits of barbed wire welded onto steel pipes and so on, is just absolutely intriguing. As Mr Trebeck points out, Miss D'Alpuget's anonymous government official, who could see it all from Canberra, was clearly finding the atmosphere too heady. The amplification about rifles and knives clearly was added by the author, but as Trebeck points out the Prime Minister's role in the dispute was far more limited than he and some other people have since made out. He was in the unusual position of facing people who were tough, determined and correct and he had little choice in the end but to try to assist the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union save some face-a task made more difficult by the fact that, as he has admitted himself, he was not widely admired by some of the senior union office bearers.

But the other important point is that Hawke had already capitulated by the time he spoke to McLachlan at Wallaroo, having earlier spoken to the then President of the Woolgrowers and Graziers Council, Sir Samuel Burston. He had offered to call off the union action in return for discussions. Burston had responded that he would not even convey this proposal to the South Australians without iron clad assurances that all bans would be lifted, all pickets removed and normal loading resumed. Hawke gave this undertaking to Burston, and thereupon Burston rang McLachlan. That was long before Hawke was able to do so, and so at this stage there was no negotiation at all, let alone any pleading with McLachlan. So when we hear this it makes us wonder about the Prime Minister. It raises a further question about what else he has tried to do to rewrite the history of this particular issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crawford Ms M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to grieve on behalf of 1,000 school children and their parents at Woodridge State High School, because this school has been removed unilaterally by a stroke of the Queensland Government pen from our disadvantaged schools program. This school, honourable members will appreciate, is in an area which has some recognised social difficulties. We have quite a high unemployment rate, and that schools program attempted, by the employment of a number of people, to ensure that children stayed at school till the end of their secondary schooling and so were able to enter the work force with the right skills and training.

SPEECH.PARA: The school is situated in an area that is recognised and noted as having very little social infrastructure. What other city of 130,000 people in Australia has no hospital and no public transport system? Very little of it is kerbed and guttered, and there are other difficulties as well. What has happened is simply that some people with problems have been placed there, with no contingency plans to meet their needs. The community has responded magnificently, and large numbers of community organisations are working in a cooperative way to help each other-with no assistance, I might add, from the Queensland State Government.

This State high school attempted through our disadvantaged schools program to address what it considered to be a very long term problem-the maintenance of its children at school, which would then enable them to have a realistic chance of entering the work force in 1989 Australia. What do we see? A government that cares? No-a government that quite simply takes money from those most in need and gives to others. It gives no explanation, no reason-despite the fact that parents and teachers have called for answers and the students themselves have sought clarification. Still we are uncertain, unsure, and we are dismissed because we do not count; the State Government does not care. So I rise on behalf of this school, and remind everyone that Federal Government money is involved. This Government provides the resources and the funding for that program under the disadvantaged schools program. It is then disbursed at the whim of the State Government. It selects the schools; it selects the people who make the decisions. We heard earlier the honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Courtice) make statements about the way in which choices are often made by the Queensland Government. One has to ask some fairly cynical questions as to what is happening here.

On behalf of those students and their parents, the community at large in Logan City and the school community of Woodridge State High School, I make this plea that the school be reinstated into the special education program to ensure that the Australians of the future will have the skills, the talent and the education to meet the challenges of the 1990s.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to bring to the attention of the House something which I believe is an absolute scandal. With all the recent talk regarding the role of governments in providing residential land to ease the current housing crisis, particularly in Sydney, I am staggered that the Greiner State Government has the cheek to blame the Federal Government for the supply problem. Within my electorate, at Narellan-which is adjacent to Camden, in Sydney's south-west-land which could ease this crisis is lying idle because of a State Housing Department miscalculation. The land in question, owned partly by the State Housing Department and partly by the private sector, was rezoned for residential purposes in May 1982. I should know because at the time I was the regional manager for the Department of Environment and Planning in New South Wales and was responsible for the rezoning of that particular land. Services to the land, such as water and sewerage, have been available since early 1987. The land itself has the potential to release a total of 9,000 lots to ease the housing shortage. Of these, 3,300 could be developed by the State Housing Department and the balance by private developers. I understand the Housing Department plans to develop a meagre 400 to 420 lots this calendar year and 400-plus a year subsequently. Nearby, private developers with land holdings of 118 hectares with a potential of 375-plus lots are seeking council approval to proceed immediately.

SPEECH.PARA: Why has this procrastination occurred in the State Government? Why are only 400 lots a year being released? Why did the Department of Housing miscalculate the demand for housing and think its stocks in Campbelltown, nearby, could cope? When will the Greiner Government get its own house in order before it throws stones at the Commonwealth Government? I believe that this is a scandal of monumental proportions. The land, as I said, is serviced; it is rezoned. There are 9,000 potential lots that could be released in Sydney's south-west with easy access to Sydney, to industrial areas around Bankstown and inner Sydney through a freeway system, and through a reasonably developed electrified rail system. But the land is lying idle.

Why is Greiner sitting on his hands? Why is the State Government not proceeding to ease the housing shortage in New South Wales, and in Sydney in particular, by not hastening and fast tracking the development of this land? I urge the Premier to do so. This is a matter that is above party politics. Why does he not get on with the job that he is supposed to do in New South Wales to ease the crisis.
