DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Wesley Vale Pulp Mill-Medical Care-Raoul Wallenberg-Tibet-Lord Mayors' Visit-World Heritage Listing-Pharmaceutical Companies-Sale of Condoms-Use of Modems-Waterfront Work Practices-Wesley Vale Pulp Mill-Security Appeals Tribunal Report

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Goodluck Mr B.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, last weekend there was a public debate in Tasmania and it was a debate about the mill. At that debate I was accused of being a liar. I might be many things but I am not and never have been a liar and I think most people in this House know that. It might have been the result of a bit of a misunderstanding. I will quote what I said:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hawke said last October he supported the mill; it was one of the best economic benefits to come to Tasmania.

The honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) asked me, face to face, `Where do you stand on the mill, Bruce?'. I said, `You know where I stand on the mill, Duncan. Where do you stand?'. He replied, `I support Mr Hawke'. That is all I said. Then I hesitated and I said that there was an equivocation in that debate because there was not very much support from the Australian Labor Party for the mill. That is fair comment. The point that I was making was this: If that mill in Tasmania is to be a reality, we must not brook the Browns of this world, or people such as that new woman who is coming out of the dust down in Tasmania to spread her wings; we must get rid of them. We must construct that mill in order to boost the economy of Tasmania and give jobs to the workers. The Labor Party purports to support the workers. Well, I support the workers and I will support the workers in Tasmania over the rotten greenies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sawford Mr R.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although most Australians are probably unaware of the fact, I believe they would be most concerned to learn that entry into general practice for doctors currently requires nothing more than undertaking one year in hospital service after graduation. They would be even more concerned to learn that currently there are no requirements for general practitioners (GPs) to maintain a sufficient level of competence by regularly updating their skills and knowledge.

SPEECH.PARA: Congratulations are certainly due to the Hawke Labor Government and particularly to the Minister for Community Services and Health (Dr Blewett) and the President of the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners, Dr Gates, on the agreed joint initiatives to provide improved patient care by improving the qualifications of GPs. `Raising the Standard of General Practice and Quality Patient Care', an agreement between the Commonwealth of Australia and the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners, is an outstanding example of leadership by government, combined with professional cooperation and initiative by medical care providers-the GPs of Australia-for the benefit of the whole Australian community. I applaud the efforts of all involved and acknowledge that this agreement is a real watershed in the relationship between government and the medical profession in Australia. I sincerely hope that this agreement receives the publicity it deserves in disseminating the key issues to all Australians. It focuses on primary care and makes the GP the gatekeeper of medical care and service for all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

—One of the great and brave humanitarians of this century was Raoul Wallenberg. I say `was' because I believe him to be dead, but like thousands of other Australians I want to know whether he is dead, and, if so, what were the details of his death. Raoul Wallenberg saved 100,000 Jewish lives in Budapest in 1944. His work was perhaps more remarkable than that of Schindler, whose deeds have been so graphically chronicled by Thomas Keneally. With the full support of the Swedish Government, Wallenberg outwitted Adolf Eichmann and the Hungarian authorities and in six months he had achieved the most significant rescue of Jews from the Holocaust. He was taken into custody by Soviet forces at the end of the Second World War and his fate is unknown. Virtually all Federal parliamentarians have signed a petition asking the Soviet Government for his release or details of his death. I will join a delegation of Australian Jews tomorrow in presenting that petition to the Soviet Counsellor. I urge the Soviet Government, in the spirit of glasnost, to tell the world what happened to Raoul Wallenberg.

—Today, 30 years ago, Chinese troops marched into the very tiny kingdom of Tibet. In those 30 years thousands of temples have been destroyed and more than one million Tibetans are dead. This week-indeed, today-on the streets of Tibet, Tibetans are being killed. Those Tibetans are unarmed and are fighting for the very cultural survival of their religion, their architecture and their traditional way of life. Many members of this Parliament, in both the Senate and the House of Representatives, have in the past day signed a petition to the Chinese Government requesting that Government to give autonomy within the People's Republic of China to the Tibetan people. This afternoon it is my intention to present that petition to the Chinese Ambassador and, on behalf all people who believe that civilised nations do not kill unnecessarily and do not use the force of war to impose their will on others, to urge him to recognise the call of the Dalai Lama to give peace to the Tibetans and to recognise their traditional culture.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter The Hon R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Lord Mayors of our great cities are visiting Canberra and therefore I think it should be regarded as a very special day. I would point out also that scattered throughout the land are literally 800 to 900 local authorities which do a really magnificent job for this country. I express the view-and I am sure members of both sides of the House share it-that without these men and women in local government it would be a sad day for us all.

SPEECH.PARA: The other matter I want to mention is the aftermath of the World Heritage listing-the declaration of the rainforests in my part of the world, far north Queensland, as being under the control of World Heritage. I say `control' because literally once a World Heritage declaration is made, the control of our destiny goes abroad. I am concerned about the aftermath of that declaration and I appeal to the Government and particularly the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) to look much more closely into the question of meeting the requirements of the little people, the many workers in the timber industry, who have suffered almost a termination of their way of life.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee Mr M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This afternoon I take this opportunity of the 90-second statement to draw the House's attention to an article which appeared on the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald in January. The headline was `Drug company paid doctors to prescribe medicine', and I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: A drug company paid psychiatrists $200 for each patient they enrolled in an open clinical evaluation of a new anti-anxiety drug which had already been approved for general marketing in Australia.
This evaluation of the drug Buspirone, marketed by Astra Pharmaceuticals Pty Ltd involved 44 psychiatrists around Australia who prescribed the drug to a large number of patients.
I believe that it is grossly improper for pharmaceutical companies to pay an incentive to doctors who have the opportunity to prescribe their patients those drugs.

Madam Speaker, perhaps you will recall that last year, the year of the Seoul Olympics, the Australian Consumers Association released information which exposed the activities of one pharmaceutical company. That company was running a competition for doctors who, if they filled out a form declaring that they had prescribed that company's drug, would be eligible to enter a competition to win an all expenses paid trip to the Seoul Olympics. I am pleased that the pharmaceutical company withdrew the offer once it was exposed to the public because I think that when they go to their doctors Australians need to be assured that their activities in prescribing drugs are based purely on sound medical reasons.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members could hardly have missed the pun and cliche ridden news item revealing that condoms would be removed from sale in the New South Wales Parliament House souvenir shop. The outraged leader of the Call to Australia Party, the Reverend Fred Nile, said that condoms were a symbol of promiscuity and selling them in Parliament House was `a bit like they were under royal patronage'. The souvenir shop may well have been an inappropriate place to sell condoms, but these sorts of comments display an unhealthy attitude to what is a normal, healthy activity. As a pharmacist, I have sold condoms for many years and I can assure the public that condoms are not a symbol of promiscuity, but a necessity for many people. Removing condoms from sale is like praising ignorance as a virtue.

SPEECH.PARA: My inquiries disclose that condoms are for sale in this Parliament-not in the souvenir shop, but at Aussie's shop. He tells me they are a fast moving item. They are available in red and green packaging, but do not bear a parliamentary seal, only a price sticker. The public can rest assured that politicians in this Parliament and the staff who work here are representative of the general community with apparently varying and normal sexual appetites. And a parliament should be representative of the community if it is to be relevant to the lives of the people. It would be hypocritical of this Parliament if we were to ban the sale of condoms in the parliamentary precincts at a time when there is a bipartisan acceptance that promotion of condoms is a desirable part of sex education and prevention of acquired immune deficiency syndrome.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is the Chair's intention to give the next two calls to the Opposition. As no Opposition member rose last time, I gave two calls to the Government, so this time it will be two to the Opposition.

—Most of us are most impressed by the tremendous advances that have been made in technology. One of the areas that have certainly flourished in recent times is the use of computers and the use of modems. I would like to bring to the attention of the House the case of one of my constituents who came to see me the other day, bearing a Telecom Australia account for more than $8,000 for a two-month period. I went to Telecom and its officials have been most cooperative. Basically, what happened here was that this person had put a 215-cycle modem on his telephone. It was thought that his 12-year-old son must have got into the hacking business and managed to contact a number of computer organisations in the United States. But on checking the situation, Telecom found that the actual power of that particular modem would not have given him access to international lines. Telecom has been tracing that problem. It would seem that there had been some interaction between this gentleman's modem and another one of much greater strength, also situated in a Brisbane suburb. It would seem that the larger modem has now plugged into the smaller modem and somebody has been doing the wrong thing by using the modem system to dial the United States, sometimes for hours on end. The cost has been going to the original modem-the one owned by the man who received the $8,000 Telecom account. While this technology continues to advance-
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is the Government dragging its feet in its attempts to clean up our waterfronts? While I am speaking, there are ships waiting to load and unload at our ports. Some of those ships have been waiting more than 18 days to dock. When they eventually dock, they and their owners will be subjected to the stand- over tactics of the dockside unions. Those tactics are costing this country millions and millions of dollars. One of the hardest hit industries is the one which is currently contributing more than 40 per cent of our export income-the rural industry.

SPEECH.PARA: We should consider that the North American wheat terminals can average between 60,000 and 120,000 tonnes per man. Australia's proud record is 14,504 tonnes per man. It is little wonder that we read that it is cheaper to ship aluminium from Sardinia to Tasmania than it is to ship it from Queensland to Tasmania. These delays are costing up to $50m a month. Ten years ago Australia sold 15 million cartons of apples a year to Europe; this season only one million cartons will be exported. One of my constituents in the Saddleworth district was involved in shipping mohair to the United Kingdom. The Australian wharf charges amounted to $261. On inquiry, my constituent discovered that the equivalent charge in the United Kingdom was a mere $61.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D. J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier during 90-second statements my colleague the honourable member for Franklin (Mr Goodluck) referred to a debate in Tasmania last weekend and certain comments that were made. In that debate I expressed myself in language which would not be regarded as parliamentary when referring to certain recollections of the honourable member for Franklin. Let me say now in parliamentary language that my recollection of a conversation that he purported to relate to the House is not akin to his recollection at all. To be quite blunt, let me say that at all stages I have taken a consistent position in my views on the Tasmanian pulp mill-we support downstream processing, but only if it is guaranteed to be under strict environmental controls and poses no threat to environmental or public safety.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I conclude, I mention briefly a report that was tabled in the House, the Security Appeals Tribunal report, and commend to the House the recommendations of Mr Justice Samuels. Mr Justice Samuels urges the Government to review the practice of departments in not referring security clearances to the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation but doing them themselves. This practice has meant that many Australians have not been given the chance to have their security classification reviewed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m., in accordance with sessional order 106a, the time for members' statements has concluded.

—My question is to the Prime Minister. I refer the Prime Minister to his rebuke at his press conference today of the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support in relation to the third runway at Sydney Airport, in which the Prime Minister said, `No, the only criticism I would have is of what would have appeared at one stage in public, not in the Parliament, to have been a pre-emption of a consideration by the Cabinet of all of the options'. Was the Prime Minister not referring then to the possibility of constructing a third runway-and thereby rebuking the Minister for keeping that option alive-yet is it not a fact that, according to a press statement made by Senator Gareth Evans on 19 August 1988, the former Minister for Transport and Communications said, `It is Government policy not to build a third runway at Sydney's Kingsford-Smith Airport'? Therefore, was the Prime Minister rebuking the Minister for merely upholding Government policy?

—As far as I can follow the question from the honourable gentleman-I must say it is a strain-the position is quite clear. If he is going to begin to do justice to my comments in regard to my Minister, he should look at all of what I said. I indicated the complete confidence I had in the Minister. I did make the comment in passing, which I have made to the Minister. I had not thought it wise to let it appear-not from his own position; every Minister of the Cabinet is entitled to his view, but there may have been cause for some people to conclude this from the way that he had spoken-that the matter had been determined by the Cabinet. Of course, it had not been. That was all I said to the Minister and that is the only point of criticism.
—I cannot understand--

—Look, how about just behaving yourselves today and being quiet. As to what was said by Senator Evans, that is a matter of record as to what the state of Government policy had been. There has been a lot of discussion about this matter. There have been a lot of proposals put. More stuff has been put on the table since Senator Evans has spoken. What I have been concerned to establish-and let me, not only in answer to the honourable gentleman, but to everybody take this opportunity to make it clear to the House-and what I have been ensuring is that when this matter does come before the Cabinet for decision, as it is now before us, all the options and all the arguments, all the pros and cons about every alternative, should be before the Cabinet so that we will have that opportunity of considering every alternative. That means that if we were persuaded on the argument that the third runway was the best way of going, then that would be the decision. Every alternative will be before the Cabinet.
—My question is to the Prime Minister. What action is the Government taking in response to the remarks made yesterday by Mr Javed Chaudry about the novel The Satanic Verses by Mr Salman Rushdie?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members opposite may have noticed that I did answer questions on this matter at a press conference I had this morning. At that stage, I had only seen the press reports in this morning's paper. I have since had reports of remarks made by Mr Chaudry on television last night. Let me repeat that Mr Chaudry's remarks are deeply offensive to me and to the Government and I would have no doubt they are deeply offensive to every member of this place. They are particularly offensive in relation to implicit threats to Australian booksellers. I am advised that Mr Chaudry is an Australian citizen, having arrived here in November 1972 and having obtained citizenship in November 1975.

ANSWER.PARA: I have sought the advice of the Director of Public Prosecutions to see whether any Federal law or laws have been broken and the DPP has advised that in his opinion no offence has been committed against the Commonwealth by Mr Chaudry. I am sure that State governments, which would regard this as a serious matter, will be examining it to see whether offences have been committed within their jurisdiction and I would suggest that they should be doing that. I imagine that they would be.

I said this morning that this Government was not one which was demanding adherence to one set of values. That is not the sort of society Australia is. But that does not mean that there are not values to which we have the strongest commitment and, in particular, we have the commitment to the right to speak freely without fear of violent reprisal or threat. That is one of the values that I think, on both sides of the House, we hold as of fundamental importance. The Government therefore deplores any threats made against Australians over the distribution of The Satanic Verses. I find it particularly deplorable that the right of free speech, which we cherish in this country, is being abused in order to threaten other Australians who wish to avail themselves of it. As I said in the House on 28 February, I congratulate those in the Australian literary and artistic community and in the publishing and bookselling business who have indicated that they will not be intimidated by such threats. Any violent action in Australia will be dealt with under the criminal law. I can assure you, Madam Speaker, and the honourable member who has asked the question, and I can assure this House, that this situation is being monitored by the Commonwealth and State agencies, which are cooperating in this matter.

I also wish to say-and I think it is fair to these people to say it-that there are approximately 120,000 Australian Muslims and as individuals or that whole group of 120,000 Australian Muslims, they should not be tarred with the brush of a handful of extremists such as Mr Chaudry or those who used children in a completely unacceptable way in a demonstration at Arncliffe on Sunday.

I am pleased to say that virtually without exception the established leadership of the Australian Muslim community-who of course are genuinely offended by The Satanic Verses and we acknowledge that-have totally disowned the calls for violent reprisals against Mr Rushdie. I refer particularly to the concerned but responsible comments made many times in recent days by a respected Muslim member of the Advisory Council on Multicultural Affairs, Dr Ahmed Shboul. The Australian Federation of Islamic Councils has also expressed the same moderate views and it has eschewed any recourse to violence. In conclusion, I add that because the Australian Muslim leadership has declined to provide sensational headlines in this issue, a void has to that extent been created and it has been filled by the abhorrent ravings of a few unrepresentative extremists.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Treasurer and I remind him of his responsibility to this Parliament for the tax file number legislation. Will he desist from blaming innocent taxpayers for breaching the Privacy Act when the Commissioner of Taxation admits using outdated records for the mailing of tax file numbers? Will the Treasurer disregard yesterday's non-answer on this issue and insist on proper safeguards and methods?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, yes! Why not? Why not?
—You take the money; so, do the job.
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting.
—The honourable member asked the question yesterday and he got the answer. Here is the Australian Taxation Office sending out letters to help people--
—`I'm from the Government; I'm here to help you'.
—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will heed the Chair.

—That is, to let them discover their tax file number, which the Commissioner apparently told the honourable member in some airport terminal, so he understands all this. The Commissioner told the Deputy Leader of the Opposition what the purpose of this is. It is to be sent to taxpayers for their assistance-many taxpayers apparently have difficulty in finding or understanding their tax file number-because after 1 April all taxpayers will be required to submit a form with their tax file number on it. So the Taxation Office assists the taxpayers of this country in that task. It is working off a list which is somewhat dated.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members-Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, the Commissioner admits this. It was somewhat dated and letters went to people who have moved or who are deceased. But the essence of what the Taxation Office is seeking to do, that is help people lodge this form post-1 April, is being attacked by the Opposition.

—My question is to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel. Has the Minister seen suggestions that the new defence information network she launched yesterday is unwanted by defence personnel and service families? Will the Minister inform the House of the benefits, if any, of the family information network for defence (FIND), and tell the House whether it is true that the network has been rejected by defence families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for McEwen for his question and also for his great interest in the Defence Force personnel living at Puckapunyal in his electorate. Yesterday I did launch a new family information network for defence personnel, which we call FIND. This is a 008 information network system which is now available to all defence personnel and their spouses around Australia. The main reason for introducing this is to provide a ready access to all information and advice on all conditions of service that exist in the Defence Force. It will, of course, be anonymous, so people can ring up and find out information without even having to give their name. It will enhance the chain of command and will also support the current family support systems that are available in the Defence Force.

ANSWER.PARA: When I launched this yesterday there were a number of people there, as has already been remarked on in the media, including all the chiefs of defence personnel, many representatives of spouses and one person who actually was not invited, and that was my shadow spokesperson in the Senate. She came along, but not primarily to find out what the system was about, as before she turned up she had already put out a statement condemning it, without knowing any details about it at all. I do not mind that as I have come to expect it from the Opposition and its policies on defence. It has no constructive policies and it spends its whole time condemning ours, whether they be policies on an information system for our families or a major military exercise like Kangaroo 89.

The comment is made from honourable members opposite that she knows more about Defence Force personnel. If she knew so much about them, she should not have put out a statement which said that the Defence Force families do not support this. The wives were there endorsing it and the chiefs of personnel were endorsing it. It is successful as of today. We expected to get about 50 calls a day but as of now we have had about 167. We have helped 167 people and we will continue to help them despite the Opposition's comments. While I am making these points I would like to raise the matter of the personal and vindictive attacks that have been made against many of our officers in the Department of Defence. This was referred to yesterday by the Minister for Defence, and I want to take that one step forward.

Yesterday, in this statement my shadow opponent criticised the person who had been the project officer, saying dismissively that she had been on my staff. In reality, she was a departmental liaison officer, a career public servant of 20 years standing, an expert in conditions of service and she is currently a Defence Force spouse. I loathe those sorts of personal attacks on people who cannot stand up for themselves. That attack by the shadow spokesperson just links up with the comments she made recently, saying that she would sack half those from lieutenant-colonel upwards in the Russell defence offices. This Government is about constructive policies for Defence Force families, and whether it is providing support services for a contingent going to Namibia or whether it is providing support services for families in Australia, we live up to our commitment and we get on with the job.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Treasurer. Are the only people in the mass mailings of tax file numbers taxpayers who have lodged returns for five years or more? If not, does that mean that people who have recently put in returns under false names will be issued with a tax file number?

—I am not aware of who is or is not on the Australian Taxation Office's mailings list. I simply repeat what I said yesterday, and that is that these reminders which the Taxation Office is sending to taxpayers, to assist them to lodge their form after 1 April will now be keyed off the latest tax file year and the addresses which are associated with the latest tax file year.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Has his attention been drawn to claims that the prices and incomes accord between the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions is in fact a myth? Is there any substance to these claims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to these claims and I thank the honourable member for Fisher for affording me the opportunity to rebut them. They appear on page 37 of that rather pathetic document `Futile Diversions'. That process is part of the futile attempt to denigrate the outstanding successes of the accord. The essence of the accord is consultation, cooperation and consensus. It is about industry, unions and government working together. That concept is totally alien to the Opposition, because all it knows and all it is putting forward in industrial relations policy is a reversion to that age old practice of confrontation, division and fragmentation, the old `us versus them' mentality. That is all the Opposition knows and all it can revert to.

ANSWER.PARA: Let us look to the successes of the accord. We have created some 1.36 million new jobs during the period of the accord and in the life of this Government. That represents a growth rate of 3.4 per cent per annum-twice the growth rate of Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries, and four times the growth rate obtained when those who now sit opposite were in power, the disastrous Howard-Fraser years. Some 56 per cent of those jobs have gone to women and 85 per cent have gone to the private sector. So in total, some 7.6 million Australians now have jobs, an all-time record. The document `Futile Diversions' refers to employment not having increased. As I have mentioned, there has been an increase of 1.36 million new jobs, four times better than was obtained by the Opposition. The unemployment rate has been cut from over 10 per cent to 6.7 per cent. That has been achieved at a time when we have seen the highest overall participation rate for 20 years-63.1 per cent-and record levels for women since World War II. The Opposition says the accord has kept prices up. Let us look back to its record. It had an inflation rate of over 11 per cent, in fact 11.5 per cent, and we have brought it down to 7.7 per cent. At the same time there has been an increase in investment, a record increase in business investment, the highest proportion of gross domestic product directed to business investment for 35 years.

The last figures I refer to relate to industrial disputes. I can tell the honourable member, because he is interested in this matter, that we have seen a reduction of almost 60 per cent in the level of industrial disputes compared with those disastrous Howard-Fraser years. That is all the men of division, the men of confrontation, the men of fragmentation in the Opposition can take us back to. All their enterprise bargaining proposals can offer is the same kind of chaos, the same kind of confrontation, that led to that massive wage blow-out, the industrial chaos, the winding down of the economy, and the massive development in unemployment, that we saw in the Howard-Fraser years. The way forward that this Government offers is through award restructuring, and through government, industry and employees pulling together. We are remodelling the way in which we organise our working arrangements and job classifications. We are providing career paths and safer, more satisfying, more rewarding jobs. That is the way in which we will continue to improve productivity and efficiency.

In conclusion, let me say that it is a myth that the Opposition offers any alternative to the successful and effective policy that has been pursued by this Government over the past six years. The Opposition is saying to the people of Australia that the creation of 1.36 million new jobs is a myth. It is saying that the reduction in the unemployment rate from more than 10 per cent to 6.7 per cent is a myth. It is saying that the massive surge in business investment is a myth, and that the 60 per cent cut in industrial disputes is a myth. What we all know is a myth is that the Opposition has a wages policy and a tax policy.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF SOCIAL SECURITY: CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Social Security confirm that since October 1988 confidential information held by his Department, including parole applications, criminal records, Medicare files, bank accounts, passport information, and even one man's tax file, has been received by a Brisbane company with a fax number that once belonged to a Brisbane Social Security Office, and that some of this information was transmitted from the headquarters of the Department in Canberra? Is the Minister aware that when this was brought to the attention of his ministerial office, on behalf of the director of this company, the reply was that the problem was an administrative one and not the Minister's concern? If the breach of confidential personal information regarding Australian citizens by his Department is not the concern of the Minister, will he kindly inform the House whose concern it is? Furthermore, will he tell the House why it took nearly six months for action to be taken on this matter?

—I had my attention drawn to a problem which arose in relation to the transfer of fax numbers between Telecom Australia and the Department of Social Security which led to material being directed to one firm rather than to the regional office of the Department of Social Security. I am aware of that problem as a result of a press report in a newspaper the other day. I immediately asked the Department to investigate the situation and to correct it. As I understand it, that is being done.

—My question is also directed to the Minister for Social Security. Given the widespread public interest in the Social Security Review report of Dr Bettina Cass on retirement incomes policy, can the Minister advise the House of the progress of consultations on this report?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —All members of the House will be interested to know that the process of consultation with respect to retirement incomes policy is proceeding, I think very effectively. It has been assisted by a task force established by the Prime Minister. That task force has now held about 40 meetings in various electorates across Australia attended by more than 2,000 people. The Prime Minister attended such a meeting in his own electorate of Wills. I think it was very much appreciated that he was able to give up his time.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government, right across Australia, has been talking directly to the groups that have met in various halls, and has established a consultation process involving discussions with peak councils-the Australian Pensioners Federation, the Australian Council of Social Service and industry, including the insurance industry. Generally, it has been accepted that issues paper No. 6 has provided a very good framework within which it will be possible for the Government to develop a policy for which there will be very broad support. We have received about 250 written submissions on retirement incomes, including one from the Opposition. Those submissions will be taken very seriously. The Government will continue to work to develop its policy.

In passing, I say that one can contrast that kind of approach-an approach which has resulted in the release of a widely circulated paper, a call for submissions, grass roots meetings across Australia and meetings with the various sectors-with the approach the Opposition has taken. It has recorded a message from the Leader of the Opposition which will cost the pensioner-if any pensioner is silly enough to spend it-at least 53c and up to $2.50, and it says absolutely nothing to the 80 per cent of people on the age pension, apart from the fact that twice yearly indexation will be maintained.

In the area of retirement incomes policy, the Government has taken the view that it is fundamentally important, not to record some message to people in the community, but to listen to people. I think the symbolism in relation to that little exercise is abundantly clear. The Opposition is not listening; it is not willing to go to the effort of sitting down with people around Australia and talking through with them what their concerns are or what the options are that they believe the Government ought to consider and to go about this process in a thorough, democratic and consultative manner.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to the question of X-rated pornography and R-rated video violence. Given that a Senate select committee and a joint select committee have reported on this issue, and the futile diversion of the matter to a Caucus committee three months ago, together with voluminous petitions from Australian citizens on the matter, is the Government yet in a position to tell voters where it stands on excessive pornography and violence in films and videos? Will the Government now support the Opposition Bill on this matter before the Senate? When will the Prime Minister tell Australians and the State Premiers where he and his Cabinet draw the line on pornography and violence?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As far as any direct area of Commonwealth involvement is concerned, the legislation that has now established self-government in the Territory, where the issue--

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members-Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —Here we go again, Madam Speaker. Let us get the giggleometer out; it will be ticking around. Opposition members just giggle, giggle, giggle. That is the level of their capacity. I thought Opposition members would have learnt from yesterday but they are slow learners. In regard to the Australian Capital Territory, as a result of the passage of the self-government legislation, what is to be done in the Australian Capital Territory is a matter for that Government when it is elected.

—Has the Treasurer's attention been drawn to recent media reports of concern expressed by a number of members of both this House and the Senate about the manner in which the Government's foreign investment policy is being implemented? If so, is there any cause for this concern?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to a number of reports of comments by members of the Opposition in this place and in the Senate, drawing attention to what they obviously regard as an excessive level of foreign investment in Australia. On a north Queensland television program on 21 February this year, the honourable member for Dawson called for swift measures to alter foreign investment rules to require 51 per cent Australian ownership. A Queensland National Party of Australia senator, Senator Sheil, was reported in the Gold Coast Bulletin on 1 March as saying that foreign investments should be restricted to joint ventures with local companies. The honourable member for Sturt, from this House, is reported in Tuesday's Advertiser as calling it `a foreign land grab that is a threat to the freedom of Australians'. The Deputy Leader of the National Party has made repeated calls for Foreign Investment Review Board (FIRB) thresholds to be made more restrictive, and the Leader of the National Party on 29 January called for restraint on foreign investment in Australia. I have most of those references with me.

ANSWER.PARA: Each and every call is completely contrary to coalition policy, which is to abolish totally the Foreign Investment Review Board and the existing regulatory framework. The Future Directions policy document states:
In recent years these restrictions have encouraged a dramatic increase in the proportion of debt in total capital inflows and in turn this has an adverse impact on our balance of payments.
And this is the punch line:

These controls should be abolished, except for certain strategic areas such as the media, and with them the Foreign Investment Review Board. They are out of step with the outward looking entrepreneurial spirit we wish to see in Australia.

Some coalition members want tougher rules for a body which they are committed to abolishing, yet this duplicity is marketed all around the Commonwealth as though it is the Government which is allowing in some way unrestricted access by foreign ownership in this country and the coalition parties which stand for something different. The fact is that it is the coalition parties that stand for an open door, open slather, foreign investment policy. The balance we have between the considerations of the dominant control of the economy by the Australian people and the very considerable benefits that worthwhile foreign investments can bring is to be pushed to one side in what is to be some slavish commitment to the entrepreneurial spirit in Australia.

It is true that the Government has relaxed the policy we inherited from the then Government, the now Opposition. We have substantially relaxed it in areas such as services, manufacturing and real estate. But in some places we have made it tighter, particularly in relation to foreigners speculating and buying in the market for established residential real estate. That is, those changes we announced in 1987 to diminish speculative buying by non-residents, which we believe were driving up house prices, have constantly been attacked by the Opposition and are being attacked this week by the Opposition in the Senate. The Leader of the Opposition and his Party stand in favour of foreigners buying established residential real estate, particularly in the Sydney market. But one would not believe that from their utterances. They actually stand in favour of unrestricted foreign purchases of residential real estate in the Sydney and Melbourne markets, but that is not the position that is put about.

So a little bit of straight talking and consistency and honesty on the part of the Opposition would not go astray to let the public know where it really stands. Opposition members try to score off the Government with these press releases and stunts when in fact they are hiding behind the real policy, which is to open Australia completely to foreign investment of whatever variety.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Treasurer. He will recall my interest in tax deductability for donations to mobile life education centres, which are doing such a marvellous job for Australian children, an interest which included the introduction of a private member's Bill last year. The Treasurer advised me late last year that he would consider extending that tax deductability in the next Budget. Have there been any developments which would enable the Treasurer to make a positive statement about the extension of tax deductability for donations to mobile life education centres?

—I think I recall that in writing to the honourable gentleman I said that there is funding on the outlays side of the Budget and support of these initiatives. I said that the appropriate time to consider questions such as tax deductability and the gift provisions is in the course of the Budget deliberations. I stand by that statement. That, along with a lot of other proposals, will be looked at in the Budget processes.

—Has the Minister for Housing and Aged Care seen the advertisement in yesterday's Canberra Times inserted by the Australian Capital Territory Pharmacy Guild relating to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS)? Can the Minister indicate to the House the Government's position regarding the pensioner contribution under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, the Pharmacy Guild has chosen to run a campaign designed to scare and confuse pensioners and the chronically ill. Despite this facade of concern, this is not a health care issue; this is all about a campaign for increased payments to pharmacists. The Guild's leaders claim that the Government has cut its members' income and that the pensioners are next to be hit. I can assure pensioners that there is absolutely no truth whatsoever in the assertion that pensioners are a target. There are no targets.

ANSWER.PARA: Despite pressures on the Budget due to unprecedented increases in the cost of the PBS, this Government has consistently rejected every suggestion-some of which have come from pharmacists as well as from other people in the community-that pensioner health card holders should have to pay. With the Guild, we introduced a safety net scheme to ensure that the chronically ill would be protected from excessive drug costs, and we have repeatedly affirmed our commitment to ensuring that the pharmaceutical benefits scheme can and will provide the most needed drugs to all Australians. There is no proposal before this Government to alter the situation. It is a total fabrication.

The real story is that the leaders of the Pharmacy Guild are blatantly causing pensioners and other people fear, confusion and anxiety. That is simply to disguise the fact that they have failed in the eyes of their members. The Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal-the independent body which sets the levels of pharmacists' remuneration under the PBS-has found the Guild's recent submission for increased rates to be flawed. The Tribunal rejected it and actually reduced the rate by 10c per prescription. This Tribunal's decision has little to do with the Government; it has a lot to do with the Guild and the tactics and arguments it uses to push its case.

That 10c decision is only half the story. The Guild's leaders rarely mention that payments to pharmacists are made up of the dispensing fee, which has been reduced on this occasion by 10c per prescription, plus a mark-up of 25 per cent on the wholesale price of the drug dispensed. For example, over the past two years pharmacy remuneration has increased by an average of 52c per prescription because of that mark-up element. So now the real story is being heard. We want to know why the Guild's leaders will not accept the umpire's decision. Maybe if they helped the Tribunal with information they would get better results.

Let me get back to the real concern in the community which this advertisement raises. The Pharmacy Guild's leadership has now embarked upon a blatant political campaign, a campaign which set out to confuse and scare sick people and pensioners. I should like to quote from a letter from Mr Matthews, the President of the Pharmacy Guild of Australia, to all his members on 7 February. In the first two pages he criticises the decision of the Tribunal-the umpire-and he continually urges his members to become militant. Then he says:

This will only be the first step in an ongoing political campaign. The next is to draw to the attention of parliamentarians the chaos that will commence on April 1 when Zyloprim, Lasix, Daonil and Sinequan etc cease to be benefits. Tell your patients, especially pensioners, of what will happen and suggest they write to their MP.

So here we have evidence of a political campaign against the umpire's decision for more money. The way in which the Guild intends to maximise its campaign is clear from that letter and the advertisement. The Guild's leaders actually want to frighten pensioners. We see the blatant evidence of that campaign in those areas.

Let me make this point clear as it is very important: this is a recommendation of the leadership of the Pharmacy Guild, and I do not expect that Australian pharmacists will indulge in or take up such tactics. My door is open to the Guild to discuss matters concerning their remuneration. My offer to them to assist their customers and pensioners and patients to understand the relatively minor changes to take place on 1 April remains open, but only on the condition that they drops this scare campaign against pensioners and the sick. The Guild now has the opportunity to salvage its credibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Telecommunications and Aviation Support aware that an Industries Assistance Commission commissioned document, associated with its international trade in services inquiry, canvasses the benefits to Australia of so-called guest migrant workers and says that in Australia's case the free movement of labour services could involve, for example, the use of South Korean construction workers to build major civil engineering projects such as airports? Will the Minister advise the House whether there has been any consideration given to the use of guest migrant workers, whether South Korean or other nationalities, to work on major government engineering projects and, in particular, as a means to achieve the Minister's assertion that he could have Badgerys Creek Airport constructed in three years?

— I thank the honourable member for his question and assertion. I am not sure whether the honourable member is actually advocating that the Government should do that. I am not aware of anyone on this side of the House who is even remotely considering that.

—Is the Attorney-General familiar with the operations of a company by the name of J and R Enterprises which is trading as Plan a Year Promotions in South Australia? Has the Attorney-General received any complaints about the products marketed by this company and, if so, what action is the Government taking to address those complaints?

—My ministerial colleague the Minister for Consumer Affairs has received a number of complaints about this particular matter. I understand that the honourable member for Hindmarsh has also made representations in respect of constituents. I am advised that this particular company advertised a directory and calendar for circulation in local areas and invited local businesses to subscribe for advertisements. I understand that the subscriptions were substantial and significant. As a result of no action by the company, in the sense of the timing and launching of the system or the advertisements, many complaints have been received. The complaints were referred to the Trade Practices Commission early this year and it has taken a fair amount of evidence relating to the situation. It has also interviewed the directors of the company concerned. The company undertook to provide a written submission to the Trade Practices Commission on or before 23 October last but this has not happened. As a result of that position I understand from the Minister for Consumer Affairs that the Trade Practices Commission is certainly actively pursuing the matter. It is expected that some action will be taken in the very near future.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training and it relates to Austudy applications, which are means tested on the basis of parents' taxable income for the previous financial year. Why does his Department insist that original copies of taxation assessments be submitted with Austudy applications? Why will his Department not accept a simple statement of taxable income on the Austudy application form, as is the practice of the Department of Social Security, for example, in the implementation of the means test on the family allowance? What safeguards are there to prevent information on this assessment notice-for example, the tax file number-being made available to people who are not entitled to the information? What action has the Minister taken to apply the relevant provisions of the Privacy Act relating to tax file numbers to his Department's handling of these assessment notices?

—Basically the reasons why original documentation has been sought is that, unlike many other applications that are made across the Government for various types of benefits, Austudy essentially is a benefit that is applied for once a year and therefore is not regularly checked in the way that some other benefits are. Accordingly, we felt it desirable to ensure that when the application was put in, the original documents should be sought so that there would be a minimisation of any chance of defrauding the scheme. Accordingly, we have sought to ensure that fraud of the scheme is kept to a minimum. There has been some concern about such things, and in reviewing the arrangements during the past year we have ensured that all procedures are tightened up. This has been part of the tightening up that we have undertaken.
