DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Madam SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government to take all reasonable steps to ensure that security safeguards and procedures are in place to prevent unauthorised access to and disclosure of tax file information.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition brings this matter of public importance before the Parliament today. An element of the concern we have would have been perceived by anyone listening to or observing Question Time today. I asked the Treasurer (Mr Keating) a question, reminding him of his responsibility to the Parliament for the administration of the Taxation Laws Amendment (Tax File Numbers) Act. With the bluff and bluster that we are used to, what exuded through that answer was the answer of a man who does not have a clue about that legislation and does not care. The arrogance and the sanctimony with which he treats the civil liberties of individuals bear out just how hypocritical the Government was last year when we were seeking to hold up the passage of that tax file legislation because we were concerned about the privacy and civil liberties implications. We were constantly traduced as allegedly holding up the legislation to protect the tax cheats.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government could not care less about the efficient working of a tax file mechanism. It cares even less about the civil liberties and the privacy elements involved. The answer this afternoon was an admission that the Australian Taxation Office was `working off a list which was somewhat dated'. If that is not a failure in the terms of the matter of public importance which is before the Parliament, I do not know what is. The subject of the matter of public importance is:
The failure of the Government to take all reasonable steps to ensure that security safeguards and procedures are in place to prevent unauthorised access to and disclosure of tax file information.

Honourable members may be intrigued to know that I did a touch of plagiarising when writing this out. The words contained in this matter of public importance are taken from the Privacy Act. It is the Privacy Act that imposes on the Treasurer, in the administration of his tax file number legislation, those very elements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is the Treasurer?

—Where is the Treasurer? I will come to the question of the Treasurer. Anything that goes wrong within the purview of the Treasurer is never the Treasurer's fault. It does not matter what it is; it is never his fault. If it involves some procedural element in the Parliament, it is someone else who has dumped that problem on him. If it involves the tax file number, it is the citizens of Australia who have breached privacy-not him. If it involves the consumer price index, God damn us, it is the fault of the Hills hoists and everything else around the home; it is not his fault. If it is the balance of payments, it is the fault of the rest of the world. It is never his fault. Those of us who have to address radio stations and the like around the country know that, in all the interviews that have been done on this issue, most of them have been conducted by the interviewers because they are reflecting the anger in the community about the way in which this Government is going about the processing of the tax file number.

SPEECH.PARA: The starting point is not perhaps, as may be thought, the current maladministration that we are seeing. The starting point is the underlying cavalier attitude of the Government from the time it proposed the tax file number. This is an arrogant Government. It exudes arrogance at all times. It cares not a whit for its supporters whom it has always claimed to represent. We know only too well how much they are suffering. The Government cares not a whit for fundamental principles that go innately with a democracy.

Had it not been for the Opposition, this tax file number legislation, honourable members will recall, would be in place today without a privacy commissioner operating. The Government, again with a cavalier attitude, dumped the tax file number legislation in this place in order to get it through and with the intention that at some time, sine die, in the future, the privacy legislation would go through. Thanks to the efforts of the shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), in negotiations with the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate), the 10 amendments moved by the Opposition were locked into the tax file number legislation. So it is not the law at this stage that is wrong; it is the administration. And who is the administrator? Ultimately, it is him. He is not here at the moment, not surprisingly. Our concerns for privacy were the ones that brought about all those amendments. That occurred in the initial stages.

Let us move to the current breaches. The man who has been so vigilant on this issue and is deserving of the credit is, in fact, the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron). He has a multiplicity of examples of the way in which privacy has been stripped asunder from most Australians who reside in Queensland, Western Australia and the Northern Territory and who have been recipients of the letters that have been sent by the Australian Taxation Office. Tax file numbers have been sent to the wrong post box numbers and wrong addresses; they have been sent out in multiples. Distressingly in the circumstances of one of our members on this side of the House, they have been sent to his father, who passed away quite some years ago. The honourable member for Moreton has those examples.

I have raised this matter. The Treasurer seemed to think he was alluding to something secret. I mentioned at a press conference earlier this week that I had been discussing this matter last Friday with the Commissioner of Taxation. As a consequence of that, yesterday we heard that, instead of sending out a plethora of letters to people going back seven or eight years, tax file numbers would now be sent only to those people who had sent in returns in the financial year 1987-88. That is no help. It only cuts down the time frame and the numbers; it does not change the system. It does not meet the objections of people who are receiving or not receiving these letters or the consequences of the letters falling into the wrong hands.

So what is the law? Let me go into the law because the Treasurer says it is not the fault of the Taxation Office. He says, `Oh no brother, I do not accept responsibility for anything. It is not my fault. It is not the Tax Office's fault; it is the fault of all those people who get these letters and open them up'. My old friend here the honourable member for Moreton used to be a smoker. Honestly, does one really think, in an analogous situation, that if I were to go to his place one night, pour petrol all over it, and the poor blighter comes home, lights his cigarette and blows the whole house asunder, it would be his fault? It is the fault of the one who caused the damage, not the consequence of the action. The fool over there will not accept that. I find him one of the most poorly read, illiterate people in this place. I suppose that, if I were to recite the maxim res ipsa loquitur, while this is probably on the lips of all the constituents of the honourable member for Moreton and they are quoting nothing else, the Treasurer may not understand it. But it does mean `it speaks for itself'. So it does in regard to the law that applies in this case.

Section 3.2 of schedule 2 of the Privacy Act states, inter alia, that security safeguards and procedures must be in place to prevent unauthorised access to, or disclosure of, tax file number information. There are other applicable sections. Furthermore, interestingly enough, there is a section in the Privacy Act, relating to the Privacy Commissioner, that is headed `Functions of Commissioner in relation to tax file numbers'. Section 28 (1) states:
In addition to the functions under section 27, the Commissioner has the following functions in relation to tax file numbers . . .
Paragraph (d) states that the duty of the Privacy Commissioner is:
to examine the records of the Commissioner of Taxation to ensure that:
(ii) he or she is taking adequate measures to prevent the unlawful disclosure of the tax file number information that he or she holds;

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the penalty?

—The Privacy Commissioner is given extensive powers. The honourable member can seek further advice for a fee on the penalty. But I will say this: The Government thought about imposing a pretty substantial fee on anybody else who broke the law-$10,000 or two years gaol, hardly a matter of flippancy to be dismissed by the Minister responsible for the administration of this Act. The Privacy Commissioner is investigating this matter now. He is investigating matters that have been raised properly through his office directly to him by the honourable member for Moreton. He is investigating those matters as he should and as he must.

SPEECH.PARA: It is not just these specific elements of the statutory law which I have referred to. I think those of us, at least on this side, with some political motivation founded on principle, with some belief in democracy have some notion and attitude that every right of intrusion which is vested in public officials must carry with it corresponding duties and they must be adhered to. That rights-duties notion does not sit well with a government that seeks to impose many more duties and responsibilities on the public sector. In fact, through that, the duty undoubtedly is on the Treasurer to ensure that the misbehaviour that is occurring ends. The consequences go beyond the breaches of privacy. What are the criminal elements? What are the opportunities for getting access to information unlawfully? What about the prosecutions that are going on now in Western Australia as a consequence of people being able to get into the Australian Taxation Office, get tax files and tax file numbers as well?

The reality is that the Treasurer should be putting his attention towards what ought to be done. Firstly, such mailing actually seems unnecessary. I was moved to interject at Question Time when he was saying how helpful the Tax Office was. I could not help thinking of the old joke that went, among other things: `I'm from the Government and I'm here to help you'. I would say: What was the purpose of the mailing in the first place? The recipients were not people who had to apply for a tax file number; they were being reminded of it.

The honourable member for Moreton will no doubt explain the motivation because he has been to the Tax Office on this issue, but if it is necessary registered mail ought be used. Those opposite say, `Oh, what about the cost?'. I remind them that when they first floated this notion of the tax file number, they told us that it would bring in more than $2 billion worth of revenue. That was subsequently brought back to some $400m. That was enough for members of the Opposition, who are motivated to stamp out the black economy, to see whether we could assist in getting an effective mechanism which properly attended to privacy conditions-a mechanism that the Labor Party regarded in a conference document as being absolutely essential.

I remind honourable members opposite that the Labor Party, at its conference in 1988, passed a resolution with regard to privacy. I simply refer to one subsection of the resolution in an article headed `Labor updates Constitutional, Legal Platform'. It states:

Labor will provide that the introduction of any national identification scheme, tax file number system or other government intrusion upon privacy will be accompanied by safeguards protecting the privacy of the individuals private and confidential information.

That is not being done. In the terminology of the analagous legislation which we rejected, namely, the Australia Card, the little fellow himself, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at Question Time, as reported in Hansard on 15 September 1987, said:
Let me make it clear, Madam Speaker, that there will be no leakage, release of information . . .

He is at it again. He says one thing and does another. Under this Government faults and breaches, as I say, are always someone else's. Whether it is the balance of payments, the consumer price index, the tax file number, it is always someone else. There is always someone who is sought to be sacrificed by the Treasurer on the altar of his own arrogance. We are seeing it done again on what the Government regards as a simple matter. The Treasurer will not even come in to discuss this matter. Not for him the privacy of the individual. Not for him anything that goes to the interests of people. People? He comes in here and talks to me about holding press conferences. I have had more press conferences than he has had breakfasts. What does he do during an election campaign? Sure, he attaches himself, as I reminded honourable members last year, to a press conference, because that is all he does. We never see him in the supermarkets; we never see him in the pubs; we never see him in the shopping centres or with people in aged persons' homes. All his remarks are in the clinical atmosphere of a press conference. Why? Because he cannot be with people. What flows through from that is an absolute disregard of people's rights, of their entitlements, of what they value in a democratic society.

The Labor Party proclaims in its platform its belief in preserving the privacy of the individual when it introduces legislation such as this. It is about time it backed it up and put pressure on the sanctimonious creature who comes in here and poses as a Treasurer, trampling over people's rights. It is time to straighten out the legislation so that there is some confidence in what is supposed to be an effective and equitable system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Speaker indicated that a matter of public importance was to be raised today I noted that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), was less than enthusiastic in embracing it. But he has given a spirited performance, though not saying a great deal about what was in it. Of course, he launched into the tradition that we have come to expect from the other side, and that is of trying to tear down the Treasurer (Mr Keating), to suggest to the people of this country that he is not enthusiastic in his job. We totally reject that and suggest to the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that in the past he may well have had more press conferences than the Treasurer has had hot breakfasts, but that was said in envy of any previous success that he may or may not have had.

SPEECH.PARA: I think a couple of points need to be clearly understood at the start in respect of the particular issue which has triggered this matter of public importance. That, of course, was the error-it is in error and it has been recognised as such by the Australian Taxation Office-in sending out letters to people in three States or Territories of Australia concerning their tax file numbers. What needs to be clearly understood is the basis on which that was done. As we all know, as of 1 April this year a new tax file position comes into force. If someone has not provided his tax file number by that time, he could be liable for paying tax at the highest marginal rate. In order to assist taxpayers of Australia the Tax Office determined that it would send letters to taxpayers for whom it had records, in respect of their existing tax file numbers, to confirm with them that those tax file numbers were still operable and that they would subsequently need to fill in the appropriate forms.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some people have been dead seven years, you clown.

—With respect to my colleague on the other side who just referred to me as a clown, it has been accepted by the Commissioner of Taxation-indeed, the Treasurer and the Government-that some letters have been sent to people inappropriately and, indeed, to dead people. We accept that that is the case. There is no question about it. The Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Boucher, has apologised for that. He has not stood behind a lame duck excuse but has said that there has been a breakdown in the Tax Office's records and communications and that the matter would be reviewed. He did not run and hide.
—He could not hide; there were 50,000 mistakes out there.

—The Commissioner went straight to the Privacy Commissioner. He did not race off to a press conference, as the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) would have done, to make outrageous statements, for example, about the collection of household information by the Australian Bureau of Statistics and what a dreadful thing that might be. He did not race off to a press conference and say that a person had received a tax file number when he had been dead for seven years. He did not say: `Oh my goodness, isn't this terrible? Oh, what a terrible breakdown in security, in the privacy of tax files'. He did not do that. He said, `We will rectify it. We will go to the Privacy Commissioner, put our cards on the table and get it sorted out'.

SPEECH.PARA: That is exactly what happened. This whole issue of privacy is an absolute laugh. What an absolute joke it is for the honourable member for Kooyong to come in here and lecture us about privacy and lecture this Government about what the Opposition would do to try to enhance the provisions of privacy and security in this legislation. He said-and I agree with him-that he and the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) made an important and significant contribution to the tax file number legislation because they pointed out some difficulties about enforcing privacy. A Privacy Commissioner was the result of that, and we congratulate honourable members for taking that bipartisan approach on that issue.

But that was it. Terrific. They did the job. Why come in here and crow about it now? Why come in and say, `We said you should have a Privacy Commissioner, but obviously sending a letter to a dead person has proved that the job is not being done.'? That is a totally fallacious and spurious argument. It does not hold up when we know what is being done in the Tax Office to overcome the difficulties of privacy and security that really matter; that is, to stop information about people getting through to other people in the community to whom we would rather not see it go, or to other agencies, whether they be government agencies or others. What absolute nonsense it is to suggest that we on this side would not be concerned with issues such as that.

I think it is important to get to the heart of this matter in respect of privacy concerns and what has been put in place by the Tax Office itself. Let us get the question of confidentiality of taxpayer information on the record. There are strict safeguards incorporated in the tax file number legislation. That will quite clearly ensure that the use of the tax file number for maintaining records is restricted to the Australian Taxation Office, which is where it should be. No-one can request a tax file number unless authorised to do so by legislation which has been through both Houses of Parliament. No-one can keep a record of another person's tax file number, use the number in their records or divulge it to another person unless authorised to do so. To overcome that, and to ensure that people will not do that, there are severe penalties, as the honourable member for Kooyong mentioned in his speech this afternoon.

There is bipartisanship here. I do not know why the honourable member for Kooyong was getting so flustered. I suppose that is why he had to make a personal attack on the Treasurer; he had nothing to say, as always. The Privacy Act, which took effect from 1 January 1989, includes guidelines for tax file number record-keepers on measures that should be taken to protect personal privacy. Those guidelines are clear and specify particular matters. I refer the honourable member for Moreton and anybody else on the other side to the document that has been published by the Australian Taxation Office dated December 1988 entitled Updated Tax File Number Information Kit. They will there see a number of documents presented. Firstly, there is one entitled An Overview of the Tax File Number Legislation. It is written in terms of cat, dog and rat so that even those opposite can understand it, and it says very clearly what it does mean. Secondly, there is one written in even clearer language entitled Provisions for the Protection of Individual Privacy. It outlines all the guidelines-they may be interim guidelines but nevertheless guidelines-for privacy and tax file numbers. If one goes to section 4 on page 4 under the heading `Use and Disclosure of Tax File Number Information', it sets out who can use it and how it will be operated.

I mentioned that there was a little bit of bipartisanship here. I refer honourable members who have spoken in this debate to a number of documents which have been published by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration, which I chair; this Committee, of course, has members from both sides of the House. The three documents that I refer to are a report from the former Expenditure Committee, chaired by your good self, Mr Deputy Speaker, in September 1986 entitled A Taxing Problem, which looked at five efficiency audits of the Australian Taxation Office. Another report is A Taxing Review-Review of Six Efficiency Audits of the Australian Taxation Office. The final one is entitled A Tale of Three Cities, which was a review of an efficiency audit of the Australian Taxation Office on taxpayers in unincorporated businesses. In every one of those reports, which incidentally were totally supported by every member of the Committee, both Opposition and Government members-there were no dissenting reports-the recommendations were that there be an upgraded tax file numbering system put into place with appropriate privacy safeguards. In the course of deliberations on that issue, I suggest that those honourable members opposite who are criticising the Australian Taxation Office for what they have or have not put in place in terms of privacy safeguards should go particularly to the transcript of evidence of the Committee that looked at the question of taxpayers in unincorporated businesses. The transcript of evidence, which is a public record and was incorporated into the records of the Parliament, shows that not only has the Australian Taxation Office said that a tax file number system is important in improving the efficiency of the tax system in this country but so has the independent Australian Audit Office. It is most enlightening to go to these documents.

As far as the question of security is concerned, one of the leading members of the Australian Taxation Office in this area, when giving evidence to the Committee, said that, because of concerns raised by some people, encryption was now being utilised by the Australian Taxation Office so that computer fraud and hacking could not take effect and that, through the in-dial facilities that are utilised in the Australian Taxation Office, information would be protected because of this encryption. He went on to say that a number of other measures were being taken to improve security. He mentioned that passwords were required at the terminals themselves and that right through the various levels of users in the Australian Taxation Office-on the terminals, at the main frame computer and so on-one had to have passwords and that variation gradings of security clearances were necessary. The whole system would stop people with a personal computer, as was suggested in a ludicrous press release put out by Senator Bishop, or using similar sorts of exercises breaking into the Australian Taxation Office in order to get access to information. Those privacy matters were obviously of great concern. The press release goes on to say that the question of the access to that data base was most important. Again I refer honourable members to that transcript of evidence. Mr Highfield, from the Australian Taxation Office, and their computer expert, Mr Seymour, were talking about it.

The tax file number system is, as I keep saying, solely administered by and from the Australian Taxation Office. There is no electronic link between the computer installations at the Office and other agencies. There is no intention to create one. So the ability for people to tap in does not exist. I take honourable members back to the good old days here a couple of years ago when people were saying that the Deakin centre was a terrible location where everyone's records of everything they have ever done in this country were being kept on this massive computer. Members from both sides of the House, including the Finance and Public Administration Committee and the Public Accounts Committee, went there to have a look at it. What did they find? They found a building that had windows, a computer and computer terminals, a building where it was not possible for all the storage capacity of Australia to be kept. That just shows how ludicrous those comments were. But some of those claims are still around today. I categorically state, on evidence submitted on the public record, that that just does not occur; that there is every opportunity taken by the Office to protect the data it collects.

TALK.START.PARA: —Then who is sending out all these letters? Is there a phantom Tax Commissioner somewhere else?

—Only authorised Tax Office staff will have access to the information held on the taxpayer data base. Exchange of information between the Tax Office and other Government departments will continue to be limited to that already authorised under the Income Tax Assessment Act. As I am sure the honourable member knows, that refers to social security exchange of information so that people can properly assess income tax liability. I am sure he has no objections to that.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat that Tax Office staff have access limited to those areas necessary for their work. The fact that the terminals are there, that passwords are necessary, that the computer is there and that all these people who work there have secrecy provisions imposed upon them by the Government means that the opportunity just does not exist. The evidence is overwhelming. I have a stack of it here, and I refer it to the honourable member. As I said a little earlier, I would suggest that the problem was created by the sending out of those letters. It created unnecessary anxiety in the minds of people. The Commissioner of Taxation and the Treasurer have responded to that. I believe that there is a lesson there and that it has been learned. The Privacy Commissioner is satisfied. The Tax Commissioner has put methods in place to overcome difficulties in the future. I, for one, am convinced that the difficulties envisaged will not arise. I believe that the tax file number system will be an important adjunct to improving the efficiency of the tax system in this country. It is certainly needed, as has been proven in the evidence not only to my Committee but to many other committees of the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would not like the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Martin) to be my custodian if he so easily accepts the assurances he has been so prepared to accept. The Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Commissioner of Taxation have both acknowledged already that they cannot provide a failsafe guarantee that more letters are not going to be sent out to the deceased and to people who have changed their address in the last year. Yet honourable members opposite have the audacity to stand here, lecturing us on the propriety of the Commissioner of Taxation and the Treasurer. They have not only conceded their mass errors but also told us that they will continue with the system, but that they have satisfactorily minimised the extent of the errors. The requirements of the Act apply equally to the Taxation Commissioner and the people of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday in this Parliament the Treasurer blamed the people for all this. He said that a breach of the Privacy Act occurred only when a misdirected letter was opened and that the opener, and not the Australian Taxation Office, would have committed the breach. He said that it was not the fault of the Tax Office; it was the fault of the opener of the letter. Section 11 of the Privacy Act defines the Taxation Commissioner as a recipient of the tax file numbers. Section 28 of the Act has already been alluded to by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock); but it is so important and so significant that it is worth repeating. That section states that the Privacy Commissioner has the following functions.
(d) to examine the records of the Commissioner of Taxation to ensure that:
(ii) he or she-
meaning the Commissioner of Taxaton; in this instance it is a he-Mr Trevor Boucher-
is taking adequate measures to prevent the unlawful disclosure of the tax file number information that he-
that is, Mr Boucher-
or she holds . . .
We then go into the guidelines for the security of tax file number information. Guideline 3.2 states:
Tax file number recipients-
meaning the Taxation Commissioner-

shall take all reasonable steps in the circumstances to ensure that security safeguards and procedures are in place to prevent unauthorised access to, modification or disclosure of, and loss of, such information, whether that information is stored in physical or electronic form.

There is not very much that is electronic about a letter. It is very uncomplicated. It is stored, and the Tax Office is not supposed to lose it. That places on the Taxation Commissioner, if he must post out letters-he does not even have to post them to people-the responsibility, not to get it nearly right, but to get it 100 per cent right. If he is a jerry builder who has an attitude of `near enough is good enough', let him come out into the open now and say, `That is my policy. That is my approach. Near enough is good enough'. He should not hide behind this lairy language of satisfactorily minimising the chances of errors. He is a jerry builder. It boils down to `near enough is good enough'. I contend that, in an issue as important as this, it is a totally reckless and irresponsible approach.

The previous speaker, the honourable member for Macarthur, tried to portray a picture of Mr Boucher running along to the Privacy Commissioner and saying, `Help. I think I have made a mistake. Guide me'. I will tell honourable members why Mr Boucher had to front the Privacy Commissioner. It was because I dobbed him in. It is as simple as that. My telephone was ringing like that in a starting price bookmaker's shop, with people whose spouses were deceased ringing. One of my constituents had three letters in his letter box at home and one in his post office box-all belonging to other people. He said, `I have five tax file numbers. What am I going to do?'. I was not going to say, `Go your hardest'. Not me! This is the type of gross error that has been made.

The Government cannot guarantee the system. It has admitted that it cannot guarantee it. It is all right to come in and try to belittle the Opposition for raising this issue; but the realities are that, in government, one has an obligation to ensure that the administration of the country works properly. Honourable members opposite cannot say, as the Treasurer has said, `Do not blame me. I am going back to my office'. He has sent in a couple of yearlings to run his race. He cannot follow that approach. He has to face the music. No more important thing has been put in place in recent months than the requirement for every person to have a tax file number and the use that is being made of it. It has become necessary only because of the growth of taxation levels in this country. If the Hawke Government was not into people's pockets to the extent that it has been, people would not have turned in such numbers to tax cheating, as sadly we have been told they have. The biggest tax cheat in this country is the Treasurer-nobody else. He is the one who has been into people's pockets. Yet he has the audacity to say, `You all have to have a brand because I cannot trust you'.

I turn to the words of the Privacy Commissioner, as reported in the media a couple of days ago. The Privacy Commissioner has a responsibility to ensure that a post-out system is watertight-or there should be no post-out at all. The media reported him as follows:
Mr O'Connor said he would ask Mr Boucher to adopt a more secure system if the Tax Office continued sending the numbers after the computer check.

We now have the computer being blamed. It is interesting to refer to a press release that Mr Boucher put out a couple of days ago. Listen to this. He said that the problems arose because in some cases the Tax Office had not been notified of a change in address. I ask honourable members: how can dead people notify changes of address? The father of the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull) passed away in September 1982. Whom do honourable members think the Taxation Office wrote to? It wrote to the father of the honourable member for Fadden. I have constituents whose loved ones passed away five or six years ago. Only two days ago another case came to the notice of my office. A man received a letter addressed to a woman he did not know had ever lived in his house. He started checking and found that she had left that address eight years previously. He rang her to tell her that he had her tax file number. She said, `I have not put in a return for 12 years. What are they writing to me for? I am an old lady. I am a war widow. Leave me alone'. That is the type of careless, sloppy approach that is causing people on this side to be concerned.
Let us go back to the Privacy Commissioner. He said:
I will discuss with him-
meaning Mr Boucher-
that if he wishes to continue the circulation of the numbers, a more secure system could be developed. In areas of privacy, it is desirable that the situation be stopped until it is sorted out.

Fancy that! He knows it all. Good on him. Mr O'Connor's first job, his first official complaint, was probably the letter I sent to him on 17 February. He knows what it is in theory. But honourable members opposite have no right to badger the Privacy Commissioner and say, `We have to get these letters out', when there is no real need to send out the letters. And honourable members opposite have admitted it, because Mr Boucher has continually claimed that the only reason the letters are being sent out is to help the public. There is no real need to do it; it is a public relations act. The system has been put in jeopardy.

The Government has fulfilled many of the predictions that were made in terms of the inability of any government to give secure guarantees. The Government should stop the post-out now. Its system will work without the post-out. But it should not subject another 320,000 people to errors, because 17.5 per cent of the people change their address annually and each year 120,000 people die. The Government will make tens of thousands of mistakes in the weeks ahead. It should stop the post-out now while it is in a position to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The people in the gallery today can see what the Liberal Party and the National Party are on about. All they are on about is having a bit of a laugh and a chuckle down here; not about the legislation. What they are having a laugh and a chuckle about amongst themselves is the fact that an error was made in the Australian Taxation Office-an error that has been admitted by the Commissioner-in sending out notices to people who should not have received them. One has to ask why this matter of public importance has been raised today. The only reason we have it is the actions of the Australian Taxation Office. As the Commissioner has pointed out, he has apologised and said that it should not have happened, and he and his staff are trying to make sure that it does not happen again. But that is the whole thing: this Opposition really does not have a focal point; it does not have any policies; there is nothing of substance in its attacks.

SPEECH.PARA: All the House heard from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) was a frothy attack, playing to the gallery, much like the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Donald Cameron) did. It was all froth and bubble and no substance. Yet the honourable member for Moreton has the audacity to start lecturing us about tax cheating. He is a member of a party that opposed every measure that this Government introduced to put some decency into the taxation system. When we ended entertainment expenses, who opposed it? It was the Liberal Party and the National Party. Entertainment expenses enabled people to go out on slush accounts and book it up to the taxpayer. We said that was not fair. They said it was fair and they fought us tooth and nail.

With the fringe benefits tax, where previously one could take fringe benefits instead of cash as one's income and pay tax only on one's cash income and pass the rest on to the taxpayer, who opposed that? It was the Liberal Party and the National Party once again. Who opposed the capital gains tax? It was the Liberal Party and the National Party once again. Every measure that we have brought in to make the taxation system decent has been opposed by the Liberal Party and the National Party.

They opposed the introduction of the upgraded tax file number when it was first introduced, and that did not surprise us, given their track record of opposing every measure to make the taxation system more decent. You would be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, as would the people of Australia, that we moved to make the taxation system decent, taking it away from the painters and dockers days of the Opposition when they were in government, when the rorts were so open that anyone who had access to a smart accountant or lawyer could pay no tax at all. In fact one of their own commissioners told them-in words such as these-that it was not a matter of the rich paying their fair share of tax; it was whether the rich paid any tax at all. That was the sort of system that Opposition members were happy to have when they were in government. They have opposed everything we have done. Yet they come in here today and the honourable member for Moreton talks about tax cheating.

As a result of the measures we have introduced, we have dropped the top tax rate from 60c, which Opposition members were happy to have when they were in government, down to 49c. The 48c rate has gone down to 40c. And for the people on low incomes, the 30c bottom rate which Mr Howard was happy to have as Treasurer has gone down to 24c, and we are going to lower it again this year. That has only been possible because we have repaired the taxation system, despite the opposition of the hecklers who have lectured us today about the upgraded tax file number. I never noticed in any of their attacks any mention of the fact that the legislation-for which the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has responsibility-was deficient. There was not one word about the legislation. This whole argument and the whole waste of time of the House put up by the Opposition was because letters were sent out by the Australian Taxation Office, and-

TALK.START.PARA: —And they are still going to send them out. Another batch will be going out tomorrow.

—The interjection acknowledges that. The only reason we have a matter of public importance on this subject today is those letters. It has nothing to do with the legislation. For pure audacity it takes a lot to knock off a Liberal. When one goes back and has a look at some of the press reports in the days when we passed this legislation, one starts having a look at the impact that they had. The simple fact is that when this Government brought that legislation in, it did not bulldoze it through the Parliament. We took account of everything that the Opposition parties said. A report in the Sun-Herald of 30 October last year said:

SPEECH.PARA: Senior Opposition sources said that Mr Brown would recommend to shadow Cabinet tomorrow that it accept the Bill following the Government's acceptance of virtually all Opposition amendments.

It has been acknowledged by this side of the Parliament that the Opposition did play a very constructive role in putting up amendments that in our view strengthened the Bill. The honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) must take some credit for that. He at least saw the need for this legislation and was prepared to work with the Government. We acknowledge his contribution. Another report, in the Sydney Morning Herald of 1 November-and this is interesting in view of the fact that the Deputy Leader of the Opposition raised this matter of public importance-states:
At that point-
and we are talking about a break in a shadow Cabinet meeting-

the shadow Treasurer, Mr Peacock, sent a letter to the Treasurer saying the Opposition would support the Bill if the Government agreed to three new Coalition amendments to strengthen privacy safeguards.
And the Government's response, reported in the same article:
Only three hours later, Mr Keating wrote back saying that a full meeting of the Hawke ministry had agreed to the changes.

Yet today the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has come in here criticising the privacy provisions of this legislation, about which he wrote a letter to the Treasurer, and the Treasurer acknowledged his letter by saying that he agreed to the changes.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member is a fool.
—Order! The Deputy Leader of the Opposition will cease interjecting and should withdraw the allegation that the honourable member for Canning is a fool.
—With great reluctance, I withdraw.
—Fancy being belted around by a powder puff. Fancy having a verbal attack on one from old Gucci over there.
—Order! The honourable member for Canning will not pursue the matter either.

—No, it is not worth it. I thank you for your guidance, Mr Deputy Speaker. But in the end, Powder Puff, it says, `Liberal win on privacy changes'. Now the powder puffs are up here again today, getting stuck into us about privacy. In the transcript of what the Deputy Leader of the Opposition had to say, there is not one word about the privacy requirements of this legislation that he attacked. There is not one attack that can be substantiated against the Treasurer. Then we have all this mock horror about the Treasurer not being here. Why should he be? The Treasurer has done everything right. The Treasurer does not have to answer non-attacks. Why should he? He has better things to do than sit around here like the Deputy Leader of the Opposition does.

SPEECH.PARA: When it comes to privacy, this Government has done everything it can to make sure that the privacy requirements under this legislation have been upheld and the Treasurer, in Question Time today, reiterated that. While I am talking about privacy, I can remember last year that the Western Mail of Western Australia, as it was then, had a front page article reporting that records of the Western Australian Police Force were being sold to people-that is, the names and addresses, incomes and ranks of police officers in Western Australia were being sold on a commercial basis. That was being openly flaunted on the front page of a major newspaper in Western Australia. I took that matter up with the Privacy Foundation, but I never received a reply, in spite of writing to it twice. I have never heard a member of the Opposition here take up that issue or any other issue to do with privacy.

As they have no policies, they have no attacks. They prefer the sort of debate that we have had here today where we have a cosy sit-around chat and a bit of a laugh and a giggle, with a few jokes thrown in, on a very serious topic. The matter had no substance to it and that is why it is very hard for members on the Government side to respond to it. There is nothing to respond to. The whole of the contribution from the Opposition today was underwritten by those letters sent out by the Taxation Office. I would dare to say that had it not been for those letters, we would not have been having this debate today.

TALK.START.PARA: —A very serious matter.

—A very serious matter-of course it is, and Mr Boucher, to his credit, has owned up and said he is going to look into the problem and fix it. But that is where the problem lies. It is not with the Treasurer. It is with the administration of the Tax Office and the staff are doing everything they can about it. In conclusion, the charges laid by the Opposition today have no substance to them. The Treasurer does not have to respond to them. He has done everything required of him in this legislation. It is about time members of the Opposition got their act together, stopped arguing among themselves and gave us some alternative policies.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired. The debate is concluded.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing and Sessional Orders be suspended as would prevent the Deputy Leader of the Opposition from moving forthwith:

That this House calls upon the Government to take all reasonable steps to ensure that security safeguards and procedures are in place to prevent unauthorised access to and disclosure of tax file information.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will second the motion and I will reserve my right to speak.
—Do you wish to take that now?
—No.

—Well, I am moving it and it will be seconded. I have already made a speech on the matter. People on this side of the House do regard the breaches that have occurred as so serious as to move for the suspension of Standing Orders. There is no need for me to reiterate at length the reasons. They have been put before the House this afternoon and they have been put in terms that are taken from the Government's own privacy legislation. So the Government will now move against us at its own risk and its own peril, for what in fact it is about to do is denying us the opportunity to affirm what it has provided for in its own form of legislation. In other words, it is denying itself.
—Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I second the motion. The reason that the Opposition is so keen to present this is the importance of the issue. Had I had a little longer to speak earlier, I would have mentioned the fact that in the next day or so the Commissioner of Taxation intends posting out more than four million more letters, and those letters will be addressed to some 320,000 people who would have shifted since they put in their last tax return, and quite a number will be sent to people who unfortunately have met their demise since that time. It is not a flippant issue, as the two Government speakers endeavoured to portray it as being earlier this afternoon. It is a most serious issue, because this tax file number system is supposed to have total integrity.

SPEECH.PARA: Yet the Commissioner of Taxation is about to commence reposting, after having sent 1.1 million letters to Queensland, Western Australia and the Northern Territory, of which more than 50,000 to 60,000 went astray, being wrongly addressed. He is now about to resume posting and claims it is all right to resume posting on the basis that he has satisfactorily minimised the error content. If he is going to use as a yardstick those who put in tax returns for the 1987-88 year and post letters to all those people in Victoria, New South Wales, Tasmania and South Australia, there is going to be an error rate in excess of 300,000. That means there are going to be some 300,000 letters floating across those States which may end up in anybody's hands and could be subjected to misuse. It is important for the ordinary citizen that this should not happen, because if people are as dishonest as we are told they are, people will be able to misuse those numbers when they obtain a job and the like. Some time down the track poor old John Brown, the person whom the number was originally intended for, will suddenly be told by the Australian Taxation Office that he has not paid tax or declared all his income. That is how serious it is.

Yet the two junior Government members came in here describing it as a matter of mirth and laughter about which the Opposition is not serious. Well, we are serious. We are putting the Government to the test right now. The motion before the House calls on the Government to take all reasonable steps to ensure that security safeguards and proceedings are in place--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! That is not the matter before the House. The matter before the House is that Standing Orders be suspended.

—Well, I can speak to that very easily and just as quickly. The reason we are taking this as seriously as we are is that we believe that the issue is so vitally important and that the whole tax file information system deserves to be secure and safe and, more importantly, it is a right of the citizens of this country that we, as a parliament, have an obligation to protect. That is why we are moving for the suspension of Standing Orders.

SPEECH.PARA: I have been watching the Government Ministers over there in a total flurry, not knowing how to handle it. They do not want to let us present it. They are obviously on the run because they are embarrassed. The whole tax file thing has been an utter fiasco and an utter disgrace of administration of the worst order. The Taxation Commissioner will blame people who did not write back saying that they have shifted, and that will include dead people. People do not have an obligation to keep writing to the Taxation Commissioner. Once is bad enough as far as the vast majority of the population is concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Moreton might address the matter that Standing Orders be suspended and not canvass the motion.

—It is utterly urgent because of all those things and because the Taxation Commissioner is on the verge of disregarding the Privacy Act and the obligation upon him to make sure that the system is totally secure and that he takes-to use the words from the Act-`all reasonable care'. This has not been done and that is why we have moved for the suspension of Standing Orders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —There really is no--
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I want to speak and I want to know whether this closes the debate.
—I have no idea what the Leader of the House is going to say. The call is to my right. I call the Leader of the House.

—There is no need to support this motion. The Government's position on this was made quite clear by the speakers in the debate on the matter of public importance and also by the position put by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in answer to questions during Question Time.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. A minute ago I asked you whether the fact that the Minister was speaking would close the debate. You said that if I waited I would find out. He is still not indicating whether he is going to close the debate. If he is, I contend there are other people who have a right to speak before the time runs out on them.
—Order! The Minister is in order in canvassing one way or the other this matter. The call goes from the right to the left in the House.

—As I said, the Treasurer answered this adequately in Question Time today. Obviously the Commissioner for Taxation takes his obligations in this regard seriously. He was attempting to create a situation of assistance to the general public on a position which was ultimately adopted by this Parliament, with the support of both sides of the chamber. That is why those changes went through. All the assurances that he will proceed properly have been given. For that reason there is no requirement to suspend Standing Orders.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. My point of order is that the Minister is not speaking to the motion. As was pointed out by you several times during the speech by the honourable member for Moreton, the motion before the Chair is for the suspension of Standing Orders, and the suspension of Standing Orders is to debate a motion calling upon the Government, not the Commissioner of Taxation, to take all reasonable steps--

—Order! The honourable member for Moncrieff will resume her seat. The matter before the Chair is the motion moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition and seconded by the honourable member for Moreton to suspend Standing Orders. The Minister, as I understand him, is canvassing the reason why Standing Orders should not be suspended, and he is entirely in order.
—Clearly this is generating too much emotion in the House. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the question be now put.
Question put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question put:
That the motion (Mr Peacock's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.
