DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF NATIONAL MEDICAL CYCLOTRON FACILITY, ROYAL PRINCE ALFRED HOSPITAL, SYDNEY

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Approval of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the Committee has duly reported to Parliament: Construction of National Medical Cyclotron facility, Royal Prince Alfred Hospital, Sydney.

The proposed public work provides for the construction of a building at the Royal Prince Alfred Hospital in Sydney to house the national medical cyclotron, associated laboratories and facilities for radiopharmaceutical production. The work also includes refurbishment of a nearby patient clinic to house a position emission tomography (PET) camera and a rapid transfer system linking it with the cyclotron building.

The national medical cyclotron will be used to produce radioisotopes for the immediate medical application of ultra short life radioisotopes in the clinical positron emission tomography (PET) centre facility at Royal Prince Alfred Hospital, Sydney; and for the nationwide distribution to other major hospitals in Australia of the longer life radioisotopes used in other medical applications. In this latter role, the cyclotron will complement the HIFAR reactor at Lucas Heights and will ensure that the complete range of radioisotopes is, for the first time, readily accessible to medicine in Australia.

The cyclotron and associated laboratories will be housed in one building. It will comprise a basement for the storage and treatment of radioactive waste, a ground floor to accommodate the cyclotron and laboratories, and a first floor for offices and plant room. The cyclotron will be the focus of the building and will be housed within a 1.9 metre-thick concrete vault. Careful consideration has been given to the safe handling of radioactive substances. To prevent accidental releases, the facility has been designed on the principle of double containment and all waste products will be controlled. An essential feature of the total proposal is the refurbishment of part of the second floor of the hospital's Albert Pavilion to house the PET centre in the mainstream clinical area. The PET camera is being funded separately by the hospital. The third major component of the work is the construction of a transfer system to deliver the products of the cyclotron to patients in the PET centre. Because of the very short radioactive half lives of the radioisotopes used in PET, their time in transit must be minimal. The cyclotron building will be linked to the PET centre by an underground conduit between the buildings.

The cyclotron building has been designed to follow the pavilion style of other buildings in the hospital complex. The limit of cost estimate for the building works totals $8.9m at January 1988 prices. This is slightly less than half the total project cost, including equipment, consultant fees and training. The Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation will manage and supervise construction of the cyclotron as well as the installation and commissioning of major equipment. In collaboration, the hospital planning staff will manage and supervise construction of the PET facility and transfer link. Completion is envisaged about 20 months after approval. I believe it is expedient that this work be carried out and I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the motion moved by the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) in relation to the cyclotron facility. I am grateful that the Minister passed to us the details of these particular references earlier today. We have had a bit of time to look at them. There is no question but that we will be taking into account those references with a great deal more consideration than has been possible in the past. In this particular case we are very happy for the project to go ahead and look forward in the future to the Minister explaining in more detail to us how the cyclotron facility works.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: CONSTRUCTION OF NEW COMMUNICATIONS AND RECRUIT SCHOOLS AT HMAS CERBERUS, CRIB POINT, VICTORIA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Construction of new Communications and Recruit Schools at HMAS Cerberus, Crib Point, Victoria.

The proposed work now before the House is for new communications and recruit schools at HMAS Cerberus, 70 kilometres south-east of Melbourne. This proposal is the second phase of a staged redevelopment of facilities at HMAS Cerberus, which is one of the principal training establishments for Royal Australian Navy personnel. The first stage of the redevelopment is nearing completion, with several facilities, including a marina and boat ramp, already in operation. The bulk of the works, including a new seamanship school and a wharf, are due to be completed by mid-1989. On 8 March 1989 the Public Works Committee tabled a favourable report recommending that construction of this second stage of the redevelopment should proceed. The Committee is also currently considering a proposal for the upgrading of living-in accommodation at HMAS Cerberus and I expect that its report on this stage of the redevelopment will be tabled in the House later this session.

As I said, this current proposal is for the provision of new facilities for the communications and recruit schools. At present the Communications School provides over 50 courses ranging from the traditional morse and flags through to complex electronic equipment training. The Recruit School offers a 12-week basic training course for new Royal Australian Navy personnel, as well as shorter courses for Royal Australian Navy Reserve recruits. At present the activities of both these schools are carried out in a number of facilities located on the base. These facilities are generally unsatisfactory for the training activities of both schools and most will be demolished to allow construction of the new works. The communications and recruit schools' functions will be temporarily relocated to enable training programs to continue during this construction period. The works proposed for the new communications school are a two-storey building and an adjacent outdoor visual training area. The facilities to be provided include: both general purpose classrooms and special purpose technical rooms fitted with communications equipment; a lecture theatre and library; and administration and instructors offices. The proposed recruit school involves two new buildings: an administrative instructional building with an adjacent partially covered parade ground; and a recruit amenities and functions building including a canteen and recreation centre. The estimated cost of this proposal is $15.95m at April 1988 prices, comprising $9.8m for the communications school and $6.15m for the recruit school. This equates to $16.68m at January 1989 prices.

Subject to the approval of the House to proceed, it is intended to call the first tenders in mid-1989. The on-site work force during the construction period is expected to peak at between 110 and 120. The facilities for both schools are expected to be completed by the end of 1991.

HMAS Cerberus has both historical and heritage significance. It was the first training establishment created specifically for the Royal Australian Navy and has been in operation for over 60 years. Today there are still a large number of traditional buildings on the base as well as formal gardens and tracts of natural coastal land of ecological importance. In its report the committee acknowledges the efforts of both the Department of Defence and my Department's Australian Construction Services in designing buildings which will be in sympathy with the historic character of the base. The Committee further considers the merit in involving heritage organisations in consultations on heritage issues at an early phase in the planning process. In all major Commonwealth development proposals such as this my Department ensures that the necessary requirements of the Heritage Act are always undertaken. To this end consultations will occur. I would like to thank the Committee for the support that it has given to this proposal, and I commend the motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Downer Mr A.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition does not oppose this motion that the Government has moved, concerning the communication and recruit schools and HMAS Cerberus. This facility will obviously be of some use and will be warmly welcomed, in particular, by those personnel involved with the Royal Australian Navy. I note that the facility will cost $16.7m. That represents a fairly small part of the total capital works program of the Commonwealth in 1988-89 of $3.4 billion. Of course, that includes the off-Budget authorities as well as on-Budget funding, which in itself is $2.2 billion, a 17 per cent increase over the previous year's figure. In passing I point out the incredible fact that some 50 per cent of all non-residential construction in Australia is carried out by the Commonwealth, State and local governments. That is an enormously high proportion.

SPEECH.PARA: The Public Works Committee is obliged to examine projects such as this work done at HMAS Cerberus. One of the things I would like the Public Works Committee to do in the future when it is looking at these projects-which it has not done in this particular case-is to examine the most efficient and cost-effective way of constructing these sorts of facilities and not to take on face value figures and proposals that the Government puts forward to the Committee in terms of methods of construction. For example, I have argued in this House for some time that the Government should be considering, on its own construction projects, greater use of subcontractors than is currently the case. There is no doubt whatsoever that taxpayers' money would be saved on the HMAS Cerberus project as well as most of the other Commonwealth projects-we are talking about $2.2 billion-worth of projects in an on-Budget sense and $3.4 billion altogether including off-Budget authorities-if greater use of sub-contractors was made. Hundreds of millions of dollars could be saved. We could save about 20 per cent of the cost of a project like this through the use of subcontractors.

It is a matter of concern to me that the Government does not consider the use of subcontractors to be consistent with its industrial relations policy and broader industrial objectives. We on this side of the House consider the protection of the taxpayers' dollar to be one of the fundamental responsibilities of this Parliament. I would hope that in the future the Public Works Committee takes up that responsibility and receives from the Minister a specific reference to examine the cost savings that could come from the use of the subcontracting system rather than the current system which the Government uses.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: AFFIRMATIVE ACTION (EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY FOR WOMEN) AMENDMENT BILL 1989

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 March, on motion by Mr Peter Morris:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr Reith had moved by way of amendment:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for its effective discrimination against women through the pursuit of policies which are biased against families and which have resulted in six years of declining living standards of women and their families'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was perhaps very appropriate that yesterday when we began debating this measure, relatively minor in itself, it was International Women's Day because that provides ample justification for the Opposition's amendment which has the effect of enlarging the debate beyond the narrow area of equal employment opportunity for women legislation as such. I will return to that. Nevertheless, the legislation before the House, the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Amendment Bill, makes some amendments, appropriate in themselves, primarily to the 1986 Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Act and it is not opposed by the Opposition. I recall that the Opposition supported that Act in the pursuit of its strong commitment to genuine equal opportunity in employment and the removal of discrimination and its strong commitment to equal opportunity and appointment based on merit, but without positive discrimination. The Opposition parted company with the Government in respect of the Equal Employment Opportunity (Commonwealth Authorities) Bill in 1987-ironically, a measure with a softer title than the 1986 measure. It did this because that Bill, now an Act, took what we judged as a definite step towards specific and quantitative equal employment opportunity programs which were in effect the equivalent of quotas.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not reopen that old debate but it was at that time that I, among others, parted company with the more radical feminists. All along I was an advocate of a voluntary approach to this issue as the preferred way forward. At the time that was not just a cop-out. In 1986 there was a mechanism ready to hand. In September of that year, under the auspices of the Business Council of Australia, a decision was taken to establish a private sector council for equal employment opportunity as a positive self-regulation initiative with the objective of fostering the continuing goodwill of business and the securing of a genuine commitment in the private sector to equality of opportunity programs. It was my view then that such a private sector, self-managed and voluntary approach had a great deal to offer in achieving really effective and meaningful change towards greater equality of opportunity in employment for women.

At all events, at this remove I believe it can be fairly said that the battle in principle, of the importance of equal opportunity for women and awareness of the issue, has largely been won. Mr Paddy McGuinness yesterday in the Australian referred to that as one of the great social advances of the past few decades. The battle, as I say, has largely been won and the pressing of positive discrimination for women via a continuing insistence on formal quotas and the like, while it may on the surface appear to ameliorate perceived discrimination, brings problems and disadvantages of itself, including the demeaning of women generally as actual appointments of women are put down by the suggestion that `she got the job just because she is a woman'. That, equally, goes against genuine equality of opportunity.

The question of equal employment opportunity and, indeed, of enhancing the lifestyle, status and fair and equitable treatment of women goes much further than this as set out in the amendment moved by the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith). The amendment states:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for its effective discrimination against women through the pursuit of policies which are biased against families and which have resulted in six years of declining living standards of women and their families'.

This is particularly so in the tax area. This is, of course, the highest taxing government in the history of Australia. We have seen that impact on families on average weekly earnings through an increase from about 17 per cent in 1983 to 23 to 24 per cent today in the proportion of their income which goes in tax. The recent authoritative study by the respected Australian Institute of Family Studies shows that this fall in disposable income is greater for families than for single people and greater for ordinary middle income taxpayers than for those on higher incomes. In particular I refer to page 10 of that report which states:
Families have done worse than single persons-
that is, over the period from 1976-77 to 1988-89, but particularly from 1984-85 to 1988-89-

and the extent of their loss rises with the number of their children. This difference between single persons and families relates to the fall in the real value of the family components in the tax system. In 1976-77, a taxpayer on AWE with a spouse and two children was given a 46 per cent reduction in tax compared to a single person. By 1988-89, their percentage had dropped to 26 per cent.

Under this present Government's tax system, it costs to opt for the role of remaining at home as wife and mother looking after children. What is not recognised is the cost of having children. The reform of this system is important. We hear about tax cuts which are in the offing, but in many ways this is a phoney exercise. What has happened is that the recent and prospective increases in home loan interest rates and mortgage payments result in the average Australian family paying for these tax cuts in advance, so to speak. It is paying out more, due to those rises in interest rates and mortgage payments, than the amount of the promised tax cuts to be given in July. The fact is that, even with the July tax cuts, Australians will not break even until early 1991, given the cost of increasing interest rates.

Another area in which women are not treated as fairly and as equitably as one would wish is in the industrial relations area which is the real crunch area. There is no doubt that the rigidity and inflexibility of the Australian wages and industrial relations systems are major factors inhibiting greater opportunity for women. What is needed is part time work and, in particular, more permanent part time work with hours attuned to the requirements of a woman who is a mother getting as much time as possible with her young children. The rigidity of present awards often rules this out. I draw attention to the fact that the centrepiece of the Opposition's industrial relations policy is voluntary employment agreements where appropriate hours of work would be a key element in the whole negotiation. In this way our industrial relations approach in introducing greater flexibility in all aspects of the employer-employee situation, particularly in relation to hours, very much meets the needs of families in the 1980s, where increasing numbers of married women want part time work as an alternative to the often difficult choice between full time work on the one hand and staying at home full time on the other. In this way the industrial relations policy of the Opposition is very important indeed.

There have been many reports about the concerns of the Labor Party and the Government at the so-called gender voting gap in the electorate-the falling off in support for the Government, particularly among women. So what happens? We are told that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) got the members of the Government together and, among other things, said, `You have got to moderate your language', referring especially to Paul, whose macho accent is putting women voters off.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member will refer to honourable members in this House by their correct titles.

—Especially the Treasurer, the honourable member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), whose macho accent was said to be putting the women voters off. What a line it was! As the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) said, how old fashioned, chauvinistic, out of date, and patronising can one be to Australian women. The truth is that the falling off in support by Australian women for the Hawke Government has nothing to do with Paul's speech, coarse as it often is, or with the accent of any other member of the Government. It has everything to do with the manifest decline in living standards under this Government as tax and mortgage payment hikes and inflation eat away at the real disposable incomes of ordinary families. It is Australian women, mothers and wives in particular, who come up against it in the supermarkets, who have to cope with the shrinking purchasing power of the household income. It is the opportunity and a fair go for women in the wider area which is important.

SPEECH.PARA: What underlies the adverse impact on Australian living standards is the failure of the Hawke Government's economic policies. While respected economic writers such as Ross Gittins blazon forth headlines such as `Keating has lost control' and `The Government has lost its way', the Treasurer and the Government fail to tell us in this place about the situation as it is. The Government has lost control; it has lost its way; and the Treasurer has lost credibility. All this is reflected in a falling off not only in the women's vote but also in total support for the Hawke Government.

Back at Budget time the Treasurer said that inflation would be down to 4 or 4 1/2 per cent by now. In fact, it is stuck, if not rising, at around 8 per cent, more than double that of our trading partners. The deficit in the balance of payments, according to the Budget, was going to come down to $9.5 billion in 1988-89. After seven months it is already greater than that and it is on course to be of the order of $16 billion-a deficit of $1 billion to $1.5 billion a month; $50m extra into hock every day. The result is that the overseas debt is rising inexorably to and beyond $120 billion-a debt of Third World proportions. This is despite the current favourable high prices for our exports. I ask: What will it be like when the world economy slackens later in the year, as predicted, and export prices weaken?

I end on this note: I had thought to ask the following as a question at Question Time today, but I raise it now. Early in May 1986 I directed a question to the Treasurer, amidst some hilarity-the content of the question, though, was deadly serious-drawing attention to the precarious state of the Australian economy. A few weeks later that was followed-I do not say it was because of it-by the Treasurer's now famous banana republic statement. With inflation at this time stuck at nearly 8 per cent and the balance of payments deficit in no way abating, a `do nothing' stance by this Government, which is what we have, stemming from election considerations, is the stuff of which market crises and subsequent recession are made. Does the Government accept the awful responsibility of a continued `do nothing' stance, or will it take the decisive action which the gravity of the situation requires?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lamb Mr A.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards) has repeated what so many speakers on the other side have done, and that is to change the whole course of this debate. Opposition speakers have attempted not to talk about equal opportunity but to bring in some rather ill-conceived ideas based on their propaganda, the booklet they call Future Directions. I think the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) is correct in calling it `Futile Diversions'. Honourable members opposite have tried to bring in a series of figures and facts which do not exist at all. They existed in the past; they exist in the figments of their imaginations. I heard someone describe the Opposition policy and program as looking through the rear vision mirror, giving a very narrow profile of the reality of the past.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition speakers are thinking only about the good days that occurred perhaps once or twice during a year, thinking of the good examples and ignoring the reality of the past. I suggest that if we were to ask women whether they wanted to return to live in the environment put together by the Opposition of 30 or 40 years ago they would all answer a resounding no, because those were the days before we had more humane divorce laws, before we had more progressive affirmative action laws, and when a woman was not even a supporter but was seen as a chattel. Very often she was seen as a person who had to stay at home. She had no choice. Regardless of the mental, psychological or physical abuse heaped upon her, it was her right and bounden duty in society to put up with that. That was the role of women. And that is what comes through with the return to this rear vision mirror, to this narrow road back into the past, which the Liberal Party would like to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —I talked specifically of industrial relations policy.

—I am coming to the industrial relations area. The honourable member for Berowra said that he had put forward and supported the idea of the Business Council of Australia on self-regulation; that, if left to their own devices, women would rise to the top, that they would have an equal place. But we know-women know out there-that, if it had been left to the men who dominate commerce, who dominate academia, who dominate decision making in this country at whatever level and in whatever avenue, there would never have been any change.

SPEECH.PARA: We have to accept that we can legislate for certain attitudinal changes, we can legislate to put into practice reforms in areas such as the home, but we cannot legislate to make the behaviour of husbands and wives change; we cannot legislate for men to change their attitudes about the women in their families. We keep out of the home with our legislation, but we have a right, an obligation, to put into place legislation that will oblige employers, businesses, to be non-discriminating, to get rid of discrimination, to get rid of the barriers that prevent the best people from progressing in the employment heirarchy. We can do that. We can put that into place.

The honourable member for Berowra relied upon the Institute of Family Studies booklet launched last week to support the Opposition's claim that somehow families are worse off now. The Opposition has totally confused families with women. It uses the words interchangeably. Women are still the centre of most families but not all families have a female head. Sometimes it is shared; sometimes there is a female head. Most sole families are headed by single mothers struggling to bring up their children. What the Opposition and the Institute of Family Studies did not say is that they were looking purely at how much tax was taken out. They did not consider how much money went from the tax system back to the families. Did we hear anything about the family allowance supplement? Did we hear anything about the cost of medical insurance? No. If we were to look at each individual family on its merits, at how much a family received in education allowances, children going to government schools and how much it costs, if we were to look at medical insurance through Medicare-insurance which families once had to pay for, and two million people in Australia could not afford medical insurance-if we look at the family allowance supplement and not just at this narrow spouse rebate that the honourable member for Berowra and others wanted to talk about, we would get a proper perspective of how much this Government has done for women and families. I will come back to that later.

A lot has been said by the Opposition about affirmative action in the work place doing nothing for women in the home; that somehow affirmative action in paid employment and education areas, to which this Bill specifically refers, actually denigrates women in the home. That is the most distorted logic I have ever heard. There is nothing further from the truth. What women must have if they are to be liberated, to be equal partners in society-or, as the Chinese say, hold up half the sky-is choice. The more educated, the better accepted in society women are by males the happier and more fulfilled they are going to be. Whether at home or in the work place, across our whole culture, the more choices they have the more fulfilled and liberated they are. It is attitudinal changes we are talking about.

We cannot legislate for that in the home, but we can do it by example. If a government argues for affirmative action, then a lot of that will rub off on our general mores in society. If we request it and legislate for it in business and in commerce, then as men come to work side by side equally with women and respect them those attitudinal changes, those societal mores, will transfer more and more into the home. They have not yet done so because we know that most women who work still go home and do the majority of the domestic work. When they work they still take on one and a half or two jobs. Men have a long way to go before we will have affirmative action where it should be-an accepted practice in every aspect of our society.

What have we got now? The demand for pornography and the disregard of a woman's worth in the home are signs of an uncivilised society. Business should be accountable for its sexist advertising, where half-draped women advertise a product that has no relationship to gender. Advertising, business, men's pleasures, still very much see women as sex objects, and until that changes affirmative action will not be deep enough in our society. At least this Government legislates where it can, and that is in the employment area, so that we cut down on women being seen as objects, second rate citizens, and try to elevate them to their proper position, which is a partnership in society.

The Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Amendment Bill concentrates on higher education. Higher education institutions have been required for the last 2 1/2 years to report on how they will bring about affirmative action in their institutions. They have to report to the Director of Affirmative Action. It is pleasing to know that in an area I have been associated with every higher education institution has fulfilled its reporting obligations. However, we have to improve the system. We can streamline the reporting process by aligning the reporting period, which was the financial year, with the academic or calendar year. Because some States also have affirmative action obligations, we can align both State and Federal reporting requirements.

The new series of amalgamations is going to be very important in the employment of women and men. When several institutions come together a new institution is formed, and we have to ask ourselves whether this is a new employer or a state of continuing employment. If we have a hiatus, how does that fit in with the reporting requirements? What happens to all the programs that have been put into effect in the past 2 1/2 years? This Bill covers those transitional arrangements. Just as the terms and conditions of academic and general staff in the higher institutions are meant to be no less favourable after amalgamation, so it should be that the affirmative action programs continue unabated. This amendment will ensure that the new institutions are not regarded as a new employer for the purposes of affirmative action. There will be no break.

There is still a lot of confusion in the community about what affirmative action means. It is important for us to consider what it means to the average man and woman in the street. Some people think it means selecting women over men for jobs without considering other qualities which make them suitable for a position; that somehow we are setting quotas; that regardless of their abilities a certain number of women will be promoted to the detriment of the quality of that work force-some form of positive discrimination. The public should be reminded that affirmative action involves dismantling the barriers that deny women equal access to the jobs and careers that are available to men. In fact, appointing the best person for the job is the principle that underpins all affirmative action legislation in Australia. By removing unfair discrimination and developing the potential of the female work force, the legislation is designed to make women competitive rather than to remove competition. It is not a numbers game; it is not a quota exercise. It is about removing discrimination. In fact, Australia would be a better place if we realised the unused potential that is reposed in women who are being denied the opportunity to apply their full potential to the benefit of themselves, their families and society.

I have no doubt that this confusion and misunderstanding is coloured by visitors from overseas. For example, last September a lot of media attention was given to a particular black American academic, Professor Thomas Sowell, a former adviser to President Reagan, a doctor of economics and a disciple of Milton Friedman, the free marketeer. I think the honourable member for Berowra embraces some of those principles, but at times he has said in this House when government should intervene, and I respect him for that. He is not a total free marketeer, although he believes that the market mechanism, where appropriate, should be allowed to operate. I respect him for that, and I have said so on other occasions. Dr Sowell says that affirmative action does not work and that women and blacks in America are rejecting it. He says that what happens is that people are promoted beyond their ability-the Peter principle-and that when they are found out they are either sacked or put out with great embarrassment. Seventy per cent of blacks who are put into universities on quota systems fail their university or higher education courses.

Affirmative action of that type may well be the American model but it is certainly not the model in Australia. We do not base our affirmative action on preferential treatment or quotas. What Professor Sowell said is that we should have equal opportunity and a larger pool of women for employers and higher education institutions to choose from. He is right on both counts. In Australia equal opportunity is affirmative action. That is how we define it. He is right about having a larger pool of women to choose from. He later admitted that he was here to learn, not to tell us how to do our own job. I hope that actually occurred.

Another observer here was Mrs Monique Gagnon-Tremblay from Canada. She is the Minister responsible for the status of women in Quebec. She observed something that I said earlier in this debate. Her observation, as an outsider, was that there is more resistance by Australian men to adopting and embracing the equality of gender than in her own country. That could well explain the tardiness of some firms to adopt the strategies of affirmative action and report on time on how they were going to achieve affirmative action for women. Quite a few firms, while they did get their reports in on time, were very slow. Perhaps it was because they could not quite grasp what equal opportunities and affirmative action are about.

Mrs Gagnon-Tremblay nominated child-care centres as one of the most important areas to achieve equal opportunity. She boasted that Quebec, with a population of some six million, had 750 child-care centres and 55 agencies for family home care, and believed that it was meeting 40 per cent of the demand. The objective is to double that. She sees child-care services as not just for women but for parents at work. Until we start talking about parents as equal partners in bringing up our young children, we will never understand the liberation of women. This Government agrees. Since 1983 we have doubled child-care places and, in a further three years, we will have trebled them.

I return to Dr Sowell's remarks that we need a larger pool. The more women we have to choose from, the more opportunities there are actually to fulfil the objectives of equal opportunity in the work force and higher education. The Government is working and succeeding to that end. Since the Hawke Government came to office 1.2 million jobs have been created in Australia. Fifty-six per cent-that is, well over half-of the jobs went to women. That gives them an opportunity to choose whether they wish to work outside the home. But their opportunities are concentrated in female positions. Although equal pay operates in this country, they receive only 75 per cent of male earnings. Until women are able to be employed in areas now dominated by men, we will not see equal pay realised.

Five or six years ago only 44 per cent, less than half, of girls finished year 12. Now it is well over half. At the end of last year, 62 per cent finished year 12. In other words, we have to start at the bottom. If we are to have a wider pool in employment, we have to provide girls with the self-confidence and the skills to swim strongly in that bigger pool. More than 70 per cent of the traineeships created under this Government under the Australian traineeship scheme have been filled by women. This is another example of how girls and young women are being given the opportunity. The jobs, employment and training scheme, the JET scheme, is designed to assist sole parents to re-enter the work force. It is still true that out there in society the work one does defines the person one is and the amount of respect one earns-except for politicians of course. All the Opposition's attacks that we have heard are for nought. The runs are on the board: women are being given a greater chance. Dr Sowell was right: if we are to remove the barriers to selecting women, we have to have more women to choose from.

We still have a long way to go in higher education. Not every institution has child-care. That must be a top priority for both staff and students. Women academics are heavily clustered in part time positions-not full time-at the lower levels such as tutors and lecturer 3s rather than as lecturers and above. They are clustered in contract positions so that their jobs are not secure, whereas males dominate tenured positions. Until we have greater equality in these aspects of employment, we cannot say that we have finished our task. Until we can point to more equal gender intakes across the disciplines rather than gender concentrations of particular professions and courses, we cannot say that we have finished our task.

This will be an important task for the higher education advisory committee on affirmative action, which had its first meeting a couple of months ago. The committee should look at the compositions of councils, which are heavily dominated by men. When a vacancy occurs on a council of a university or a college of advanced education, the old boy network still operates. Other men are more likely to fill those positions. As the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), suggested to our Caucus-and the Caucus embraced it-at least 25 per cent of boards, governing bodies and councils should be women and at least 25 per cent men. That is one way of saying it in a non-discriminatory fashion and of encouraging women to apply for those positions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! the honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank the honourable members who have participated in what has become a quite wide-ranging debate. The provisions of the Affirmative Action (Equal Employment Opportunity for Women) Amendment Bill are quite narrow. They deal simply with a common reporting date for organisations covered by the provisions of the principal Act. I would like to comment on the points raised by the last speaker from the other side, the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards). He referred to positive discrimination and said that legislation that provided for quotas was unnecessary. No quotas are imposed in this legislation. Obviously, the honourable member does not understand what is in the legislation and how it is intended to work. It demonstrates a gross incompetence by the Opposition about what equal opportunity is all about. It is no wonder that the Opposition can never work out where it stands in this matter. I will refer to that later in my remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Berowra also made some comments about inflation and employment. Those comments indicate a mock concern for Australian families and Australian women. The hard facts are that during the life of this Government we have seen inflation reduced from 11.5 per cent to 7.7 per cent. It is higher than we want to see it, but there has been a considerable reduction on the performance of that Government of which the honourable member for Berowra and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) and most of his colleagues were members. The unemployment rate was at over 10 per cent. Today it has been announced that the unemployment rate has dropped to 6.7 per cent.

During the life of the Hawke Administration we have seen the creation of some 1,360,000 new jobs. Of these new jobs, 56 per cent have gone to women. That has happened at a time when there have been record levels in the participation rate, in the proportion of Australians of labour force age who want to be in the work force-working or looking for jobs. Contrast that record of achievement with that of the Fraser-Howard years. In just 12 months of their administration about a quarter of a million Australians lost their jobs. It is just cant for the Opposition to be talking about its concern for Australian women and Australian families. Just look at its performance. The most important thing that any government can do for an Australian family is to ensure that its breadwinner has a job. That is what this Government is about. That is what it has been about. In that respect we are very proud of our record.

Historically, more has been achieved for women's equality under this Government than under any other government. Labor was the first party ever to bring down a women's policy, enabling greater freedom of choice and participation for women in our society. The Liberals have attacked us over our policies with regard to women and the family. But I ask: What response has their own party come up with? We can turn to the latest little bit of fun and pleasure-they call it Future Directions; we call it `Futile Diversions'-but their policy document is 110 pages of rhetoric. If we look through that we find a miserable one and a half pages devoted to women's policy. In that one and a half pages, what do we find? Motherhood pronouncements; nothing solid, nothing firm, nothing that shows a clear commitment on the part of the Opposition.

Opposition members state that they support equal opportunity. But clearly there is the usual confusion amongst the Opposition between the Liberal Party and the National Party as to what this support actually involves. On the one hand we had the Leader of the Opposition telling us yesterday that equality of opportunity is something to which the Liberal Party and National Party are completely committed. In their own policy document the coalition states that it `will ensure that equal employment opportunity legislation is implemented in a sensitive manner'. On the other hand, yesterday we had the National Party member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) telling us that what the legislation before us now and its predecessor are doing is actually enforcing discrimination by legislating to try to change attitudes. So yet again Opposition members cannot get their act together. They cannot get their act together on such a simple matter as where they stand on equal opportunity legislation.

Again we are going to have to sit through another embarrassing, humdrum rerun of the rumpus that the Opposition created a couple of years ago when a number of those from their ranks crossed the floor over the Equal Employment Opportunity (Commonwealth Authorities) Bill. They could not make up their minds then. What is going to be the story this time? What surprises can we expect from a coalition government? What surprises are in store for 51 per cent of Australia's population-Australian women-when we hear the National Party member for Cowper telling us that again the Government has come up with this affirmative action nonsense. Therein lies the truth. `This affirmative action nonsense', says the National Party member for Cowper. That is really the view of the National Party towards Australian women.

We have the mock concern that we heard yesterday and today from the Leader of the Opposition and other members of the Liberal Party and I think we can say pretty assuredly that, if ever the chance arose, we would have the National Party-the party of the honourable member for Cowper-pushing for the repeal of the current legislative measures that provide equal opportunity for Australian women. This legislation before us that they would want to repeal received a positive response from 99 per cent of the largest companies in Australia last year. It is legislation that has been hailed as an overwhelming success in encouraging a change of attitudes towards women in the work force.

The fact is that the Opposition does not have a future direction on this issue. They do not have a future direction that will stand examination or to which there is commitment from both of those parties. In fact, they have lost their direction in this area of policy. But what are other Opposition policies in this area? Opposition members say they are committed to ensuring that women gain greater benefit from their policies, especially with respect to families, education and training facilities. That is a nice statement. They talk about amending the tax system. How would they do this? Through income splitting, across the board payments, or rebates? But most importantly, how would they pay for it? They can only pay for it through massive cuts in social welfare expenditure, education expenditure and health expenditure, or the introduction of a broad-based consumption tax, which is really the original personal commitment of the Leader of the Opposition. And that kind of measure discriminates quite clearly against low income families, the very families that they purport to want to support and help.

To put it succinctly, once again we have the Opposition grandstanding on a very rickety stage-another exercise in opportunism. Yet again we have conflict, opportunism and division in the Opposition. Let me just deal with one other area that bears very strongly on that promise of the Opposition. We have the Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock), the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) and a range of their colleagues, calling for substantial cuts in expenditure by this Government. They cannot tell us where. All they say is that there should be severe cuts-a very tight fiscal policy. When we ask them where, they cannot delineate or specify. But at the same time as they are saying that, the National Party member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) is wandering around the country saying, `Spend more money on roads. Spend another $430m or $450m'. Back here in Canberra the Leader of the Opposition is saying, `Spend less money. I cannot tell you where'. I only mention that because it again highlights the conflicts within the Opposition. It highlights the shallowness of the undertakings and commitments that they make.

Yesterday we had the Opposition spokesperson on industrial relations telling us about the need for flexible working arrangements, especially for women working part time. This is the very same issue that is currently being addressed through award restructuring, a process that has been initiated by this Government and is strongly supported. In the life of our Government we have seen a 32 per cent increase in part time employment. Through award restructuring we are creating opportunities for flexible working arrangements, dismantling traditional barriers, creating better career paths, greater skilling and more rewarding job opportunities. And within that process is the opportunity to create greater equality of opportunity for Australian women. The Government has been putting this into place. It is something we are participating in and doing; we are not just grandstanding, talking about it.

To sum up, this Government has done more towards achieving equality in opportunity for Australian women than any other government. As is illustrated through `Futile Diversions', the Opposition clearly has nothing to offer Australian women. Its behaviour in the past and its inconsistency as illustrated during the debate of this Bill show up the obvious that there is no cohesive women's policy being put forward by Opposition members. The only good thing about that is that they are not likely to have a chance to try to implement the policies that they are putting. I stress again that women have been given more opportunities under this Government than ever before in the history of this country, and they have seized those opportunities.

I will briefly look at the record. Since 1983 1.36 million new jobs have been created, 56 per cent of which have gone to women. We are achieving those objectives in a time when we have had a record participation by Australian women in the work force, since World War II. The gap between male and female earnings has been narrowed. The ratio of adult female ordinary time earnings to adult male earnings rose between 1983 and 1988 from 79.7 per cent to 83.4 per cent. The rate of growth in jobs for females has averaged over 4 per cent annually.

Let me turn to other initiatives. The national policy for the education of girls in Australian schools and the plan of action for women in tertiary education: in 1987, 57 per cent of girls stayed on to the end of secondary school compared with 44 per cent in 1983. In 1988 women represented 51 per cent of all enrolled students in universities and colleges of advanced education, compared with 46 per cent in 1983. There are more apprenticeship opportunities for women. There is a range of labour market programs aimed at increasing women's participation across a wide range of industries and occupations. There is action to remove the provisions in awards which by their discriminatory or restrictive nature hinder participation in particular occupations. This is a priority issue in the context of award restructuring.

There is support for improving regulation of pay and conditions of outworkers, paying particular attention to the needs of women in occupational health and safety. There is support for women and their families. Some 20,000 new child-care places have brought the total number of Commonwealth provided child-care places to 110,000, an increase of about 64,000 since 1983. Women are the major recipients of social security outlays, with about 61 per cent of total social security expenditure on pensions, benefits and allowances going to women. Measures such as the family allowance supplement and the jobs, education and training package are both major initiatives to help break the poverty cycle which women find themselves trapped in.

Further initiatives are the development of the national women's health policy, due to be released shortly; the Government's allocation of $5.1m over the next three years to provide a national screening service for breast and cervical cancer; the ratification of International Labour Organisation Convention No. 156 and the support of the parental leave case due before the Industrial Relations Commission later this year.

Overall, the Government's record is a proud one, to serve Australian women and to better their position. It is through this record that this Government can stand tall on a global level with its ongoing commitment to promote equality and to improve the position of women in Australian society. I commend the Bill to the House, and the Government rejects the amendment moved by the Opposition.
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 March, on motion by Mr Duncan:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the Geneva Conventions Amendment Bill 1989, the purpose of which is to ratify a protocol which has been agreed upon at the end of a long series of international conferences. I suppose one can best summarise the protocol by saying that its purpose is to isolate civilians and civilian targets from the effects of war. The protocol tries to do this with respect to international war, and we have been told that there is another protocol which seeks to achieve the same objective with respect to internal military situations, which I suppose can best be described as civil wars or perhaps revolutions. We have been told by the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) in his speech that the purpose of the Bill is to enable protocol I, that is to say, the protocol relating to international conflict, to be ratified. We have also been told that protocol II does not need legislation to ratify it, but that the effect of the ratification of protocol I will be that protocol II will also bind Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: We therefore have a situation where the objective of the protocol, which is the protocol additional to the Geneva Conventions of 12 August 1949 and relates to the Protection of Victims of International Armed Conflicts, is to protect civilians and civilian objectives from the dreadful scourge of war and the consequences of international war. Of course, that objective is laudable and one that all people will seek to support.

The Opposition will, however, oppose this Bill for several reasons. The first reason is that the principal provisions of the protocol are ambiguous, and are not simply ambiguous on a strict legal interpretation but ambiguous in their substance to the extent that the actual operation of this protocol must be left in very grave doubt. The second reason we oppose the Bill is that the protocol, if it applied to Australia and its armed forces, would undoubtedly limit the effectiveness of the Australian defence forces and limit them very severely, to the extent that we must conclude that there would be doubt as to whether the Australian defence forces would be able to achieve their objective in an armed conflict if they were required to comply with the terms of the protocol.

It goes further than that, however, because, thirdly, we also take the view that if the Australian armed forces were bound by this protocol, they would in fact be put in danger. We are not prepared to go along with a situation where that is to be the result. Enough danger inevitably flows from the conflict itself without imposing excessive legalisms on the armed forces, the result of which must be, in our view, that they would be subjected to additional and unnecessary danger.

The fourth reason we oppose the Bill is that, although ratification has been performed, assumed and undertaken by a number of countries, what can be said of those countries that have ratified it is that they are not countries which are instantly identified as our immediate allies nor are they countries which are in our region. Countries in our region, with virtually no exception, have not ratified the protocol and our principal allies have not ratified the protocol. The United States, so far as we know, will not ratify it. I venture to say that that is almost certainly the case with respect to other countries with which we usually identify ourselves, but it is certainly true of the United States. Therefore, at the outset, I want to make it plain that we will oppose this Bill which seeks to achieve the ratification of the protocol, and we will oppose it for the reasons that I have briefly given.

Having said that, I also want to make it plain that our opposition is not to the concept of having a structure of international humanitarian law and it is not an opposition to some of the principles and provisions which are set out and contained in the protocol. For our part we support the concept of having international humanitarian law where there is a case for it. We support that notion in principle and we will support it in practice. We support the efforts made by the International Red Cross and other branches of the Red Cross and, indeed, the efforts made by other organisations and people to lay down principles of international humanitarian law. All of that is common ground; we are at one on those points. To take it further, we can also say that we support attempts to protect civilians from the devastating effects of war. Anyone who seeks to argue that, from our opposition to this Bill, the Opposition is opposed to international humanitarian law is completely mistaken. Indeed, for our part we would expect the Australian defence forces to comply with civilised principles when they are engaged in an armed conflict, even those that may not be enforceable under the law that is applicable at the time.

There are many provisions in the protocol that we support. One would hope that they would be common ground amongst all who are concerned with this subject. They are, and should be, common ground. We say, therefore, that when we look at the protocol, we see provisions in it which we support. No suggestion should be made by anyone that we are opposed to the entirety of the provisions in the protocol, because that is simply not the case.

I refer the House to some of the provisions of the protocol in order to support that proposition. As I say, there is a whole series. In fact, the protocol has about 63 pages and therefore contains many provisions. In that protocol there is a large number of provisions to which we take no exception. Indeed, not only do we take no exception to them, but also we would assume that they would be applied and are applied, whether they are contained in this or any other provision of international law, or whether they are contained in any statement of international law. I refer, for instance, to the proposition that the wounded, the sick and the shipwrecked must be respected, protected and given medical care and attention. Who would disagree with that proposition? Certainly not us. I refer to another proposition contained in the protocol that internees and detainees must not be subjected to inappropriate medical procedures such as mutilation and medical experiments. Who would disagree with that proposition? Who would disagree with the proposition that medical units must be respected and protected and that they should not be made the object of attack? We certainly support that proposition in the protocol.

There is a provision to the effect that civil medical units must be protected unless they commit acts that are harmful to the enemy. We support that provision. There is a provision to the effect that an occupying power must ensure that the medical needs of the civilian population continue to be satisfied. We support that provision. There is a provision that civilian, medical and religious personnel must be respected and protected. There are provisions to the effect that the civilian population must respect the wounded, the sick and the shipwrecked. And so it goes on. There is no need for me to detail what would total a considerable list of provisions in the protocol to which we take no exception. I want to make that perfectly plain. As I have said before, and I simply repeat it before I move on, we would support those principles in practice, whether or not they were contained in a regime of international law. Indeed, they are probably second nature to all Australians.

Of course, it can also be said that many of those provisions are already contained in the Fourth Convention, which is one of the four Geneva conventions which Australia acceded to and which are enforceable under Australian law by the Geneva Conventions Act, the Act which is being amended by the Bill that is presently before the House. It must be acknowledged by any observer that many of those provisions are already contained in the Convention and there is no need for an additional instrument to set them out again.

I hope that so far I have made our position clear. The first proposition, as I have said, is that we will oppose this Bill. We will oppose it for the reasons which I have briefly given and which I will amplify as the debate continues. It must also be said that we support the notion and the concept of international humanitarian law. We believe very strongly indeed that there should be provisions relating to the protection of civilians in some of those cases of the sort that I have already referred to.

Our concerns do not stem from the sorts of provisions that I have referred to. As I have said, many of them are already contained in the Fourth Geneva Convention. Our concern arises basically from two fundamental articles in the protocol and, in the first place, from the terms of those fundamental provisions in the protocol. Furthermore, our concern arises from the colour which is given to the whole of the protocol by those two fundamental provisions. In addition, our concern arises from several particular provisions of the protocol which I will refer to as we proceed.

Having regard to those fundamental provisions in the protocol, the colour that is given by those fundamental provisions to the whole of the protocol, and some of the particular provisions of the protocol about which we are concerned, we believe that the provisions of the protocol in total give rise to a justification for rejecting the Bill and for not ratifying the protocol. Let me illustrate that point and make it plainer by referring initially to two articles of the protocol, the first being article 48. I draw your attention, Mr Deputy Speaker, to the fact that article 48 is headed `Basic Rules'. We can assume that the draftsmen of this protocol meant what they said and were aware that substance of this basic and most important area of the Convention is to be found in article 48. Article 48 provides:

In order to ensure respect for and protection of the civilian population and civilian objects, the Parties to the conflict shall at all times distinguish between the civilian population and combatants and between civilian objects and military objectives and accordingly shall direct their operations only against military objectives.

I draw the House's attention to the fact that if this is to be applied in the words that are set out in the protocol, the word is `only'. That then is the basic rule. In addition, I will for the purposes of this argument draw the House's attention to article 51, which is headed `Protection of the civilian population'. Paragraph 2 of that article states:
The civilian population as such, as well as individual civilians, shall not be the object of attack.

There we have a fairly basic proposition. But to make the effect of that clause clear I ask honourable members to go back to article 49, which explains in effect what the protocol is talking about at that stage. I draw the House's attention to three provisions in article 49. The first, which is paragraph 1, makes it plain that these restrictions apply not only when a party is engaged in an offensive posture or exercise but also when it is in defence. I think in the version tabled in the Parliament there is a spelling error-I presume it is a spelling error-which might be corrected. Should it not be `whether in offence or in defence'? Perhaps we can change that at some stage. If I am right on that, the intention of the draftsman is to say, `Whether you are engaged on the offensive or the defensive, that is an attack for the purpose of this provision of the protocol'.

The second thing to note is that the provisions of the protocol with respect to attacks apply to all attacks in whatever territory they are conducted. So it is intended to have a very wide ambit. The third provision is paragraph 3 of article 49, which states:
The provisions of this Section apply to any land, air or sea warfare which may affect the civilian population . . .

It is not `which does or necessarily will' have that result, it is `which may affect the civilian population'. In further support of that I draw the attention of honourable members to article 52, paragraph 2 of which provides that attacks shall be limited strictly to military objectives. So we find once again this very clear intention of the protocol, being not that we are trying to achieve the best or the best in all circumstances but that the protocol is intended to have a strict limitation and a strict application. One of our concerns is that in military encounters that imposes a burden on the armed forces which is really impossible to ask for and impossible to achieve.

The basic rule is that operations are only to be against military objectives. We know that what is being talked about is a situation that may be one of defence as well as offence. We know it is intended to have a particularly wide coverage. The total effect of all this is very plain indeed. It is to isolate civilian targets in such a way that in our view the armed forces would be neutralised. There is no doubt that this is what President Reagan had in mind when he said that this protocol was fundamentally flawed and when his Joint Chiefs of Staff Committee made a statement in an article on this subject, which many honourable members would have seen, to the effect that there is a lot in this which is simply militarily unacceptable.

In many cases the provisions are vague and uncertain. When one adds that vagueness and uncertainty to provisions which almost reek of an inability to apply them with the intention the draftsman had, we believe that the only conclusion that fairly can be reached is in the first place that this will impose very severe limitations on our armed forces engaged in exercises in which we and all Australians expect them to succeed. It really is an unreasonable limitation to impose upon them, a limitation which when they are engaged in those exercises will result in their being in a situation of danger.

It is probably no surprise for honourable members to find, when pondering provisions such as those I have read out and many other provisions of the protocol, that there is a provision-article 82-to the effect that military commanders are to have lawyers with them. They will probably need them. What will happen in the meantime while they get legal advice as to whether they are allowed to attack a particular objective I leave it to the House to speculate. It goes further. When we look at some of the basic principles of the protocol we see that they emphasise the ambiguity and the uncertainty and the difficulty there will be in applying them. For instance, article 56 is an interesting article. It requires that there will be no assault on dams, dykes and nuclear electrical generating stations. It goes on to say:
. . . even where these objects are military objectives, if such attack may cause the release of dangerous forces and consequent severe losses among the civilian population.

We take the view that to impose on the armed forces a limitation of that sort, going as far as preventing them from attacking military objectives, goes too far. It limits the effectiveness of the armed forces to the extent that they would be neutralised, and it must add to the inevitable danger that they themselves will be involved in and subjected to by the very nature of the war when they are not able to act with the full flexibility that a military force must have, when they are to be bound by excessively restrictive provisions such as this and, above all, when the restrictive provisions to which they are bound under this protocol are, in many cases, vague and uncertain.

As an illustration of that, honourable members may ask: How is the article on dangerous installations to which I have referred to be put into practice? As we read on we find a curious provision to the effect that if one is on the receiving end one marks the buildings or structures with three orange circles on the same axis. Then the question arises: what happens if there are no orange circles on the structures? The conclusions are given in paragraph 7, which states:
The absence of such marking in no way relieves any Party to the conflict of its obligations under this Article.

So those on the receiving end may mark their installations with three orange circles, obviously as a warning to the attacker that they are about to face a situation where a provision of this protocol will limit and prevent them from attacking it. Obviously, that is the purpose of its being there in the first place. Then we find that if those in the defending country, if we can call it that, do not have the markings on the structures, it does not relieve the attacker at all. One might well ask what was the purpose of it all. What were the lawyers doing when the decision was being made as to whether to attack or not.

In our view, when we put all of that together we must conclude that it imposes limitations on the effectiveness of our armed forces. They would be fighting with one arm tied behind their back. In modern warfare we cannot make this clinical distinction, in the way in which the protocol seeks to do, between military matters on the one hand and civilian matters on the other. We cannot make that clinical distinction between civilian targets and objectives on the one hand and military targets on the other. They are obviously going to be mixed. If the armed forces are going to do what we want them to do-namely, to win-they cannot be denied that flexibility that they need to pursue the war or military encounter with all of the vigour and ability that goes with them. Secondly, in the course of doing all that, we would have to conclude that they would be put in additional danger, which is unnecessary.

We find our concern exacerbated when we see, as I have said, that very few, if any, of our neighbours have, as at 1 March 1989, ratified this protocol. Singapore, Malaysia and Indonesia have not done so, and the list goes on. We find that the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation countries have not ratified it. The United States, Great Britain, Japan, Canada, West Germany, France and even the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics have not done so. We obviously have our interests inextricably woven with those of our allies, whether they are in Europe or in this part of the world, and particularly, with the United States. It would seem an unacceptable situation to us if the ratification took place at this stage in the absence of ratifications from those other parties.

We are very concerned about this. My concern was considerably added to when I discovered that my view was shared by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). We now know that the Prime Minister has been engaging in correspondence with former President Reagan about this matter. One of the letters was referred to in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning. Our Prime Minister took it upon himself to write pursuing this issue with President Reagan because we have an obvious involvement with the United States. If we have a situation where we have joint military exercises with an American commander, who is not restricted by the protocol, who might give an order, then the consequence of our being bound by this protocol and the Americans not being bound by it must be utter confusion and a conflict in orders and in what the combined forces of our two countries are able to achieve. Our Prime Minister wrote to President Reagan saying that there were a number of `ambiguities and operational complexities in the protocol'. He is certainly right about the ambiguities. He says that there are operational complexities in the protocol. He is certainly right there.

I will give the Prime Minister his due, because he went on and said that despite the fact that there were those ambiguities and operational complexities, `We consider that on balance the practical obstacles are not such as to warrant Australia not ratifying the protocol'. I will give him due marks for making that additional statement. But is that really the situation to which the Australian Government is going to subject the Australian armed forces? Will it tell them to go into war or some conflict under and bound by, with all the force of law, a protocol which the Prime Minister says contains ambiguities and operational complexities? I am not a military person but I do not need to be one to be told that if I am fighting a war subject to international law and a 63-page protocol, that is bad enough; but when I am told that in addition to that it is ambiguous and has operational complexities in it, then I am entitled to make a protest. We make a protest on their behalf. Frankly, I really wonder what the Government is doing about this provision when it is prepared to go ahead on the basis of that admission.

The Prime Minister's letter goes on to say that there are declarations of understanding which Australia is making about this. Where are those declarations of understanding if they are going to make the effect of this protocol clearer? In his speech the Attorney-General did not expose them. He did not tell us about the provisions of the declarations of understanding, but in this letter from Mr Hawke to President Reagan he tells us that there are declarations of understanding. I would like to know what they are and how they make the protocol clearer than it is now. I would also like a clearer statement, which is not contained in the second reading speech, as to what the Australian armed forces really think of this protocol. That was left out of the second reading speech. It is a notable omission. I gather that their position is that they can live with it, or words to that effect. That is not good enough. We would like to know exactly what their view is and how it is going to affect their operation abilities.

For all of those reasons, I conclude on the same point that I made at the opening of my remarks. We support international humanitarian law. We support measures to protect civilians in law, but we cannot, for the reasons that I have given, and especially for the reasons set out by the Prime Minister in his letter to President Reagan, support the Bill, and therefore, we oppose it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am speaking for the first time in this debate. I want to reply, within a short space of time, to the remarks made by the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown). Let me say at the outset that it is a surprise to us to know now that the Opposition is opposing the ratification of this Geneva Convention. I understand that there might be some ambiguities that the Opposition wishes to have clarified. But I think it ought to be put on the record that the signing of the Convention was in December 1978. That means that the Convention was signed when the honourable member and his Party were in government. The words were the same then. What worries me, from the point of view of this nation, is that we do not want to have a debate here about something that might be deemed to be limiting the armed forces of Australia and creating doubts and ambiguities.

SPEECH.PARA: I will talk for only a few minutes. I will ask leave to continue my remarks later so that the debate will be adjourned. It will be on the basis that the Red Cross and other organisations can talk to the Opposition and see whether they can convince it that the ambiguities and uncertainties which were certainly created for the first time by President Reagan in a letter written in 1987 can be properly debated.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Hawke admits them and agrees with him.

—I ought to put it on the record that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) wrote to the President of the United States in reply to the suggestions that the President had made, saying they did not have foundation. I invite the honourable gentleman to look at the reply given by the International Red Cross to the letter of the President to the Congress. It is very significant because it says a number of things. It makes the point that the President's letter mentions that the `Joint Chiefs of Staff have concluded that a number of the provisions of the protocol are militarily unacceptable'. It casts doubts on that issue. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is nevertheless striking that the President's message emphasizes the terrorist argument at great length while devoting much less attention to the military objections.
In fairness to the United States, the previous President did not have the same objections as President Reagan. At the same time, we should look at what the Red Cross was saying. It said:
The reasons that induced the Joint Chiefs of Staff ultimately to reject Protocol 1 are not specified in the President's message, and their final report on Protocol 1 is classified.
I can understand the Red Cross being concerned about these matters. It went on to make this final point, in fairness to the whole issue:

. . . the unprecedented language used by the United States to justify its decision not to ratify Protocol 1 will not do lasting damage to such a delicate undertaking as humanitarian treaties always are . . . Moreover, failure to ratify by a major power such as the United States would deprive the world of a common framework for the humanitarian rules governing armed conflicts.

I understand that. The honourable gentleman was Parliamentary Adviser to the Australian Delegation to the United Nations in 1976. There is a resolution there which he would have participated in, urging the speedy adoption and bringing into effect of this particular protocol. He knows the detail backwards. I am trying to say that a number of countries, in fact some 60-odd, have already ratified. Well over 100 have already signed. Obviously, the real influence was the United States under President Reagan feeling that it should not sign. That is the issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Malaysia, Singapore and Indonesia?
—But the influence is basically in terms of the structures that the honourable member was anxious to talk about. A number of countries, including the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, have signed.
—It has not ratified it.

—The Act imposes a legal obligation on a country, after signature, not to do anything contrary to the protocol. The words in the protocol were clearly known to the honourable gentleman and others who signed it in 1978. The Minister for Foreign Affairs of 1978 is now the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock). It is a bit late in the day in terms of legal argument to come in here and say, `There is something wrong here. There are going to be problems'. I am advised that we can give arguments in rational terms to explain the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue is to try to protect civilians from extermination. Certainly, it is not necessary for a lawyer to be present at all times because the big reservation in all worries that the honourable gentleman put forward, and with some sincerity, is that one still has to balance that with what is called the proportionality of the necessity of the military venture at the time. In other words, the whole judgment as to the circumstances goes to the military commander. There is no question of looking at the situation later and saying that one might have misjudged the issue.
