The fact is that there is a reservation all the time that the question of military necessity is virtually the guiding light. So all those protocols that the honourable gentleman mentioned ought to be read in toto because that is what it is all about. Military necessity has always to be balanced against the consequences for civilians. That is very clear.

Article 57 now gives guidance concerning the test of proportionality whereby an attack should not be launched if its effects would be excessive, et cetera. The honourable gentleman expressed concern about attacks on dams, dykes and nuclear power stations. But that would not apply if a particular installation were used for other than what are called normal functions of civilian use. If used in respect of assisting war production, it becomes a target. That is the position. What we have here is an obsessive interest in words when Opposition members saw no difficulty with them when they were in government and signed the document. That is the point. What has happened since it was signed?

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a difference between signing and ratifying.

—It is no different in the terms of what we are about. Let me make the point that the President's message was basically concerned about whether there would be some recognition of guerilla activities. That is not valid. Even though he was entitled to say so, it is not valid because, as the honourable gentleman knows, the articles provide that, in those special circumstances, there should be some recognition of what would be called a force that is fighting for, say, its independence or against a colonial power.
—The Americans still will not ratify it.

—Well, I doubt that; it may be that they will. The point is that the Red Cross has received a lot of letters from a lot of people saying that they support its proposition. I am anxious that the Red Cross have a chance to talk to members of the Opposition. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
—Is what is being asked for that we resume the debate later on?
—Yes, after Opposition members have met with the Red Cross and other parties.
—Does that mean today?
—I would not think it would be possible today.
—Well, it is to be put off then, to be adjourned?
—Yes, we will adjourn the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House that we suspend the sitting as the next item of business, the Student Assistance Amendment Bill, is not ready to proceed.

INTERJECT.PARA: Sitting suspended from 5.55 to 8 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 2 March, on motion by Mr Duncan:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beale Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating the Student Assistance Amendment Bill 1989. Before we come to that Bill I want to say something about the way in which we have arrived at this debate tonight because I think it is illustrative of this Government's shocking management performance. Before dinner we were having a debate on the Geneva Conventions Amendment Bill. Without warning, the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen), who had charge of that Bill--
—Order! The honourable member for Deakin might address the Student Assistance Amendment Bill rather than--
—With respect, I am addressing that Bill because I am saying how we come to be debating the Bill. I remind you that this afternoon--
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take a point of order. The Opposition spokesman is not addressing the legislation. He was not in the House at the time the Bill was to come on.
—Order! The point of order is probably in order to the extent that the honourable member for Deakin should address the matter before the Chair.

—I would like to speak to the point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. It is true that at the time this Bill was due to be brought on I was not in the House. I was not in the House because the Attorney- General adjourned the debate on the other Bill.
—The honourable member for Deakin has no point of order. The honourable member can address the matter before the Chair, which is the Student Assistance Amendment Bill.

—I will just close the other matter by saying that the Government gagged us this afternoon and then created a half-hour space later in the afternoon when there was no business before the House. It gagged the debate either because it was embarrassed or because it had a surfeit of business. It is obvious that it did not have a surfeit of business. It was embarrassed about the tax file numbers.
—I take a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. The Opposition spokesman is not addressing the legislation before the House.
—I think the honourable member for Deakin is now going to address the matter before the Chair rather than extraneous matters.
—It is justifiable.
—The honourable member for Mackellar does not assist the debate by interjection.

—I will come to the Bill, but, as the honourable member for Mackellar has said, and quite rightly, the Government is clearly embarrassed about what happened when it gagged the tax file debate this afternoon and now it has all this spare time.

SPEECH.PARA: We are debating the Student Assistance Amendment Bill. This Bill incorporates some minor changes to the Student Assistance Act. For example, the explanatory memorandum refers to replacing the words `advanced education institution' and the word `university' with references to higher education institutions. I am not quite sure why the Government wants to do that. It seems to be rather pedantic and churlish. Colleges are still colleges and universities are still universities, whatever we might call them. To change their names to `higher education institutions' seems to me to be a bit of a waste of time and money.

However, the purpose of this Bill does seem to be a general tidying up of the Student Assistance Act, altering wording and facilitating the management of programs. Accordingly, we will not oppose this legislation. However, we seek to condemn the Government for aspects of higher education as it relates to student assistance. Accordingly the coalition moves the following amendment:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
`whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House condemns the Government for-
(1) its inability to appreciate the special needs for assistance for students from rural areas; and
(2) the turmoil caused by its policies on, and administration of, assistance for students in higher education institutions'.
The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) received a dorothy dix question in the House on 2 March. In the course of answering that question he said:
If the Opposition wants to engage in a sensible debate on education policy we will be happy to accommodate it.

The Minister knew quite well that we would move this amendment to open out the debate for a full view on student assistance and the administration of assistance for students in higher education institutions. The question is: Where is the Minister? The junior Minister, the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan), is here, but the Minister who invited us to engage in a sensible debate does not even have the courtesy to come to the chamber--

TALK.START.PARA: —Because it is my Bill.

—It is not the junior Minister's Bill; it is the senior Minister's Bill. He sent the junior Minister in here. His office told me that. It said he thought this Bill was so inconsequential that he would send Duncan. The question is: Where is the Minister? The Minister invites us to conduct a sensible debate with him, and he is not even here. The reason he is not here is that he does not want to have a debate about higher education because his policies have left our higher education institutions and the students who attend them in absolute turmoil. What he has done for higher education-and it is reflected every day in the press when we read of the turmoil in our higher education system-is to turn the whole thing upside down, to the grave detriment of the students and the institutions. Austudy is an absolute nightmare.
—I take a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. Can you inform us whether there are copies of this amendment around?

—The honourable member has moved a second reading amendment. He is speaking to that amendment, which will be circulated by the time the honourable member completes his address. It is not proposed to circulate the amendment until it is seconded because until then it is not properly before the House. But by the time the matter is proposed the amendment will have been circulated.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. As you quite rightly point out, the amendment will be seconded at the end of my second reading response. If the honourable member for the Northern Territory knew something about the rules of the House he would know that and would not have been on his feet for that churlish point of order. If he spent a little more time understanding what goes on here instead of--
—If you had had your amendment prepared before dinner--
—Order! The honourable member for the Northern Territory will cease interjecting and the honourable member for Deakin will not respond to the interjections.

—As I was saying, Austudy is an absolute nightmare. Those of us who have seen the form for Austudy, which is about 2 1/2 feet wide by two feet high-that is, three-quarters of a metre by two-thirds of a metre-with a whole series of regulations and qualifications realise that one has to have a higher education to read the form before one can qualify to get the higher education.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to draw attention to what the Liberal and National Party policy has to say about Austudy. It states:

Austudy has been bedevilled by administrative deficiencies and suffers from continuing allegations of unfairness in the award of benefits. The Liberal and National Parties will, in government, thoroughly review the rules and administration of AUSTUDY to ensure that they are fair to all and that the scheme runs smoothly.

As I say, Austudy is an absolute mess and a disgrace and needs to be looked at. The student assistance that arises from Austudy needs to be cleaned up in a proper, effective and administrative way. This Bill does not address those difficulties at all. The Department has been trying to fix these difficulties up with its regulations and changes, but the fact is that Austudy is an absolute mess, bedevilled by inefficiencies and abuses, and something should be done about it.

Furthermore, the Government has imposed a harsh assets test on students from rural areas, isolated students. The Government simply does not understand about students from rural areas. The Government does not understand that those students have to travel in order to get their education, whether it is to schools, which are not the subject of the discussion here today, or to higher education institutions. The Government is punishing students from rural areas by imposing this harsh assets test, as my colleague the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan) said. It is an absolute disgrace. Our higher education policy, recently released and widely acclaimed, has this to say:

Particular regard will also be given to the needs of regional and rural students who have to travel long distances, or be accommodated away from home, to attend higher education institutions. We will establish a realistic assets test, including a hardship provision.
I know that my friend and colleague the honourable member for Lyne is delighted that the Liberal and National parties' policy on the assets test for rural children is phrased in that way.

The Government's higher education policy proposals and its policies on student assistance have created turmoil, uncertainty and outrage in higher education institutions and for students across the country. For example, as far as the amalgamations are concerned, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training is pushing for a complete centralisation of control of higher education institutions and corresponding increases in the bureaucracy that will be associated with higher education. Why does the Government not talk to some people in the system?

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order: the honourable member is addressing himself to issues related to higher education which have absolutely nothing to do with this Bill. I suggest that the honourable member should relate his comments to the Bill before the House.
—If I may speak to that point--

—We are not going to have a debate on points of order. The House generally allows reasonable latitude on matters before it. The honourable member for Deakin should ensure that the majority of his remarks are made in relation to the Student Assistance Amendment Bill.

—With respect, I have been speaking for 12 minutes, and the whole time has been taken up with students. I have been talking about Austudy, the assets test on isolated children, and I am now talking about the effects on student assistance of what is happening in the institutions. Quite clearly, the amendment allows me to deal with those matters. I repeat that the Minister is pushing for complete centralisation of control of the higher education institutions, with the effect that has on student assistance. He is talking about the number of institutions coming down from 63 to 35 or 40. These amalgamations, which are at the centre of the move to establish a unified national scheme of education over which the Government can assert control, are an absolute mess.

SPEECH.PARA: If I could refer briefly to that, in December the South Australian Labor Government asserted that it would not toe the Dawkins line on this matter. The Adelaide Advertiser of 21 December 1988 had this to say:

The State Government has abandoned plans for a major restructuring of higher education institutions in South Australia . . . The Employment and Further Education Minister . . . yesterday announced State Cabinet had decided against the move, despite his support . . . It was labelled a `fiasco' by the Opposition . . .

It is quite clear from what the Advertiser has to say that the effect on students and student assistance of these amalgamations is going to be very detrimental. Furthermore, Queensland is also concerned about these effects on students and student assistance. The Queensland Government on 7 February this year had this to say:
State Cabinet has decided not to proceed with a Commonwealth originated proposal to establish a new university by merging several existing institutions.
The statement goes on:
The Queensland amalgamation proposals came from the Queensland authorities not from the Commonwealth . . .
The Commonwealth had asserted to the contrary.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Deakin should address his amendment and the Bill before the House, which is about student assistance in institutions of higher education and other institutions. The debate is not about amalgamations of institutions of higher education. While the honourable member might wish to illustrate arguments, that cannot be the burden of his argument.
—Thank you for your guidance, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—I am always here to help my friend the honourable member for Deakin.

—If I may summarise what I have been saying about student assistance and the effect that amalgamations are having on student assistance in Queensland, South Australia and the Australian Capital Territory, we condemn this strategy. Our policy advocates the autonomy of higher education institutions. We are opposed to the arbitrary amalgamation of them in such a way that it affects students and, hence, we oppose this legislation that is before us tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: There is also an effect on students and student assistance from the Minister's insistence on educational profiles-this iniquitous system whereby each institution must negotiate a profile with the Department as a condition of funding. I emphasise `condition of funding' because a condition of funding is clearly tied up with the relevance of students and student assistance. These institutions will be obliged to meet what are called national priorities, which may or may not be appropriate for the institution or for the market that the institution is supposed to serve or for the students. This is simply another area in which the mania for centralisation is apparent and autonomy is blatantly removed from the institutions. Furthermore, we have a situation where the Government is siphoning funds away from the universities and putting them in the hands of what is loosely called the Australian Research Council and the effect this has on students and student assistance--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I think we have been very tolerant with the honourable member. I know that he has a speech that has been prepared by some research officer and he is dealing with that--
—The Minister might get to his point of order.

—The point of order is that quite clearly the honourable member is not being relevant at all when he talks about matters such as siphoning off funding from higher education into research funding. That has nothing to do with this Bill at all. I ask you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to ask the honourable member to come back to the point of the Bill.

—The Chair has been tolerant with the honourable member for Deakin. He should address the matter before the House, which is a Bill to amend the Student Assistance Act, and his amendment to that Bill, not the amalgamations of tertiary institutions or other areas of Government involvement, except perhaps to illustrate his argument. He must not make it the burden of his whole argument.

—I would like to repeat, if I may, that it is obvious that the Government is pretty sensitive about this issue. Mr Deputy Speaker, you have not made a single ruling on this whole question without a point of order from the Government side. The reason the Government is sensitive about it is that it knows it has it wrong.

—Order! If the honourable member for Deakin is now suggesting that I should enforce the rules rigidly, I am happy to do so. He might address the matter before the House and not other extraneous matters.
—He has lost his cool.
—The honourable member for Streeton will not assist the Chair by making that sort of interjection.
—The honourable member for Streeton is spending a lot of time in the House these days. I suspect that it is a concertina of experience.
—If the honourable member for Deakin does not address the matter before the Chair, he might not spend too much time here for the rest of the evening.

—The changes this Bill proposes include changing the wording to reflect the Government's decisions on higher education funding, which I have said before are pedantic and churlish and unnecessary, making more workable the rules on authorised persons, enabling students to expedite appeals, and generally improving the administrative mechanisms and wording of the Act. As I said before, we do not take real exception to that and, accordingly, will not oppose the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: We have moved this second reading amendment condemning the Government for its inability to appreciate the special needs for assistance of students from rural areas, a matter about which I spoke for nearly 10 minutes. We have moved it because of the turmoil caused by the Government's policies on and administration of the assistance for students in higher education institutions. I have been dealing with the question of student assistance and higher education institutions by talking about amalgamations and profiles, all of which affect students and the institutions. Since you, Mr Deputy Speaker, have given me guidance on this, I touch very briefly on another area that is affecting adversely students and student assistance. What the Government is doing with research is taking money away--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Deakin is trying the patience of the Chair.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, this Bill seeks to amend the Student Assistance Act 1973, which gives the statutory basis for Austudy and postgraduate awards. When I say to you that the principal Act, which this Bill amends, deals with postgraduate awards, you will recognise how vital it is that we understand what is going on in research. The research area attracts students who are involved in postgraduate courses. The Government is taking money away from the universities, research and postgraduate students.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill forms the basis for postgraduate awards. The Government will give that money to a politically controlled group called the Australian Research Council, which will hand out research funds on a political, and not a scientific, basis. In terms of assistance for students, clearly what will happen to research will affect students very unfavour- ably. In order to overcome this difficulty and satisfactorily resolve the question of postgraduate awards, we would scrap the guidelines for the Australian Research Council, reduce bureaucratic interference and award research grants on the basis of competitive excellence-not on the basis of nebulous and rapidly changing government perceptions of national priorities.

The Student Assistance Act 1973 not only provides the basis for Austudy and postgraduate awards but also is part of the whole network of the way in which the Government is dealing with students and assistance to students. In that context, the Government's so called graduate tax, its higher education contribution scheme, has a very deleterious effect on students and student assistance. It is a strange anomaly that on the one hand we are debating a Bill that amends the statutory basis for Austudy and postgraduate awards and seeks to streamline the process and make it more effective and therefore give students more benefit in terms of appeals and so forth, and on the other hand the Government is introducing a punitive graduate tax. It seems quite anomalous that on the one hand the Government is seeking to do things to make it easier for students and yet, on the other, it is acting deleteriously in terms of students and student assistance.

This is the most publicised area of the Government's changes to higher education. It is a system-again inconsistent with this Bill-which, though it purports to be fair, has already, at this early stage, been shown to be filled with anomalies and inequities. It discourages postgraduate work. I remind you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the Student Assistance Act forms the basis for postgraduate awards. Because of the number of years it takes higher education students to get through to the postgraduate and research levels, the obligation that they build up over that period, which may be as much as $10,000, $12,000 or even $15,000, will discourage students from going on to postgraduate work and indulging in research work-all of which is vital for the future of this country.

We have to do more research work. We have to be more attuned to what is happening in science. The Government has decimated the science and research communities with its policies, and by cutting down the funds to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, by taking money away from the higher education institutions and giving it to this nebulous Australian Research Council. When we are debating this Bill, which forms the basis of postgraduate awards, it seem incredible that other Government policies are actively discouraging students from going on to postgraduate work.

We propose a system of awards, scholarships, charges and loans which will be more favourable to students and institutions. Our policy is to open up the system and allow it to react to market forces, for it to be marked by productive competition and corresponding excellence of achievement. We want a system of student driven enrolment that provides choice for the students and competition between institutions. Although we do not object to the changing of phrases and the other minor changes in this Bill, the Government, in this Bill, has completely failed to address the difficulties that exist in higher education institutions, the difficulties that arise with Austudy and the difficulties that arise with isolated children.

The Government's policy indicates that it has no faith in higher education institutions, it has no faith in our students, it does not understand the proper need for student assistance and it has no faith in our leading academics. It thinks that the only way to run higher education is to force the institutions to teach what it wants them to teach through the profiles; amalgamate them so that there are fewer to deal with and they are easier to manipulate; amalgamate them under threat, under coercion of less funds; syphon off research funds, which will affect postgraduate students and, hence, the whole system of postgraduate awards to which this Bill refers; and centralise control in a bureaucracy here in Canberra that has control over everything that goes on in the higher education system.

I conclude by contrasting what the Government is trying to do in higher education with what the coalition will do in government-that is not too far away. In addition to reviewing thoroughly the rules and administration of Austudy, the coalition will restore autonomy to all higher education institutions, dismantle the centralised bureaucracy, abolish the profiles, withdraw the arbitrary requirements for amalgamations, stimulate healthy competition between the institutions, modify the policy guidelines of the centralist Labor Government of the Australian Research Council, maintain through the 1989-91 triennial system the number of places provided in the 1988 Budget, provide the institutions with funds to allow the grant of national education scholarships and allow those scholarships to no less than 25 per cent of the holders of the awards.

We would abolish Labor's $1,800 a year, indexed graduate tax and replace it with an annual tuition charge of $600, to be paid by the non-scholarship students directly or through a loans scheme. We would permit institutions to offer additional places on any basis they saw fit. We would facilitate commercial loan arrangements for those students who wished to borrow the amount of their obligations to the institutions so that payments could be made. In sharp contrast to what this Labor Government is trying to do in terms of discouraging postgraduate students and centralising control of higher education, we would open the whole system out so there was a much broader choice for the students and much wider diversity and competition between the institutions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I still do not have a copy of the amendment, so it is difficult to address its contents. I found the contribution of the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) amusing but erroneous. It did not really contribute to the debate. The honourable member referred to this debate being brought on when it was. Had he had his wits about him, he would have had his amendment drafted and he would have been in the House at six o'clock; but he was not. He was absent without leave. That is why this debate was brought on at eight o'clock. It was not because the Government failed to have business to put before the House. It was because the honourable member for Deakin did not have his amendment prepared.

SPEECH.PARA: As the honourable member said, this legislation makes minor changes to the Student Assistance Act. It is important to recognise why the changes are necessary, what this Government has done in the area of student assistance and what the results of that have been. For example, in 1982 under the Fraser Government, $188.3m was expended on student income support. The Labor Government, since coming to office, has more than tripled this, assisting students in 1988 at a cost of over $720m. That is something like four times the amount of money put on the deck by the Opposition when it was in office. Under the Liberals, less than 116,000 students were assisted in 1982. In six years this Government has more than doubled that figure, assisting over 285,000 young people to the end of 1988.

Particular attention has been paid to school retention rates. This Government has made it its purpose to attract young people to stay at school and to avail themselves of the educational opportunities that are required to take this country into the next century. By way of comparison, school retention rates for year 12 in 1983 were 36 per cent. In 1988, after five years of this Government, that proportion had been increased to 58 per cent. The contribution of honourable members opposite when they were in government pales in comparison with the efforts made by this Government to increase school retention rates and provide educational opportunities for all sections of the community.

Yesterday the House had before it the affirmative action legislation. It addressed the needs of women in education. It highlighted the effectiveness of this Government's policy in the retention rates for girls at year 12. The difference in rates between Austudy and the unemployment benefit is considered by this Government to be a serious anomaly, contributing to the disincentive to continue with further education. This is being addressed progressively and from 1989 Austudy and Abstudy and rates for special disadvantaged groups have been increased to the equivalent of the single rate of unemployment benefit. These special groups include long term pensioners and beneficiaries for six out of the last nine months, Aboriginal people and migrants undertaking special English courses.

The Government is committed to increasing gradually the level of Austudy to the level of the unemployment benefit for all students as the Budget circumstances permit. In the last Budget the Government lifted the parental income threshold from $16,000 to $16,950 and the personal income threshold from $2,000 to $3,000 so that more students may take advantage of maximum benefits. Since the introduction of these changes in the last Budget, there has been an increase of around 27 per cent in the number of recipients of Austudy and 24 per cent more applications were received in 1988 than in 1987. That is an effective measure of the contribution that this scheme is making in assisting those young people seeking education.

The decentralisation of the Austudy administration to Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) offices around the country will ensure that there is greater accessibility to information and assistance, particularly-for the benefit of honourable members opposite-for those living in rural areas. The Government is aware that there are anomalies and it hopes to address these anomalies as economic circumstances permit. These anomalies include the restrictive limit of $500, with dollar for dollar reduction, applied to educational assistance such as scholarships and bursaries. One-off prizes are now exempt from the personal income assessment, as are scholarships intended to be up-front payments of the higher education contribution charge; the provision of assistance to young homeless students during the six weeks qualifying period; the workload concessions for disabled students; tightening the process of transfer from unemployment benefit to Austudy; and the eligibility difficulties for some students from non-English speaking backgrounds. To assist in ironing out such anomalies the Government is looking at simplifying the student assistance regulations, incorporating a plain English text.

I was somewhat amused by the contribution by the honourable member for Deakin. He said-and I think I have the quote right-there was widespread support for the Opposition's higher education policy. That is laughable. I remind you, Mr Deputy Speaker, the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles) and the honourable member for Deakin of a quote from the Australian Financial Review of 24 February referring to opposition from the Vice-Chancellors Committee to the Opposition policy. The article read:
The new chairman of the committee, Professor Brian Wilson, supported the Government's line, saying the first priority `should be to support the public system'.
In my own electorate I have a student union which put out a press release recently which said:
The Northern Territory University Students Union today warned students not to be fooled by the Liberal/National party's Tertiary Fees Policy released yesterday.

University Student Union Vice-President Michael Parker has attacked the policy as a cunning trick to introduce full Tertiary Fees upon students already suffering under the Tertiary Tax. Mr Parker said, `The Liberals' and Nationals' policy will mean that students will be paying a Fee of between $600 and $9,000 every year before they start'.

That is the reality. Members of the Opposition know that they are going to have full fee paying students. That is the reality. Members of the Opposition are not prepared to accept that it is the reality, nor are they prepared to admit it to the Australian population. As a result, thousands of students will be excluded from tertiary education, and they know that that is the reality. The press release continued:

The Liberal/National plan to allocate 25 per cent of existing places as Fee exempt is also fraught with faults. It would see Fee exempt places not going to students on the basis of need but at the discretion of the individual institutions . . .
The policy will also reduce the funds available to Public Tertiary Institutions by not increasing the current level of funding and also dispersing it to private institutions, such as Bond University.

That also is the reality. Let us go to what the Opposition spokesman, the honourable member for Deakin, said. Let me address a couple of the points that he made. The fee that would need to be imposed on higher education students if the Government were to meet its commitments to growth in the higher education sector, without increasing its own outlays and without contribution of students through the higher education contribution scheme, would be enormous-far more than the $600 touted by the Opposition. In the final year of this triennium, 1991, the Government's legislative commitment to higher education is $547.7m greater than the figure for 1988 in real terms.

Most of this increase is to be funded from increases in Commonwealth spending on this area, but a small part will be raised from contributions from students. Ultimately, students will be contributing about 20 per cent of the costs of their courses through the higher education contribution scheme. By 1991, it is projected, there will be some 400,000 students in the system. Assuming that, say, 25 per cent of these students were exempt from the payment of fees through scholarships or some other means, then in order to make up the $547.7m without extra government funding, each one of the remaining 75 per cent of students would have to pay an annual up-front fee of more than the $1,800 a year of this higher education contribution charge. That is the reality.

Opposition members continually harp on about fiscal constraint and lowering government expenditure, but time and again they come into this House making statements or bringing up policy initiatives which will mean further government expenditure. This is just another example. It is clear that, if 25 per cent of students are non-paying students, the rest will have to pay for them. What about the 25 per cent of non-paying students? At present 40 per cent of all tertiary students get Austudy. The Opposition intends to provide support for only 25 per cent. Where does that leave the rest?

TALK.START.PARA: —That is exactly correct.

—Yes, it is exactly correct. Opposition members seek to make a direct cut in Commonwealth assistance. They are embarrassed by the facts. Each student, regardless of whether part time or full time, internal or external, whether receiving Austudy or not, would have to pay more up-front than is required through the higher education contribution scheme, which of course provides income-contingent pay later arrangements. That is the reality. Opposition members do not like it, they do not want to accept it, and they will not be honest with the Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has recently claimed that it can match the Government's commitment with a fee of $600. The honourable member for Deakin has guaranteed that the fee will not be increased or even indexed under a coalition government, yet the Opposition's fiscal policy is for reductions in government expenditure. There is a huge credibility gap. That credibility gap is even larger when one considers the funds that would be siphoned off into the private sector under the Opposition's policy to support private tertiary institutions, such as the Bond University. The impact on the public education system would be catastrophic. There is a very simple way of looking at this credibility gap. In current dollar terms, the higher education contribution scheme when fully operational will raise over $500m. The $600 fee proposed by the Opposition would raise no more than $170m. Who are Opposition members trying to fool when they say that they will not jack up the fee? What is the reality? The honourable member for Deakin said that the Opposition would retain its commitment to the number of places announced in the Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Earlier the honourable member for the Northern Territory drew my attention to relevance. I now draw his attention to relevance.

—I conclude by saying that we are talking here about people on Austudy having to pay more as a result of the Opposition's higher education policy. That is clear, and the evidence is before us. The Opposition's scheme would raise $170m. The reality is that Austudy students must pay. Some 25 per cent of students will have free places-no more than 25 per cent-and 40 per cent of current students receive Austudy. One does not have to be too sharp to work it out. The scholarships to which the Opposition refers will not be based on need. And who will they go to? They will go to the Opposition's friends in the private universities. That is the reality, and Opposition members know it. The Opposition has not got a rational approach to education policy, it does not have a rational response to this Government's educational initiatives, and as a result will be rejected at the next general election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carlton The Hon J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I begin my speech I would like to correct a complete misapprehension of the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon). I notice that he was actually down on the Australian Labor Party list to speak on the Geneva Conventions Amendment Bill but not on the Student Assistance Amendment Bill. I can only conclude that, because the other debate was curtailed, he was given a speech to read which he did not understand, because the Labor Party has to stick to its spoils program. He had to have his speech, but he seems to have spoken on the wrong Bill.
—Order! The honourable member for Mackellar might address himself to the matter before the House and not reflect on other members.
—Well, I am going to reflect not on the integrity-
—You most certainly will not reflect on any other members.
—I am not going to reflect on the integrity of the honourable member, but I will reflect on his arguments, which is within the Standing Orders. There is no question about that.
—You shall not make reflections upon individuals and you might address the matter before the House, which is the Student Assistance Amendment Bill and the amendment which you have seconded.

—Yes. I am going to point out, within Standing Orders, that the honourable member was totally confused between Austudy and scholarships. He said that the Opposition policy allowed for 25 per cent of students in higher education to have free education, which is true, and the Labor Party provides no free education under its policy for anybody, and that is correct. Then he said that currently 40 per cent of students get Austudy which, of course, is for a living allowance and not for fees. He said that therefore, under the coalition policy, the difference between 40 per cent and 25 per cent would disadvantage a whole number of students.

SPEECH.PARA: He is clearly mixing apples and oranges, quite different matters. Scholarships are totally different from Austudy which is a living allowance. The scholarship ensures that those students will not have to pay the fee. That is either deceitful or just a total misapprehension of what we are talking about, and I have to correct that before I say anything else. Tonight's debate is about student assistance. We are assisting students to enter into and complete their tertiary education. We are talking specifically about higher education in universities and in colleges of advanced education.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, we are not. It is secondary as well.

—We are talking about secondary education as well, but the main impact of the debate at the moment is on tertiary education, because that is the area where people have to pay the higher education contribution; that is where they have to pay the graduate tax. That is where the principal bite is at the moment. That is really where the focus of the debate is. The way in which the Labor Party has been assisting students is to require all of them to pay $1,800 minus 15 per cent up front as a fee, or it assists them by saying, `You do not have to pay that right now, but you can repay it when you go into the work force by paying higher tax'. In other words, the students can pay it back indexed so it will cost more than $1,800 later on through the tax. That is the higher education contribution scheme, and that is the way the Labor Party is currently assisting students.

SPEECH.PARA: As I pointed out at the time this Bill was introduced by the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan), this was a severe disadvantage to students in families which were poor or in families which had no previous experience of higher education and perhaps had less motivation to look at it and knew less about it. Therefore it was a disincentive to the very kinds of people we are trying to get into higher education. We are trying to extend the opportunities for a broader group within the population to get into higher education, and that is an objective which is shared by both sides of the House. I argued at the time the higher education contribution scheme-the graduate tax-was brought in that by applying it to everybody it would be a severe disincentive in those families where there was no previous experience of higher education or where there was extreme hardship. I argued very strongly about this from my own experience, because I came from such a family. I had the advantage of a Commonwealth scholarship. I came from a family which had no prior knowledge of higher education, and I came to a university without knowing anything about it. I think the chances of my having got there without there being a Commonwealth scholarship available would have been extremely small. So when I talk about student assistance, I talk about it from personal experience. Because of the means test applied to my parents' income, I was also given a living allowance under the Commonwealth scholarship, so I do believe I know something of what I am talking about.

The Labor Party has introduced the scheme on grounds which were generally supported. In other words, it was said that students that benefited from higher education should be required to make some contribution towards the additional employability they might have as a result of their higher education. There was no doubt that there was a public benefit in higher education, but there was also a personal benefit. The argument put forward by the Minister, when he talked about the new scheme, was that because there was a personal benefit, in addition to the public benefit, it was reasonable for the student to make a partial contribution.

I actually accept that argument. I do not have any difficulty with it. However, if we are talking about student assistance, which is the subject of tonight's debate, we have to look at the circumstances of the students that front up to these particular requirements. We have to work out ways of assisting them into higher education, and of helping them to remain there. These ways must have some relevance to their personal situations, or to the situations of their families. That is what we are talking about tonight. The Bill makes some changes which are useful in this direction and for that reason the Opposition supports it. The Opposition has moved an amendment which is critical of the Government's administration of assistance. It is within that context that I wish to address my remarks. The higher education contribution scheme requires that students have a liability of $1,800 for a full year of a course. They can meet that requirement, either by paying the $1,800 minus 15 per cent discount up front, or they can sign a contract with the Government, which enables the Government to deduct the indexed amount over a period once those students go into employment. The Opposition opposed that scheme when it was introduced, not on the ground of the basic principle of students making a contribution, but on the ground that the general application of the higher education contribution was a severe--

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Mackellar will address himself to the Student Assistance Amendment Bill and his amendment, not to matters dealing with the higher education charge.

—It is impossible to talk about assistance to students without talking about the context within which that assistance is required. If there is an $1,800 contribution required of students, and there is obviously a need for assistance to students in that regard, it forms part of the argument. I understand perfectly the earlier arguments about relevance and I have taken those into account in the construction of my speech. However, without talking about the barriers over which students have to jump in order to get into higher education and stay there, one cannot legitimately discuss the plans of the Government to assist students.

—As I have said to other speakers before, honourable members can illustrate their arguments by referring to other matters, but the burden of one's argument needs to be about the matter that is before the Chair. Relevance has been raised on a number of occasions in this debate and in the instance, because of the raising of that point of relevance, it is necessary for us to keep the debate along those lines.

—Having heard the earlier discussions on that matter and your interventions, Mr Deputy Speaker, and the points of order taken, I was more than usually attentive, more than most people-and I have been here the whole time since the start of the debate. I did not interject more than twice. I took those factors into account when constructing my speech. In fact, I made a number of amendments to my speech, so that I would remain within the Standing Orders of the House.
—I am pleased to see the honourable member for Mackellar is assisting the Chair.

—I always try, Mr Deputy Speaker. Sometimes I am tested, almost beyond measure, but I try very hard. I believe-and I think this point is quite legitimately within the Standing Orders of the House-that it is important to point out the alternative proposals of the Opposition with regard to assistance to students. It is a matter of strategy and tactics of this Government during Question Time, when its members have an advantage under Standing Orders and have 10 minutes to our half a second and during other debates when they can take advantage of Standing Orders in respect of interjections and so on, to parrot, over and over again, the claim that the Opposition has no idea and no policies. We are told that during the general debates in the House it is possible for the Opposition to put forward its alternative policies under the subject matter being discussed at the time. We are told that during every Question Time. Madam Speaker lectures us on that day by day. Therefore, I am taking the opportunity tonight on this matter of student assistance-
—Order! I do not think the honourable member should reflect upon the Speaker. He should withdraw that remark in case it is construed by some to be a reflection on the Speaker.
—I think it is perfectly within the Speaker's legitimate area of authority to lecture the House on Standing Orders, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—It might help the debate if you withdraw it and then we can continue.
—What am I asked to withdraw?
—It might be inopportune to say that the Speaker lectures the House on matters.
—There is no question of a lecture in this case on the higher education contribution charge, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—You might withdraw that and then we can proceed. It will help everybody.

—I will help you, Mr Deputy Speaker, by withdrawing that. I would like to refer to the alternative set of proposals by the Opposition on student assistance matters. At the heart of our proposals is the objective of widening participation in higher education. A parallel set of objectives is to release the institutions from the yoke of government interference and to provide them with the sustenance they need to determine their own destinies without bureaucratic interference.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not speak about the latter set of objectives. I have cut that out of my speech because it would be out of order under the present rules for me to mention it. With regard to student assistance, instead of having the $1,800 higher education contribution charge-the graduate tax-and a very lengthy requirement to repay it by way of the taxation system or, alternatively, an up-front payment of $1,530, which I think is the current requirement, we propose to introduce a tuition fee of $600 which would apply to every student. This scheme would have the following offsets: the first one-this will assist students in a very material way-is that 25 per cent of the places will be free, because the institutions will be allowed to award a minimum of 25 per cent of the places without a fee being imposed. I think the institutions will accept the very new and important discipline of deciding who will be given these free places. This will not be done on the basis of a general national scholarship, because all the prospective medical and legal students who apply to enter universities in Sydney and Melbourne would win all the scholarships as they get the highest school results. Each institution would have its own set of objectives in regard to which students ought to be admitted.

I think the general approach of the university and college administrations will be to administer such schemes wisely. In the past they administered scholarship schemes. Some of those schemes have become so small that they are only in place in an embryonic fashion. I think it will be an important new responsibility for institutions to administer the 25 per cent free places component to make sure that they are distributed equitably. I have great confidence in those who run the institutions, advised by student groups, lecturers, and the various bodies which deal with student assistance within universities-people who handle housing, personal problems, student problems and so on-being able to work out schemes which are equitable and humane. This will remove the barriers to students from disadvantaged families which currently exist under the Dawkins scheme. That will be a very important advance in this area.

The second important contribution that can be made to student assistance is to encourage private bodies, statutory authorities and government departments which need particular skills to provide scholarships and thus pay the $600 fee on behalf of students. That is already being provided for under our policy; I must say that it is done under the Labor Party's policy. Nurses will be covered under a Commonwealth-State arrangement-in other words, the $600 fee for nurses will be paid by the State governments. The New South Wales Education Department has indicated that it will provide the equivalent of scholarships for teacher trainees.

I believe that companies which are anxious to employ graduates of colleges and universities will come forward with $600 scholarships. I also believe that statutory authorities such as metropolitan water, sewerage and drainage boards, electricity commissions and so on that are interested in taking on students will provide scholarships. I believe that the major companies will provide them. Further, I believe that local communities that are interested in the development of their communities and regions will provide them. I can see the possibility of Lions clubs, Rotary and other groups providing scholarships. I can see a whole raft of private or semi-private scholarships in addition to the taxpayer funded scholarships which the institutions will make available to 25 per cent of students. So I would see a larger percentage of students being assisted.

The remaining fees would be paid directly by the students with money derived from whatever means. But, in order to ensure that nobody is denied a place because of an inability to get a free scholarship or because of a lack of support from parents, companies, statutory authorities or whatever, a Liberal-National government will facilitate, by government guarantee or other means, commercial loan arrangements with generous repayment periods for those students who wish to borrow the $600 to be paid to an institution. This will ensure that no prospective student is denied access to higher education because of inability to meet his contribution towards tuition costs.

Let me contrast the assistance being given to students by the Government and the assistance that would be given by a coalition government to enable students to participate and remain in higher education. The Labor Party has imposed a blanket charge of $1,800, less a 15 per cent discount for an up-front fee, which brings the charge down to roughly $1,530. Alternatively, a student can opt for a lifelong charge or less, depending on what is earned, paid through the tax system with an indexed $1,800 having to be paid back for each year of study. Under a Liberal-National government, a $600 charge would be applied to all initially, with a minimum of 25 per cent of students selected by the institutions being given a free $600 scholarship. In addition, a series of private or semi-private scholarships would increase the number of free places. Students who could not find $600 from their own resources, from their parents or whatever, could possibly take advantage of a guaranteed loan arrangement with generous repayment provisions. As a result, nobody will be denied access.

That is a far better scheme than the Labor Party's scheme. It also has the additional advantage that the money received from the fee would go directly to the institution that earns it. It would not go into a special fund in the Commonwealth Treasury, as does the higher education contribution charge. Of course, the fee would be received immediately in the year the tuition is given. We would not be dealing with some kind of delayed process which used the taxation system to collect the higher education charge that is then paid into a Treasury account.

The Liberal-National program for student assistance is clearly better designed-it is better for the students and it is better for the institutions. All we have to do is explain it to rebut the kind of obfuscation and misrepresentation employed in this House tonight by the honourable member for the Northern Territory. I have absolutely no worries that this policy will be fully supported when it is looked at and read by students in the institutions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon Mr E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), who opened this debate for the Opposition, spoke bravely but revealed his inability to comprehend the complexities of higher education in our nation as we prepare to enter the twenty-first century. The honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) spoke persuasively but with some unease, I suspect, causing a suspicion that he had no real belief in the arguments he presented. I reject their nonsense claims that this Government has catered inadequately for educational assistance for rural youth. Our record of success surpasses the Opposition's wildest dreams of what it could hope to achieve were it to gain the confidence of the electorate. Our policies for tertiary education have caused ripples of discontent, certainly. Some Melbourne University students-a vocal minority of the university student body-yesterday demonstrated against the higher education fee. That was an example of the greedy trying to mislead the needy. The majority of students, parents and academics have praise for the Hawke Government's educational philosophy.

SPEECH.PARA: I remember my education odyssey well enough and the hardships my parents and I faced. Before the honourable member for Mackellar, having made a rather soft presentation, leaves the chamber, let me rebut this nonsense about scholarships. He may well have received a Commonwealth scholarship and gone to university, but what about those people who, having received payments for 10 months of the year, did not have parents who were sufficiently wealthy for them to fall back on during the two months when they received no payments? Did the honourable member for Mackellar ever work as a railway station assistant cleaning out latrines? Did he ever have to become a call boy-that is an interesting term-at a railway workshop, calling in demolition and emergency crews? Let us not talk about scholarships. I suspect that the honourable member for Mackellar may have come from a wealthier background than I did.

Let me go back to students' needs and the lot of students in a period when we had a conservative government in this country. The richest 10 per cent of students were getting an average of $35 per week for education purposes. What were the poorer 10 per cent of the population getting? Those poorer kids had an average of $3.50 per week spent on them-one-tenth of what the children from the better class families were receiving. The Liberal and National parties seek to perpetuate an unjust system. They seek to perpetuate a policy which results in the poor subsidising the rich.

Turning to tertiary students' needs, let me take the Hunter, a working class area, as an example. Five per cent of people in my electorate have tertiary qualifications. What is the percentage in electorates such as Kooyong or Bradfield or Ryan, which are represented by conservative members? We find that 25 per cent of the people in those electorates have tertiary qualifications. We should ask ourselves when students most need assistance. I have had no trouble selling the higher education fee in my electorate. When students come to me I say to them, `You are paying an administrative fee. What would you rather do? Would you rather pay $5.50 per week at the time of your greatest need, when you have the backside out of your trousers, or $7 or $8 a week when you are earning $22,000 a year?'. Overwhelmingly, the reply is, `Gosh, that is not a bad deal. I find it very difficult now to find the $5.50 a week for the administration fee but certainly $7 or $8 a week will be no great impost upon me when I am earning $22,000 a year'. So we must destroy some of the nonsense arguments that are being presented by those who sit opposite.

The purpose of the Student Assistance Amendment Bill is to make a number of minor changes to the Student Assistance Act, which provides the legislative basis for Austudy and the postgraduate award scheme. In 1987 the Hawke Labor Government introduced Austudy as the main scheme for community-wide student assistance. Austudy replaced the former tertiary education assistance scheme, the adult secondary education scheme and the secondary allowances scheme. Essentially, Austudy gives assistance to students from low income families or disadvantaged backgrounds to enable them to complete their secondary education and to undertake higher education.

I draw attention to the fact that approximately 58 per cent of students now complete their year 12 education. Contrast this figure with the record of the previous coalition Government, under which only 36 per cent of students completed their secondary education. Under the coalition Government fewer than 116,000 students received education assistance. But this Government, since coming to office, has more than doubled the number of students receiving assistance. There were over 285,000 students receiving assistance at the end of 1988 and the number is still growing. I think most people would agree that the Government's record speaks for itself.

Let us look at expenditure on the Austudy scheme. The 1988-89 Federal Budget committed a massive $785.5m to Austudy. All up, the Federal Government's commitment to the education sector has risen from $438m in 1986 to $840m this year. Let us contrast that figure with the 1982 coalition Government's expenditure of a lousy $188m of student income support. No wonder honourable members opposite sink low in their seats. Again the record speaks for itself.

It is worth pointing out that this Government, since coming to office, has more than tripled student income support. That is what this Bill is all about-assistance for students. Total outlays for student assistance are expected to exceed $1 billion by 1999. In 1989 it is estimated that Austudy assistance will be provided to some 42 per cent of tertiary students and 40 per cent of secondary students aged 16 and over. When this Government came to office in 1983 it was clear that Australia needed a highly skilled and adaptable work force in order to became internationally competitive. It recognised that, by international standards, Australia fell short in its knowledge of new techniques and the supply of skilled personnel. The Hawke Government has sought to address this shortcoming by encouraging our young people to stay on at school to complete their secondary education and then to undertake higher education or participate in work skills training programs.

TALK.START.PARA: —To keep them off the dole queue.

—Yes, we have got them off the dole queue. We have created one and a quarter million jobs since we came to government. Yet when the Opposition was in government 500 jobs were lost per day. What a proud record we have in that field. I am glad that the honourable member interrupted. Maranoa is a very wise electorate and it sends wise members to this place. I am so proud that the honourable member assisted me. The points I have mentioned on student retention rates give a clear indication that the Government's strategy is working and working very well.

SPEECH.PARA: When Austudy was introduced in 1987 it was not without its teething problems. Delays in students receiving their first Austudy payment were caused by the changeover from the tertiary education assistance scheme and computerising the system. But fortunately the problems in that first year were rectified to a large extent and there has been a marked improvement in the time taken to process applications. I welcomed the announcement in the 1988-89 Budget that from 1989 Austudy payments to students over 21 were being brought into line with unemployment and sickness benefits. Previously, people on social security benefits were precluded from undertaking full time study to enhance their career opportunities because of the difference in the Austudy payment and the social security benefit. In my electorate of Hunter many people were desperately trying to improve their career opportunities but they were not able to make ends meet on the Austudy payment. Therefore, they had to undertake part time courses or maybe go to university or technical and further education colleges only one night a week so that they still qualified for their social security benefit. Not surprisingly, these people are delighted with the increase in the Austudy payment as they are now able to undertake full time study without being financially disadvantaged.

Even this excellent move by the Government to increase Austudy payments this year has brought its own set of problems. I am pleased that the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan) has been quick off the mark to recognise that there are still a few bugs in the system. He is now looking at ways to iron out these problems and generally improve the system. The move to decentralisation is a good one, particularly in rural areas with selected Commonwealth Employment Service offices now able to deliver a range of information about Austudy and Abstudy. However, in my electorate of Hunter, our local CES office of Maitland was inundated with requests for Austudy application forms and quickly exhausted its supply. The Maitland CES was unable to secure additional supplies quickly. I had at least one constituent each day come into my office for an application form. This continued for some time because supplies were depleted. Although this delay was no cause for joy, it has now been rectified. There should be no recurrence. But there was obviously a substantial underestimate of the number of application forms supplied to CES regional offices. No doubt this will be a one-off situation, with adequate supplies being on hand for future years.

I have also drawn the Minister's attention to the problem that has arisen when people notify their social security office that they are undertaking full time study. As a consequence their social security benefit ceases from the day the commence their course. There seems to be too great a gap between that time and the time they receive their first Austudy payment. One instance that comes to mind concerns a constituent who was retrenched from his job early last year. He was married with two children. He quickly realised that the only way to further his career prospects, obtain secure employment and have a better lifestyle for his family was to further his education. He was accepted into a course in about June 1988, but it took eight weeks for his Austudy application to be processed. Those bugs are still occurring, but the whole basis of the scheme is excellent and is receiving overwhelming endorsement from the electorate.

Although we have ranged rather widely in this debate I have tried to stick to the facts. I have not debated the higher education fee. However, as I said earlier, the Minister is moving quickly to iron out the bugs. I am sure that from now on we will have no more of these minor hiccups. I welcome the Minister's advice that as soon as economic circumstances permit a few remaining anomalies will be addressed. These include the restrictive limit of $500-with a dollar for dollar reduction-applied to educational assistance such as scholarships and bursaries. One-off prizes are now exempt from the personal income assessment, as are scholarships intended to be up-front payment of the higher education contribution scheme. The Minister is also examining the provision of assistance to young homeless students during the six-week qualifying period. Following the Burdekin report's revelations this is very pleasing indeed. I have a number of disabled students in my electorate of Hunter and I am pleased that the Government is looking at the question of workload concessions for disabled students.

This Government has a proud record in the education sector and is committed to gradually increasing the level of Austudy to the level of unemployment benefit for all students as Budget circumstances permit. I would also like to mention that in last year's Budget the Government lifted the parental income threshold for Austudy from $16,000 to $16,950, and the personal income threshold-the amount of income that people on Austudy can earn before losing part of their allowance-from $2,000 to $3,000. Other budgetary measures include a new Austudy and Abstudy assets test which will make student financial support much more equitable and will ensure that financial support goes to those most in need of help.

It is important to stress, once again, that by any fair assessment this Government has taken giant strides forward in the provision of assistance to higher education students. Since taking office in 1983, the Government has progressively improved the level of financial assistance to students from low income families and disadvantaged backgrounds, including Aboriginal and disabled students. It has substantially increased the level of funding to the education sector. It has faced the challenge and has acknowledged the responsibility of better equipping Australia to take its place in an increasingly competitive world.

In conclusion, I congratulate the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, the Hon. John Dawkins, and the Minister for Employment and Education Services, the Hon. Peter Duncan. By any estimation, their contribution has been outstanding. I am quite confident that in years to come people will look back on the Hawke Government's achievements in the field of education and applaud long and loud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr I.M.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the Student Assistance Amendment Bill 1989, which seeks to make a number of minor changes to the Student Assistance Act 1973, which Act provides the legislative basis for Austudy and the postgraduate awards scheme. Within the framework of the Budget Papers, assistance to students includes the isolated children's allowance. I will come back to that.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill seeks to modify the appeal procedures under the Student Assistance Act and will remove restrictions on students authorising someone else to act on their behalf in seeking a review of a departmental decision. It will also permit students to expedite their appeals to the Student Assistance Review Tribunal by waiving their right to receive background papers at least 14 days before the hearing. So very minor amendments are being put in place with this legislation.

The Bill will make some drafting changes to the provisions under the Act relating to Austudy. This allows members from both sides of the House, but particularly our side of the House, to question the recently introduced assets testing by the Labor Government of the revamped education assistance which the Federal Government wrapped up in a new package some two or three years ago. It put a new name on it and sold it as Austudy. Obviously, the Government has put a little more money into that. But, in typical fashion, with its socialist thinking and trends, the Labor Government has introduced an assets test on this allowance. As usual, anyone with a bit of capital in Australia is discriminated against by this Government.

The Government wonders why we have a balance of payments deficit of $1.5 billion a month and interest rates at 20 per cent. There are lots of families in the area I represent. The electorate of Maranoa, in south-west Queensland, is a very large and isolated area. It is very difficult for people in outlying areas to educate their children. They have to rely on boarding schools, particularly once the children get to secondary school stage. A number of parents have to send their children to boarding school for all their education unless they employ teachers or teach their children themselves by correspondence classes or School of the Air classes which operate throughout Queensland and inland Australia. We on this side of the House believe that, because of this assets test, those people are being totally discriminated against.

I do not believe that an income test should apply to education. All people pay tax. People on large incomes pay large amounts of tax and I do not see why they should not have some assistance to send their children to school. If they are denied that assistance, they are in effect paying tax twice: they pay it through the normal method of indirect or personal taxation and then they are asked to pay again because they are excluded from any assistance being offered. I must say that, under the isolated children's scheme, the first $989 is paid by the Federal Government. Of course, that is taxable. For students over the age of 16, that amount is added to their income for tax purposes. Obviously, not many students would be liable for tax as not many would receive income. But, if they do receive income, this Government, having given them assistance on the one hand, takes it away with the other. That approach is typical in a whole range of Government assistance measures. Such assistance is included in one's income and thus taxed. With bracket creep, the higher one's income the higher the amount of taxation. Under the tax system with which we are saddled, there is no adjustment for inflation. People move into a higher tax bracket and so pay more taxation.

State governments also pay some assistance to isolated children, but it is not enough to cover the cost. In my case, I send a child to a grammar school, which is in most cases cheaper than a number of boarding schools. It costs $2,500 a term just for the basic boarding and teaching fees. About half that amount is for boarding fees and the other half is for teaching fees. If one multiplies that by three, one is looking at about $8,000 a year. Then there is all the travel involved, although there is some travel assistance for students. But most parents who live in isolated communities have to pay large amounts for travel, and there are other associated costs. So I would estimate that it costs about $10,000 to educate a child who is not able to walk daily to what is usually a state school. Each State has its own education system. State schools have been provided for over 100 years now by the taxpayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are great schools.

—Most high schools are excellent. I find that, like most things in life, how good the school is depends on who the headmaster or headmistress is and on the quality of the school's administration. There are some excellent high schools in my electorate: at Chinchilla, Charleville, Cunnamulla, Goondiwindi-you name it. I also know of some excellent boarding schools. In some States, particularly in my own State of Queensland, agricultural colleges run boarding schools. But in most cases it is the churches that have become involved in running boarding schools. They do an excellent job. The Catholic Church has its own education system. It does an excellent job educating children throughout the States, not only at the primary level but also at the secondary level of education.

SPEECH.PARA: Unlike the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon), I do not believe that there is necessarily such a thing as an underprivileged child in Australia as far as education is concerned. The education system is universal. It is available to all. It is just a case of the Government putting in place systems and allowing people to make use of them. There is no excuse on the part of any government for any student not to have equal opportunity or equal access to the education system. That is the policy that we on our side of politics adopt. Our policy is to abolish the assets test on the isolated children's allowance. We also advocate the inclusion of a hardship clause in the assets test on Austudy. I believe that is how it should be, and I am sure that most parents listening to this debate tonight would agree with me.

It is amazing that the Labor Government excludes the family home from the capital gains tax but does not exclude it from the assets test. Some homes around Sydney Harbour are valued at $10m or $20m. I know I am taking an extreme example, but one can live in such homes in many suburbs in the capital cities of Australia, sock away one's income and build up one's asset in the family home. That is forcing up the price of the family home. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) decided to exclude the family home from the capital gains tax. He had a whim in a radio interview in Perth before an election-I cannot quite remember which election it was-and decided that the family home should be excluded. The result is a total distortion of the system.

We are opposed to the capital gains tax. We intend to abolish it and put in a system involving depreciation over a five-year period. But the Australian Labor Party, the socialists of this country, have excluded the family home from the capital gains tax. As I have said, they have built up a system whereby people can put all their income into their homes. But the family home is not excluded from the assets test. Rural Australians do not pour all their money into their homes-obviously they build reasonably good homes-because there is no incentive for them to do so. They pour money into their businesses. So they build up their farms, although it is difficult these days for them even to do that under this Government because the Government has abolished the depreciation allowances. The Government wonders why there is no investment taking place in this country. One only gets a 5 per cent investment allowance for most items, so it is pretty difficult.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is at record levels.

—That is nonsense; it has been running at record levels for the last six months. But since honourable members opposite have been in government it has been running at minus amounts. Why is the balance of trade running at a deficit of $1.5m a month if there is record investment? That is a lot of nonsense. How can anyone invest with interest rates at 18 or 19 per cent? It is just nonsense to think that investment is taking place.

SPEECH.PARA: One night here in the House $1 billion was wiped off the investment allowance. There is no investment allowance in our tax system at all. There is no encouragement in our tax system at all to invest in business. Those on the other side wonder why it is not happening. One wonders why Australia is going bankrupt. It is not hard to work out. No-one wants to invest in this country-except the Japanese. They are pouring money in because they have got money at 4 per cent. Under the investment guidelines the Government is operating, there is money coming in in bucket loads. The Japanese are building schools here. They wish to build specialised Japanese schools here to teach English. There is plenty of that going on in New South Wales because they are the sorts of schemes the Labor Government is encouraging.

I do not mind joint ventures but I am opposed to the 100 per cent investment that the present Government is allowing. Capital investment in Australia may have picked up in the last few months, but it has been abysmal until now and it will not last long because interest rates have gone to where they have. Interest is one of the biggest costs there is in business, although in business they are a tax deduction. But if one does not have the cash flow one does not have the tax deduction available to one.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I am getting a bit off the track, but in 1988-89 Government funding for the isolated children's allowance was $26.9m, down 17 per cent or $5.5m from the 1987-88 contribution, which was $32m.
