In 1988-89 Government education places for assistance to isolated children were down by 4,500 or 23 per cent. There are 4,500 children out there now who are not getting assistance. I was at Peak Downs electoral council at Capella last weekend where I was told that there were so many children staying away from boarding school that the school of the air system, the radio system that people there have to use to educate their children, is being clogged because there are not enough channels available and so people do not get a proper education. These are the sorts of problems and distortions which the Government puts in place once it introduces something like an assets test.

An amount of $3.2m has been transferred into Austudy. As a result, 4,500 children in remote areas of Australia will not be given education assistance under the Labor Government. These are facts and figures straight out of the Budget Papers, under student assistance. It is there in black and white for those on both sides of the House to read. I am sure the Labor Party does not want to know too much about it but that is the sort of system it has introduced. Of course, the Austudy assets testing is precluding many people from obtaining a decent education. There are no universities at Charleville that I know of, none at Roma, none at Goondiwindi, none at Birdsville. But if one happens to be a child who lives in one of those places one has to go 1,800 miles to university in Brisbane-because that is where the closest university to my electorate is. Such children need assistance. Families can have millions of dollars of assets, but if they have no cash flow, no cash income, they are expected by this Government to sell their assets.

That is what the Government is doing with overseas investment. It is selling off Australia, bankrupting the country and offering it to the highest bidders from wherever. Most of them are coming from Japan. We are being asked under this assets test to do exactly the same thing. The expected net market value of assets is the price expected once the assets are sold less any debts associated with the assets such as loans, mortgages, hire purchase agreements, et cetera. The Government is telling people that if they cannot meet their education costs, if they need to sell their assets to educate their children, it expects them to do that.

What is this country coming to? It is no wonder we are broke. These are the sorts of policies that this Labor Government has put in place. As I said previously, I believe that all children should get an education even without an income test, but I guess if we need to have an income test we probably would be prepared to face up to that. But to introduce an assets test on top of the income test which we have today is beyond the pale because it means that certain children are excluded from getting a reasonable education. I did not think that was what the Australian Labor Party was about. I do not know how rural Labor members feel. I do not know how the honourable member for Hunter and others feel about the sorts of policies that have been introduced by the Minister. I would imagine that they would find it pretty tough and awkward in their electorates when they are asked to explain why so many children do not have the same opportunities. That is what we are on about. It is tough for families to have to send away to school children of age five and onwards. Not only do parents have to break up families but also they have to struggle and do all sorts of things in order to get enough money together to pay the exorbitant costs that are now involved in giving children an education.

The isolated children's allowance (ICA) is income-tested and cuts off at $300,000. A 50 per cent allowance means that this limit can be extended to $600,000. But it is not difficult to reach that figure these days. Most businesses and farms are worth that sort of money. If one does not have the income because of droughts or whatever, it is very difficult to get the money that is needed to have one's children educated. I agree with the honourable member for Hunter that greater educational opportunities should be available to all children. All Australians should have equal opportunity.

Only last week Mrs Patricia Mitchell from the Isolated Children's and Parents Association was in Parliament House. The Association is very concerned that the children's allowances are in no way indexed. There is no guarantee that the allowances will continue, even at the reduced rate. The Association wants legislation to be enacted to guarantee that its members' children will continue to be eligible for this sort of assistance. The isolated children's scheme, which appears as a one-line entry in the Budget, has been allocated nearly $27m in 1988-89. Of course, as I mentioned, in 1987-88, $35m was allocated. There has been a reduction of $8m some of which has gone to Austudy.

I am sure that the Government would not take a private member's Bill on board. But I am looking at ways in which we can put in place some legislation which will guarantee ongoing assistance. This item should not be just a one-liner that can be wiped out of the Budget Papers.

TALK.START.PARA: —What will it cost?

—It will not cost any more than it is costing now. All we want to do is put into legislation a requirement that this assistance will continue to be available to children throughout Australia. At present, assistance is at the whim of the Treasurer each year. There is nothing to say that it should be given to help children.
—We are giving enough.
—I do not believe that the Government is giving enough because it has introduced an assets test on the isolated children's scheme as well as on Austudy. A lot of people are experiencing hardship.

SPEECH.PARA: Obviously there are very minor changes taking place, but many Australians are concerned. I hope that the Government looks seriously at the hardships that it has imposed on many families with the introduction of the assets test on Austudy and the isolated children's scheme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know what to make of the contribution by the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Ian Cameron). However, he raised a few points that can be responded to. He talked about abolishing the assets test and wondered why it imposed was in the first place. I can tell the honourable member that a number of people in my electorate from working class families on fixed incomes were upset because their children, who had to pay their fees in cash, attended schools or they were going to school or on to higher education institutions with the children of wealthier parents who were receiving Austudy. There was a basic inequality there. I suppose it always comes back to the way in which one measures income or wealth. The assets test is one way that the Government has come up with to make sure that we can more effectively target that money to where it is going. If all we are going to do is abolish the assets test on Austudy, then that inequality will be put back in and we will get people of substantial wealth adjusting their incomes so that they can get Austudy.
—You have got it now with the capital gains tax exemption.

—The honourable member for Maranoa does not know what he is talking about. He obviously has not been following what has been happening. He also talked about education in the country. I have sympathy for some of the points raised by the honourable member, certainly in regard to isolated children. When one looks at education in the country, one has to admit that there is a basic inequality in the distribution of incomes. Not everybody in the country is poor; there are a lot of rich people, and one has to ask oneself whether they keep their children at the local primary or secondary school. By and large, the answer is that they do not. What they do is send them down to the city. The effect of that on local education is that there are smaller class sizes, smaller schools and fewer offerings for those people who are left behind. If the Opposition had addressed those problems when it was in government or in its contributions here, we could perhaps say that it was thinking a little about what is happening to the quality of education in the country. But there is nothing about that. It is all about assets tests and a private member's Bill to make sure that people get as much money as they need and that it will not cost any more. We have heard all that. We have seen all the rubbery figures.

—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I point out to the House that there are many areas in Australia where there are no secondary schools and nowhere that children can get an education in those towns.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—There is no way that they would go to the nearest one either, which is the point I was making. I think it is fair to say, looking at education over the years, that up until quite recently we did not take education as seriously as we should have or as seriously as our trading partners did. The statistic that is always talked about is that in 1983 only 36 per cent of our young people finished high school, which was abysmally low. That was reflected right through our educational offerings. Less than 7 per cent of our young people were going on to a university education.

SPEECH.PARA: I was just talking about inequality in the bush. There is also inequality in the cities. As the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) put it, at university one could usually tell where a person came from by his postcode. It was education by postcode. Those people who happened to live in the better off areas were by and large the people who went to university and got the benefit of a degree. This Government is on about making sure that everybody has the opportunity, and the legislation before us tonight aims to do just that. The Government realises that not everybody can afford at the end of secondary school to stay on for a very expensive tertiary education. That is what Austudy is all about.

When one looks at the advances in education in this country, by and large they have been under Labor governments. The Whitlam Labor Government brought in Austudy. This Government has drastically expanded education, not only in universities and colleges of advanced education but also in technical and further education institutions and primary and secondary schools. Our policies have been aimed at making sure that education is expanded right across the board. Of course, one of the features of the previous Government's education policy was the need to import skills. It always found it easier to go overseas and bring in tradesmen than to train our own. This Government has adopted a very different policy of home grown skills training. Our training is now done in this country, as do all those countries that are going a lot better than we are.

The education system in 1983 reflected the economy-basically agrarian and no value added. The Government is changing that education system because there is massive change to the work force. One can tie in with the award restructuring that is going on the sort of educational offerings this Government is putting into place, in cooperation with the employers, the unions and the education providers of this country. One starts looking at getting out of the system all of those unproductive work practices.

On a number of occasions the Treasurer (Mr Keating) has pointed out to the House the investment in new plant and equipment coming into this country. We have to have people to run all that new plant and equipment. We have to have people to operate it and maintain it. That is what the Government's education system is aimed at doing. Once again, the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business quite rightly pointed out that in 1983 anyone who wanted to see an industrial museum had only to look at Australian industry. That was quite true. The plant and equipment we had belonged basically to the 1920s, we were importing our skills and we were not trading enough. The whole thing had to change.

TALK.START.PARA: —Our farmers are the most efficient in the world.

—The honourable member for Maranoa might have been happy with that system, but it was not good enough for us. I wish to talk about the expansion of higher education in this country. There are two basic ways of doing it. Substantial resources have to be put into higher education if it is to be expanded. We could have taken the necessary funds out of Consolidated Revenue and not made a charge on the students at all.
—You are against the Bond University; what are you on about?
—Mr Deputy Speaker, that is constant chatter.
—I will protect you in a moment. If the honourable member Maranoa does not remain silent, I will deal with him.
—The honourable member for Maranoa has a very penetrating voice. I am trying to think as I speak, but it is very hard with him babbling away.
—Get on with it, George, I thought you were a good parliamentarian.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Maranoa.

—As I said before we silenced the honourable member for Maranoa, in terms of expanding education we were confronted basically with the need to make a decision about whether to take the necessary money from tax revenue or to ask the students to make some contribution themselves. I have always been of the opinion that the students should make a contribution. There is absolutely no doubt that our society benefits from our education system, but there is also a personal benefit. I had that personal benefit quantified for me by the Parliamentary Library. I asked the Library to look at the expected lifetime earnings of people in different categories. The figures they came up with are all expressed in 1986 dollars, so honourable members can make a direct comparison between the lifetime earnings of those who go through the different strands of education and those with no education.

SPEECH.PARA: Labourers and related workers, people with few or no skills, can expect to earn $750,000 over their working lives. That figure jumps to $930,000 for people such as electrical tradesmen and for clerks-those who have received some formal training. For the university-educated such as natural scientists, building professionals and engineers, the figure jumps to $1.34m. For people in the health area, such as diagnosticians and treatment practitioners, it jumps to $1.5m. It can be seen that education does benefit the individual, and to ask individuals to pay back the $1,800 after they have received the benefit of that education seems to me to be a very fair and honest way of seeking a contribution from them.

There are no upfront changes to deter people from going into higher education. As I have pointed out, there is not much hope for anyone who does not take advantage of higher education, knowing the benefits that accrue to those attaining it. I do not think people have really sat down and thought through the benefits of having a higher education, as reflected in those figures. Certainly, if they did, a lot more people would want to get into higher education. I think that is happening now. A lot more people want to get into our universities.

As I said before, the alternative to that method of fund raising was to take the necessary funds from taxation revenue. I viewed it in this way: Either the recipients of the benefits of higher education were to make some contribution themselves or we were going to ask the vast majority of the Australian population, over 90 per cent of whom would never go near a university, to fund all university places. I thought it was a bit unfair to ask truck drivers trying to bring up families and buy houses on an income of less than $20,000 a year to pay higher taxes to help fund the expansion in universities. I fully support the Government's moves in this matter.

When one compares that with the Opposition's policy of a $600 up-front fee-as the Minister has pointed out-one sees that, even allowing for the money that that will generate, there will be a $500m shortfall. The obvious conclusion one would have to draw-it was drawn by the students on day one; the first day this policy hit the streets-is that that is only the tip of the iceberg. Once that policy is in and there is that shortfall from the funds, the obvious thing to do is increase it. It was not properly costed. The up-front charge, especially for people on low incomes, is a poor feature of the Opposition's policy and certainly one that we would not embrace. That is one of the reasons why we have condemned it.

When one takes the Opposition's figures on education and sees that it maintains that 25 per cent of students will get a free education, no one has any idea about how it is to be allocated. Will it go to the poorest 25 per cent of students? Will it go to country students? Will it go to all students? Will it be a bit of dog's breakfast as to where those students come from? I really do not know and neither does anybody else. When one looks at that 25 per cent and remembers that currently 40 per cent of students are eligible for Austudy, one comes to the conclusion that there will be a 15 per cent shortfall. So even on its own figures of free education for 25 per cent, it will not cover the students that are currently in need. That point should be made when viewing the Opposition's policy.

When looking at the way in which education in this country has been expanded one only has to go back-these figures have been used before but they are worth repeating-to the last year of the Fraser Government, when $188.3m was expended on student income support. In equivalent dollar terms $720m has been expended this year-a massive increase in student support. One would expect that because we have expanded tertiary education quite dramatically over that time. Even allowing for that growth, one can see that the income support going to each student has been raised dramatically. In the last year of the former Government, 116,000 students were assisted in their income support. In only six years, the Government has more than doubled this figure, assisting over 285,000 young people to the end of last year.

In one sense we cannot be too critical. The Opposition has at least thrown up a policy in this area. It was shot full of holes the first day not only by the Minister but also by the students, who said they would have nothing to do with it. But at least it has a policy out that we can have a look at. We can start costing it and come out with figures such as the ones I have just quoted. It will have to have policies in other areas that complement it. We have not even seen a taxation policy yet. How do students know how the taxation policy will tie in? What about the medical benefits? The whole area is related. At least under this Government Medicare covers their health insurance. The Opposition has to start explaining to the people of Australia how it would run this country in many areas.

The policies that have been thrown up by the shadow Minister for education, the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale), are not a very good start. For the reasons that I and other speakers have outlined, the Government's record stands in stark contrast to that of the Government that preceded it. I am sure that at the next election the Government will be returned and will carry on the good work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now that we have finished the previous debate on Medicare, we will get on to the subject of the Bill. I remind the House that we are tonight debating the Student Assistance Amendment Bill, which, among other things, does a number of things in relation to Austudy. I want to refer to the second reading speech of the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan) when introducing the Bill into the House of Representatives. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill will repeal the requirement that departmental assessors under the Act, referred to as `authorised persons', be ministerially appointed. This requirement gives unnecessary administrative complexity to the appointment of over 300 officers, very few of whom are at senior level. The Bill proposes instead that authorised persons be identified as officers whose departmental duties include making decisions on Austudy or postgraduate awards.

It is that section of the Bill to which I shall be addressing my speech this evening. The relevant clause is clause 4 (b), which includes definitions. The definition of `authorised person' is in the following terms:

``authorised person'' means an officer of the Department who is required or permitted by the duties of his or her office or, if he or she is acting in an office, of the office in which he or she is acting, to perform some or all of the functions, or excercise some or all of the powers, of an authorised person under this Act or the regulations;
The explanatory memorandum tells us that the expression `officer' is used in the new definition of `authorised person':

The latter definition needs to be consistent with the concept of `senior authorised person' in section 17 (5) of the Principal Act, i.e. `authorised person' needs to be limited to officers in the normal hierarchy of the Australian Public Service. Accordingly, the definition of `officer' is amended so as not to include employees in general, who would not necessarily come within that hierarchy.

So this section of the Bill is to make it a little easier to handle Austudy applications and the assessment of them. It is to widen it. It is to make certain information available to more people. The thing, we are told, at the moment is administratively too complex and we need more people available to do it who are doing other things as well, but every now and then they are going to do something in this Bill under this requirement. Today I addressed a question to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) and it was the Minister for Employment and Education Services who answered. I asked:

My question . . . relates to Austudy applications, which are means tested on the basis of parents' taxable income for the previous financial year. Why does his Department insist that original copies of taxation assessments be submitted with Austudy applications? Why will his Department not accept a simple statement of taxable income on the Austudy application form, as is the practice of the Department of Social Security, for example, in the implementation of the means test on the family allowance? What safeguards are there to prevent information on this assessment notice-for example, the tax file number-being made available to people who are not entitled to the information? What action has the Minister taken to apply the relevant provisions of the Privacy Act relating to tax file numbers to his Department's handling of these assessment notices?

In his answer the Minister slid right from under. I do not know whether he realised what the implication of that question was or whether he simply did not know the answer. The Minister for Employment and Education Services said:

Basically the reason why original documentation has been sought is that, unlike many other applications that are made across the Government for various types of benefits, Austudy essentially is a benefit that is applied for once a year and therefore is not regularly checked in the way that some other benefits are. Accordingly, we felt it desirable to ensure that when the application was put in the original documents should be sought so that there would be a minimisation of any chance of defrauding the scheme. Accordingly, we have sought to ensure that fraud of the scheme is kept to a minimum. There has been some concern about such things and in reviewing the arrangements during the past year we have ensured that the whole procedures are tightened up. This has been part of the tightening up that we have undertaken.

The Minister's entire concern is to tighten up in relation to fraud, which of course I would applaud, but he has had no concern at all for the Privacy Act, which has been a matter of some debate in this House today. There is no need for an applicant to submit an original of a taxation assessment form if fraud is the concern. For example, an applicant could submit a certified copy of a taxation assessment form, certified by a justice of the peace, which would be just as good. In fact, people are required to hand over the original of their taxation assessment form and hope that they get it back. That is the central point of what I will be talking about tonight.

There is no need, further, I would submit, for the taxation assessment notice to be submitted at all. I referred specifically in my question to the family allowance. It is in the same category as that described by the Minister. It is a once a year application form. It is not periodically reviewed throughout the financial year. Family allowance is assessed on the basis of taxable income in the previous year. On 1 July a person's income could reach $1m. It does not matter, it is what was the person's taxable income in the previous year. That is exactly the same position as for Austudy. People are not required to provide their taxation assessment notice when they apply for family allowance. There is a section on the form where they are required to state the amount of their taxable income for the previous year. The Department of Social Security makes whatever checks are necessary, presumably of the Taxation Office to guard against fraud. There is no reason why Austudy could not be handled in exactly the same way. Therefore, the Minister's answer in that respect is quite wrong. He did not answer my question and misrepresented what is possible. As I have said, it is not necessary in any event to require original documents. The Privacy Act has a direct relevance to this debate. I shall briefly refer to the relevant provisions and return to them towards the end of my speech. Guideline 3 of the Privacy Act says:

Tax file number recipients-in this case this is officers of the Department of Employment, Education and Training; they become recipients of the tax file number by virtue of having in their hands a taxation assessment-
shall take all reasonable steps in the circumstances to:
(a) introduce information handling procedures to protect the privacy of individuals in relation to their tax file number information;
(b) make staff aware of the rights of individuals to privacy in relation to their tax file number information . . .

That is what I was referring to further in my question today. The Minister said that there had been some concern and that procedures had been tightened up-and I shall come to that matter in a moment. Further, in guideline 3 one sees the statement:

Tax file number recipients holding tax file number information shall take all reasonable steps in the circumstances to ensure that security safeguards and procedures are in place to prevent unauthorised access to, modification or disclosure of, and loss of, such information, whether that information is stored in physical or electronic forms.

Tax file number recipients shall take all reasonable steps in the circumstances to ensure that access to records which contain tax file number information for authorised purposes is confined to persons who have a need for access to such information for the purpose of carrying out tax-related functions of the tax file number recipient.

I am not even sure whether this Bill complies with that guideline in widening, so that it is nice and easy for the Department, the number of people who will be handling the application forms with the attached taxation assessment. An expert would be able to answer whether the Bill does comply with the guidelines. Yesterday, certain information came to me. I want to relate a case in point about the handling by the Department of Employment, Education and Training of tax file number information. Another member's constituent, whom we will call the Smiths, received back the Austudy assessment of their son. Attached to it was the original tax file assessment notice of a constituent of mine, whom we will call the Browns. The Browns had put in an application for their daughter. So the Smiths received the assessment, presumably for their son-we cannot be sure because the wrong tax file assessment number is attached to it. The Smiths got the Browns' tax file assessment complete with tax file number. The Browns had received the assessment for their daughter-presumably the right one-with no tax file assessment notice attached to it. They did not have the Smiths' tax file assessment. The Smiths took this matter to their member of Parliament, expressing some anger. They had asked whether they could submit a certified copy rather than part with their original. However, the Department said no and insisted on the original-only the original would do. I say to the Minister that after the Privacy Act no review was done of departmental procedures, or that would not have happened for a start. The Smiths got back somebody else's assessment notice and the somebody else did not have theirs. They were advised to post the tax file assessment back to the Department. Yesterday the Browns received a notice in the mail of their tax file assessment in a plain brown envelope. There was no indication of where it came from. There was no covering letter saying, `We omitted to return this to you with your daughter's application'; nothing-just whack it in a plain brown envelope and hope nobody is the wiser.

The Minister's Department is in breach of the Privacy Act. I hope very much that my constituent pursues the course of action I suggested, namely, a complaint with a view to prosecution of the Department for its handling of that tax file assessment. In the meantime, the Smiths do not have theirs; nobody has theirs. It is on a desk somewhere, or in a wastepaper basket, in a file or in Heaven knows whose hands. Maybe the Joneses have got the Smiths' tax file assessment. Who knows? It still has not turned up as of today. Sloppy would be putting it kindly.

It was this Government that brought in the tax file number provisions for tax cheats. It is that action of this Government that means we have a Privacy Act, and thank God we do, which covers this very clearly and simply. There has been some reference to guideline 4 in the debate here today and elsewhere, and I will refer to a paragraph of it so that it is very clear what I am talking about. Guideline 4.3 (c) states:
Government agencies, including the Commissioner of Taxation, shall not directly or indirectly disclose tax file number information . . .

This Government agency, the Department of Employment, Education and Training, which apparently wants much lower ranking officers to have access to this information, cannot handle it at present. I do not know why we should be making it easier for it. I would like to refer to section 11 of the Privacy Act and its relevance in this matter. Section 11 (1) states:

A person who is (whether lawfully or unlawfully) in possession or control of a record that contains tax file number information shall be regarded, for the purposes of this Act, as a file number recipient.

So when the Smiths got the Browns' tax file assessment and tax file number, under the definition of the Privacy Act they were tax file number recipients. They were in possession of it unlawfully, but that unlawfulness, of course, related to the actions of the Department and not the Smiths. There was no unlawful act. Mind you, Mr Deputy Speaker, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) would say that the Smiths, by virtue of opening an envelope addressed to them containing information that was not theirs, could have been acting unlawfully-the parallel he is giving is about people opening envelopes containing information that does not belong to them. If the Smiths had not dealt with it expeditiously, let us say if they had handed it over to a staff member of the member of Parliament they went to see, according to the Treasurer they would have committed an unlawful act. However, they posted it back to the Department. Who knows who in the Department has since handled that tax file assessment with the attached number and the other information on it.

I do not know whether the Minister cares. I will be interested to hear whether he does. He is going to have a lot of time to do his homework, because this debate will not finish tonight, it will be in continuation when we come back in more than three weeks time. But I would expect the Minister to come back with something a little better than the answer he gave me to my question today. I think we should have a detailed statement from the Minister on how his Department is handling people's taxation information and a detailed explanation of how this could possibly have happened. He does not have to know what happened in the case of the Smiths and the Browns, as they are not their names. He will find out their names well and good if they decide to pursue a prosecution. But that is not the point. If it has happened in this case-where the recipient just happened to go and see the member of Parliament, who said, `Post it back straight away'; she did not even take a photocopy because he knew the implications of it-who knows how many cases it has happened in. In any event, where is the Smiths' assessment?

There is only one physical way this could have happened; after applications are received, at some stage tax assessment notices are physically removed from the application. They are not kept attached in such a way that they cannot be removed. The fact that it has happened to two people, Smith and Brown, shows that it is not just an isolated incident. The fact that Brown's assessment can be attached to Smith's form-the form was the right one-shows the amount of diligence taken by officers of this Department in the handling of highly confidential and personal information about applicants for Austudy. The possibilities are, of course, endless. I would like the Minister to give some details about that. I want to know who handles the assessments now and how they are handled. I want to know the changes that this legislation will bring about; who will be handling the assessments in future and how they will be handled. Why must it be the original assessment, and not the alternative that the Department of Social Security quite adequately uses for a totally parallel payment? Why is it not possible for the Department of Employment, Education and Training to follow the same course?

My time is close to running out and I know others are hoping to speak tonight before we adjourn. I strongly support the second reading amendment moved by the shadow Minister for education, the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale). It is a pity that the honourable member for Canning (Mr Gear), who spoke before me, is not still in the House. When he made his waffly speech about `our tax policy' and `our Medicare policy', `our health policy' or our whatever-else policy, we found out what his Government was really doing and how little it cares. We have had a lot of lip service on the subject of privacy, confidentiality, care and concern about people. Here are some really distressed people, who are not wealthy, or they would not be receiving Austudy. What is the Minister going to do about those people?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As previous speakers have indicated, the Student Assistance Amendment Bill seeks to make a number of relatively minor changes to the Student Assistance Act 1973, which gives a basis for both Austudy and post-graduate awards. Its purpose is a general tidying up of the Student Assistance Act altering wording and facilitating management. In some areas it is pedantic, as the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale) so rightly said in this place earlier this evening.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst the Opposition generally supports the provisions of the Bill, more important are the Government's philosophical and practical flaws inherent in its general approach to higher education. I do not wish to delay the House at this late hour. However, it is impossible to talk about student assistance without drawing on the rationale for student contribution. In order to do that, I would like to highlight, and draw to the attention of the House, two media releases and to contrast them; one by the honourable member for Deakin and the other by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins).

Taking first the media release by the honourable member for Deakin, I will highlight the points he makes in relation to student contributions and student assistance. In the context of releasing the Liberal and National parties' higher education policy on 23 February, he said:

The Policy also commits a Liberal National Government to a thorough review of AUSTUDY with improved income support as budgetary circumstances permit, and an independent enquiry into inadequacies in the post-graduate award system.
A loans scheme with generous repayment terms would help needy students meet the costs of the annual tuition charge.
The graduate tax is nothing but a tax on knowledge imposed by a Labor Government that has no respect for academic excellence and no vision for the young people of this nation.
By forcing students into debt to the tax man, the Hawke Government has shown that it does not understand the needs of young Australians.

This is an appalling act of discrimination, which will make it harder than ever for young people to get ahead and make ends meet when they graduate and find jobs. The $1,800 a year graduate tax discriminates against young people and will cause students to start their working lives with tax debts of over $6,000. A Liberal and National Party government would ensure that one in four students, as previous speakers from this side of the House have said, funded by the Federal Government through national education awards, receive a totally free education, with the others paying $600 a year as an annual tuition charge. On 1989 enrolment figures, this would mean that in excess of 100,000 higher education students would receive a free education on the basis of merit and/or need in Australian universities, colleges of advanced education and institutes of technology. The policy guarantees that the number of national education awards presented during the 1989-91 triennium will not be less than the number of student places projected in the 1988 Budget Papers.

The Liberal and National parties are committed to easing the burden on young people in general, and have decided to set a level of $600 for that annual tuition charge. We believe that the charge of $600 for other student is a fair and affordable contribution to full-time study. We will ensure that students have a choice of paying it up-front at the time of enrolment, paying it off through the year on a semester basis, or repaying it through a loans scheme. The annual tuition charge is a sensible and practical response to students' concerns while also satisfying their educational and economic needs.
I turn to the press release issued by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training in which he criticised the honourable member for Deakin (Mr Beale). He said:

Students would not be exempted on the basis of merit, but on some dangerous sounding system of Commonwealth-State assessment which sound reminiscent of the proponents of the master race during the 1930s.
How absurd can one get! He continued:

Not only do Mr Beale's and Mr Howard's sums not add up, but their plans to impose a $600 up-front fee will mean thousands of young Australians will be discouraged from going on to university and college by the fee.
That is clearly not true. He continued:
. . . The system of funding would produce a funding shortfall relative to the resourcing levels committed in the current Government's funding decision for the 1989-91 triennium.
That is blatantly untrue.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is misleading.

—It is very misleading; it is untrue. I would like to point out to the Government and to the Minister for Employment and Education Services (Mr Duncan), who is at the table, that the Government has indicated that it expects to raise $41.8m this year, rising to $170m in 1991-92. Even if one uses the figures for student places of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, our scheme would raise $146.7m in 1989, rising to $170.1m in 1991. I suggest that the Minister's maths is almost as bad as his famous interest rate predictions.

SPEECH.PARA: Unlike the emotive, ideological rubbish-and it is nothing more than that-which I heard in this place earlier this evening from the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) and the honourable member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon), I do not believe that higher education is the preserve of the relatively privileged in Australia. It has been possible over the years for people on relatively modest incomes to enter higher education. By what stretch of the imagination could a massive increase in costs to students be said to improve the access of the under-privileged? I believe that, on the one hand, the higher education contribution scheme, the so-called graduate tax, is objectionable philosophically, that it provides a significant financial disincentive for students from low income and disadvantaged families, and that, from a practical perspective, it is unworkable administratively. On the other hand, the Opposition's alternative policy, whilst acknowledging that there is no such thing as a free education if the number of tertiary places is to be expanded, at least provides a workable and equitable solution.
Papers

I favour any higher educational system that will restore a sound funding basis and that will give State governments greater responsibility for planning future development in our States. On that point I welcome the Queensland Government's decision to afford full university status progressively over the three years from 1 January 1990 to the Darling Downs Institute of Advanced Education in my electorate. Not everything the Minister puts forward in his higher education policy is wrong; some of it is very sensible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Precious little.

—There are some major aspects with which I would disagree. Some of it has a good deal that will help the system. However, and I will finish on this point, it seems to me that there is a serious danger that his cure will be more painful than the disease and may even kill the patient.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Mr P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition released in the last fortnight a visionary and imaginative higher education policy. It is one which rebuts so much of the ideological bent of the Government's approach to higher education: the Government's forced merger of a great many tertiary institutions which are so reluctant to downgrade their standards in these forced amalgamations; the Government's widespread appointments of political hacks to senior positions within tertiary institutions so as to reflect its particular ideological prejudices; and, moreover, its discriminatory, unfair and burdensome higher education tax. However much the Government tries to dress it up as a graduate tax, the truth remains that this form of levy acts as a disincentive to students obtaining higher education in this country. Who could argue that this country needs a greater number of graduates from tertiary institutions? Who could argue that we fall behind most other Western countries in regard to graduates, particularly in the fields of science and engineering.
—What are they doing to science and research?

—What is the Government doing to science and engineering? Heavens above! Amongst secondary students and, of course, amongst tertiary students it is actively discouraging science and engineering as a career. The fact is that research in our tertiary institutions has been reduced to almost a notional level. There are researchers in our institutions who do not have the equipment or the funding to continue their programs. They do little else, tragically for the economic future of this country, but sit around twiddling their thumbs.
—What are they doing to CSIRO?

—What is the Government doing to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO), as the honourable member for Deakin and the distinguished shadow Minister for education asks? It is bleeding to death the flagship of science in this country. It is doing to CSIRO exactly what it is doing to the research effort in higher education institutions. It is tragic for the future of this country that so few young people see science as a worthy career. It is not simply a matter of remuneration; it is more a matter of career structure. They have to know, firstly, that there is some sort of security in the form of tenure, as well as a career path which they can follow to senior positions. At present the universities are in absolute uproar as they band-aid outdated equipment, some of which, incidentally, poses a serious health risk to scientists who operate it and daily undergo risk of personal injury.

SPEECH.PARA: The truth is that science in this country is in a downward spiral, an absolute free fall, as this Government presides over the destruction of science. What better evidence is there of that but the bitterness, the absolute hatred, that exists between the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) and the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones). The rules of this House, if not common decency, prevent me from telling the people of Australia what the Minister for Education called the Minister for Science in a bitter and antagonistic meeting last week. It ranks with ex-President Richard Nixon's expletive deleted tapes; it shows the disarray that exists between education and science in this country.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: General Practitioners-Unemployment-`Authority Required' Prescriptions-Migration Applications-Ethiopia-Minister for Defence Science and Personnel-Mr Bernie Newson

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., the debate is interrupted. I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sawford Mr R.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) gave a wonderful audition for the comedy hour. The essential attributes of the agreement `Raising the Standard-General Practice and Quality Patient Care' between the Commonwealth and the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners is based on a sound rationale. It develops appropriate processes that acknowledge the special relationship between general practitioners (GPs) and patients. It is task orientated to provide an improved quality care for patients, better qualified GPs and cost effectiveness for the taxpayer. The package is completed by an effective review and monitoring independent of the Government and the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners. The focus of the agreement is on the provision of primary care. It is a preventative policy that raises the status and influence of GPs whilst providing improved quality medical care.

SPEECH.PARA: The agreement reaffirms the precious relationship between patient and GP. It also reasserts the primary role of the GP in medical care. Patients would benefit from a person continuing comprehensive care. The long term plan well into the next century deserves the overwhelming support of the community, the medical profession and this Parliament. By continuing their medical education and quality assurance programs, GPs will improve the quality of care for their patients. There has been indicated a sensible transition period until 1995, after which doctors seeking to enter general practice will be required to undertake specific postgraduate training in general practice.

Well trained and experienced GPs could significantly reduce health costs in the secondary and tertiary sectors by appropriate investigation and management at the primary level and by accurate referral to other sectors where appropriate. This greater emphasis on the GP as the gatekeeper of medical care will have obvious benefits. GPs will be able to spend more time with patients where necessary and they will be in a better position to discourage inappropriate and expensive referrals to specialists and unnecessary ordering of pathology, radiology and pharmaceuticals. In effect, changes are being sought in work practices which will result in increased productivity in general practice through improvement in the quality of patient care.

The new schedule, including fee differentials, will be implemented from 1 August 1989. It is expected that around 90 per cent of GPs will immediately qualify for enrolment on the new vocational register-a similar arrangement to that currently applying to specialists. The new schedule will contain four new content-based descriptors for GP consultations, some of which would include a time element in addition to the content element. Standards of GP practice will inevitably be raised. The inclusion of the time element in some of the descriptors will limit the potential for a drift to higher priced services and, immediately, will make it easier and simpler for patients to understand just what they are paying for. The date of 1 August 1989 is appropriate for the implementation of the agreement. This will allow for the passage of the necessary legislation, for the voluntary registration of GPs, and for the information on the changes to be widely distributed among doctors and patients.

The package is completed by an effective monitoring system. The monitoring and auditing of the use of the new content-based items will be carried out by a peer review body independent of the Government and the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners but, importantly, with the support of the college. It is, of course, in the best interests of the profession that the standards and codes of conduct are maintained. The new monitoring process will extend the current profile-based system to include random practice audits and assessments of the appropriateness of specialist referrals, diagnostic tests and prescribing pharmaceuticals. For doctors who do not qualify or who chose not to enrol on the vocational register, the present time-tiered items will remain, which will ensure that patients of doctors not enrolled are not disadvantaged by the new arrangements.

In summing up, it is patently obvious that agreement to this package will mean that the overwhelming majority of all those directly affected will be winners-patients, general practitioners and government. Patients can be sure of receiving top quality medical care at a reasonable cost. General practitioners will have an improved status and will play a more influencial role in health care, and government and, therefore, the community at large can be assured that the taxpayers' funds are properly spent through Medicare on the most cost-effective care for patients. But most important of all, it focuses upon positive and constructive benefits for people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Contrary to what is popular opinion in the community, it strikes me as I look around this Parliament that it may well be that the workers of Australia are represented by the Opposition and not by the Government. In fact, if we look at those who occupy the benches on either side of this Parliament and we consider their backgrounds, we discover that those who have actually had to depend on a day's physical work in order to make ends meet are more represented on this side of the House than the academics and union representatives that presently make up the Government. I might be forgiven for observing that I wonder whether there are not those on the other side of the House who think that manual labour is a visitor from Spain.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, I want to read to you a letter that came to me from the District Council of Saddleworth and Auburn which, as the honourable member for Mayo (Mr Downer) can vouch, is hardly the most radical local government body in the electorate of Wakefield. The District Clerk wrote to me in the following terms:
Dear Sir,
I have been instructed by my Council to write to you on the rather sensitive issue of employment for the long term unemployed.

From time to time, messages of concern are conveyed to the Council over the lack of interest by many unemployed to find full time employment. We note these concerns, but until now have not thought it our business to take up these complaints with the Department of Social Security or yourself; however the following situation occurred recently which directly affected the Council.

A local unemployed person had approached the Council seeking casual work and we did engage him for a short while last year giving him employment doing footpath work. He worked quite well on his own and we advised him that we would consider his services again when the need arose.
Soon after he ceased work with us, he and his wife returned to England for about six months.

Recently we were again in need of casual labour and employed this person to carry out various manual tasks working both alone and also with the Council Work gang. In all he was employed for 10 days and paid $655.21.
Once the person began working with our other permanent employees he began complaining that the work was too heavy and demanding, and that financially he was better off on the unemployment benefits.
This was causing concern to our workers and affecting their morale so the matter was reported to our Works Supervisor, who confronted the employee.
He was informed by the employee that he would be giving up the position because:
(a) He was $50 per week worse off in direct payment
(b) When the fact was taken into account that he had to have a cut lunch and also a shower every day there was a further loss of $50 per week.
(c) The work was too demanding
(d) He did not like the early start in the morning

Obviously this person will not be employed again by the Council, although at this time we would still have about 4/5 weeks casual work available immediately with the possibility of more later in the year.

This type of situation can only be described as ridiculous, when a person has no incentive to find work being paid more to stay at home. Obviously the unemployment benefits are too high when considering all the fringe benefits as well. This person has only his wife as a dependant.
We are also aware that another local unemployed person was offered fulltime work at over $400 per fortnight, but refused it because of the same reasons as in our experience.

The Clerk goes on in the letter but time will not permit me to read the rest of it. I simply want to conclude on this note: I do not stand here making a plea for sweatshop conditions. I stand here making a plea not on behalf of a private employer who might be accused of exploiting these people but on behalf of a local governing body obliged to meet minimum standards. We are denying this person the right to a sense of self-achievement, a sense of incentive and a sense of doing what he ought to be doing in order to make provision for his family. We are denying it because we simply do not oblige him to work in order to receive unemployment benefits. The honourable member may sit gloating but while he does so he denies him what is a fundamental human right-the right to make provision and not merely live by some sort of cargo cult mentality.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grace Mr E.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to an urgent constituent inquiry of 16 February 1989 which has confirmed, to my disappointment, the widely-held suspicion that there exists amongst the medical fraternity a small clique of doctors who are waging, to the detriment of the physical and emotional well-being of their patients, an insidious campaign against the Government's 1988 May statement decision to place certain expensive drugs on the authority list of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. It is well known, of course, that some doctors have strongly disagreed with the original decision to place some 53 expensive drugs on the authority list, and it is recognised that a legitimate and proper campaign exists to convince the Government to review the matter. This is despite the fact that this decision, and the subsequent re-evaluation which resulted in 34 drugs being withdrawn from the list, were taken on the advice of the Pharmaceuticals Benefits Advisory Committee, which is a committee consisting of medical practitioners.

SPEECH.PARA: However, in light of the events that have taken place following the abovementioned constituent inquiry, it is now obvious to me that some doctors have been prepared to elevate this campaign to a sinister and morally indefensible level. In this constituent's case I was approached by a migrant woman with a very restricted knowledge of the English language. She had been sent to my office by a local consulting physician, Dr Lunn of 17 Moore Street, Liverpool, after he had advised her that he was unable to prescribe the urgent heart medication that her mother required because he first required Government authority. Evidently Dr Lunn had told her that it normally took two weeks for authorisation to be received and there was nothing he could do to assist, despite the fact that the constituent's mother had already used the last of her supply of the medication. As the constituent's English was marginal at best, I asked my electorate assistant to contact Dr Lunn at his surgery to get more details on the matter. Dr Lunn's secretary confirmed that the good doctor was unable to prescribe the medication required and she further confirmed that the doctor had asked the constituent to visit her local Federal member to protest by saying that Dr Lunn was not in favour of the recent change and was in no way prepared to dispense the prescription.

Obviously on hearing of Dr Lunn's actions I was most concerned, and I made enquiries to ascertain the substance of the allegations. What I discovered, of course, was that Dr Lunn's advice to his patient was false because the Government has already made allowances to give urgent prescriptions. Simply, this amounted to doctors either phoning the emergency number sent to all doctors for immediate authorisation, or writing `urgent' across the prescription, in which case pharmacists would instantly dispense in lieu of authorisation. After receiving this information I instructed my electorate assistant to contact Dr Lunn and advise him of the avenues of action that were open. At this stage of course I was assuming that Dr Lunn was not aware of the emergency arrangements that were in place. After all, nobody could really believe that a doctor would be so vicious and cold-blooded as to allow a patient to leave his surgery knowing that the patient could be worried and confused over not being able to obtain what he might believe to be a crucial medication. Certainly nobody could conceive of a doctor taking that course of action with a patient with little understanding of the English language. I was wrong.

Unfortunately it was the case that Dr Lunn was not interested in knowing about, or utilising, the two available methods for prescribing authority list medications immediately. Dr Lunn's receptionist offered, after conferring with her employer, the spurious excuse that he could not mark the prescription as urgent as it would not be a legal prescription without a stamp on it. They were not prepared to even discuss the issue of the emergency phone numbers. My request to speak with the good doctor personally was rejected outright and the conversation was concluded there. Fortunately for my constituent and her mother my office was quickly able to contact another doctor and he carried out the appropriate procedure to obtain the necessary medication immediately.

However, the question does remain as to how many other innocent people have been put through the same emotional turmoil by doctors who have turned their backs on their Hippocratic oath, and the ethics of the medical profession, in order to strengthen their hand in what amounts to a glorified industrial dispute. How many other patients have left their doctor's surgery frightened and confused at their inability to obtain important medications? Unfortunately, my investigations have revealed that Dr Lunn's reprehensible actions are not unique in the medical fraternity. Certainly the overwhelming majority of doctors would never contemplate using such cruel and callous tactics to further their industrial aims, but most of those to whom I have spoken confidentially are aware of others who have taken part in such a campaign. I am sure all members of this House will join with me in saying that it is a sad day for medicine and our community in general when such tactics can even be considered, let alone used.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sullivan Mrs K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly about the Government's latest action in relation to the review of migration applications. Last year the Government put forward an amendment to the Migration Act which was to require those who were applying for a review of a migration application to pay a fee with their application. Also, the legislation said that in future the grounds for a review would be limited. However, it did not detail the grounds of the limitation. An objection was raised by the Opposition in debate on that amendment to the Act because we said that there was a change of policy and the amendment, saying that the grounds for a review in future being provided for in regulation, was not acceptable; in other words, the grounds for review had to be detailed in the legislation and not done by regulation. In the event the Bill was amended in the Senate and the requirement for the paying of a fee was removed.

SPEECH.PARA: The Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has proceeded to require applicants wanting a review to pay a fee when putting in that application. I believe that the Attorney- General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has advised the Department that the requirement for people to pay a fee is illegal, which is something we said at the time. In the meantime many hundreds of applications have been put in, none of which would be entertained without the payment of a fee. The people putting in the applications have paid the fee and it has not been made clear what will happen in their case. My office-as I am sure is the case with the offices of other members-has simply been contacted verbally by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs to say that, as of several days ago, the Department would not accept any more requests for reviews of applications until 30 March. So now the situation is even worse than it was before. Before people were required to pay a fee that legally they could not be required to pay, but their only recourse was to go to court to challenge the requirement for the fee. Now they cannot even submit an application for a review until 30 March. The only applications that are being considered are those which were postdated a few days ago. We are told that the rule will be changed, we will have another fee called a second application fee and there will be some requirement for legislation. I hope that this time the Government will get the requirements straight and will put in that legislation the grounds on which a review will be considered, because that is yet to be clarified.

I question the right of the Government to take the actions that it has. When it has been queried in the past we have been told by departmental officers that because there was a lack of legislation in a certain area they could do these things; in other words, they were doing it without Parliament's scrutiny. They were doing things that were not provided for under legislation. They were being done in a backdoor sort of way and nothing could be done about it. It is now clear that the Attorney-General has told the Department that it was not legal to require the payment of that fee.

I think that the Minister should explain fully just what the Government proposes to do. Does it intend to charge a fee as from 30 March on the same basis as the previous, now discontinued, fee? If that previous fee were illegal, surely the new fee will be illegal. Maybe giving it a different name will change that, but it ought to be explained. On what grounds is the whole question of review of applications to migrate to proceed? At present those who want to put in applications to review do not know on what basis they should proceed and, as a member of Parliament, I do not know on what basis I should advise them. I can only tell them that they cannot do it at present; it is all frozen until 30 March; sometime after 30 March they will be able to do it again; they will have to pay a fee of $240; and I am not sure whether they will have to pay that fee as from 30 March or not. In short, the whole thing is a great jumble.

If the Minister at the time-the former member for Port Adelaide, Mick Young-had got the procedure right when he had been the Minister, none of this need have happened. At the time the Opposition offered him its full cooperation, but said the cooperation would not extend to something as fundamental as policy on immigration review being contained in regulations; it had to be contained in legislation which was open to debate by the Parliament. I trust that the new Minister will show a greater regard for the Parliament and for those seeking a review of migration applications in his future acts in this matter. As a member of parliament, I anxiously look forward to what he will do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to reply to the speech that was given in this chamber last night in the adjournment debate by the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher). I tried to reply last night but, unfortunately, I did not get the call. The speech was devoted to what he perceived as the current situation in Ethiopia. I must say that I thought the speech was a disgrace not only in that it was inaccurate but also because it was grossly offensive to a delegation from Ethiopia, which delegation was entertained last night in this Parliament by the Presiding Officers. Members of the delegation visited the Parliament at Question Time yesterday and have been here for the last few days.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) talked tonight about traditions. Members of the Opposition are very fond of talking in this place about traditions and standards when it suits them. There are certain matters of courtesy and tradition and I must say that last night the honourable member for Curtin breached all of these. Having been the leader of a parliamentary delegation to Ethiopia last year, I issued the invitation, on behalf of the Presiding Officers, for a delegation from the Shengo to visit Australia. Wherever my delegation went in Ethiopia, we were met with kindness and help. We were not abused in the way that the honourable member for Curtin abused our guests last night. It was also my pleasure last Sunday to welcome the Ethiopian delegation to Australia. I wonder whether, in the week or so that the delegation has been here, the honourable member for Curtin has taken the opportunity to meet with any member of the Ethiopian delegation, or whether his mind is so closed that he could not do this.

We do not hear members of the Opposition saying very much about Nicaragua or places like that. They support the brutal activities going on there. They support brutal regimes. But, immediately anyone is regarded in their view as being from a leftist government, venom just spews out of their mouths. One of the things the honourable member for Curtin talked about last night was 2,000 Cuban troops in Ethiopia. I do not know whether there are 2,000 Cuban troops in Ethiopia. I did not see any Cuban troops, and the information I have is that there are none there.

But, having said that, Ethiopia does have problems; no-one would deny that. Ethiopia has dreadful problems. Since the time of the revolution, it has been faced with not one but two civil wars. It has a huge refugee problem. Hundreds of thousands of its refugees are not Ethiopian refugees but have come from the Sudan. Ethiopia, one of the poorest countries in the world, is looking after and caring for these refugees.

I am somewhat constrained in what I can say here because the official delegation report has not yet been presented to the Parliament, although I must say that that has not stopped some members of the delegation from releasing their own reports, which have received wide publicity.

Last night the honourable member for Curtin said that the drought in Ethiopia was caused by the resettlement program. That is absolute rubbish. We went through Eritrea and Tigre. We saw the ground there and the results of poor agricultural policies over many years. In many respects, the only way that that land can regain productive capacity is to have a villagisation program. We discussed with the people there some of the aspects of villagisation. I must say that I was not terribly impressed with some of it; nevertheless, we understand it.

This is the plea I make to those on the other side: it is all very well to criticise these countries but we should try to understand some of the problems they are facing. For example, at the time of the revolution, they had an illiteracy rate of about 90 per cent. The brutal regime of Haile Selassie kept the people down. They are trying to come to terms with some of the problems they are facing. If we reopened our mission in Ethiopia-which, in my view, we should never have closed-perhaps with that direct link with Ethiopia people such as the honourable member for Curtin might be better informed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Webster Mr A.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday in the Senate Senator Newman made a very clear personal explanation related to a misrepresentation by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) regarding his claim that she intended to sack half the lieutenant-colonels in the Royal Australian Army. That furphy was repeated today by his colleague, the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mrs Kelly). It can only be assumed that today's gross misrepresentation is not an accident and that it almost constitutes a deliberate attempt by the Government to mislead the Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very unsatisfactory situation. The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel further misrepresented Senator Newman today in answering a dorothy dix question about her new telephone number system, which she launched with the help of two admirals, one air vice-marshal, one general, two brigadiers, a deputy secretary, a first assistant secretary, together with 50 assorted others. Senator Newman did not proceed to debate the cost of the media launch or the Minister's expenditure priorities in relation to the needs of Service families. The Minister complained that Senator Newman had already put out a statement before her media conference while not knowing anything about her new telephone number at all. This is the misrepresentation which has to be answered.

Senator Newman has been very well informed about the Minister's secret weapon for several months-that the computer equipment for it cost $108,000, that the Minister has retained an advertising agency, that she has employed three staff, that she has acquired new office furniture for it and that she plans to spend hundreds of thousands of dollars on advertising in the months to come. Senator Newman has known for some time that the Service spouses regard this as a very low priority in terms of the needs of Defence Force families.

Senator Newman also knew that the family liaison officers are not allowed to be counsellors, that there are 38,000 married Service personnel and that 34,000 of those personnel have children. All of these are basic facts which the Minister revealed her ignorance of at her own press conference.

Another misrepresentation was made today. The Minister accused Senator Newman of attacking quite viciously a former member of her staff, somebody who could not return the attack. I want to place on record precisely what the `vicious attack' was. I quote from Senator Newman's press release:

When you phone Mrs Kelly's new 008 hot line, not only will you hear Mrs Kelly's former member of staff tell you what the Family Liaison Officers and Service Commanders have already told you, but at a cost of only $108,000 you will also receive a new computer system.
This hardly constitutes a vicious attack.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) for being in the House. I would like to give him some documents in relation to Mr Bernie Newson of Cooma, a Vietnam veteran who is totally and permanently disabled due to war caused injuries while on war service in Vietnam. On a later occasion I propose to say a little more about this matter. I appreciate, as I said, the fact that the Minister is in the House. In letters to the Minister, Mr Newson has concentrated on the report of the Royal Commission into the Use and Effects of Chemical Agents on Australian Personnel in Vietnam. I believe that I have new material that will assist the Minister in his investigations. Mr Newson has concentrated on discrepancies that he has found in the report and he has asked me to help him and thousands of other veterans in getting that message across. Mr Newson says that the Minister has not considered American D declassified documents that completely contradict the findings of the Royal Commission. I propose to get those documents to the Minister. I know that he will consider them in full detail when I do that.
